175969331,"So it seems like one benzo a night for sleep seems to be ok. Maybe cuz of the fact that the brain repairs itself during sleep and is a sedated state during that time anyways. 1mg of Ativan or 7.5mg of zopiclone. My mom takes 1mg of Ativan every night to sleep and has been doing it for ~3 years so I was looking up reviews because I was worried. But people have been taking 1mg a night for 15-20 years with no problem. The reason that I'm worried is because of the ""Panic attack effect""!!!, stop taking and then BOOMBOOMBOOM the heart beats and you hear it in your ears.. My mom can't ever have that.. But if she sticks to 1mg a night and never takes extra, that won't happen. It works for psychophysiological insomnia if that's what it is. Some people just can't do proper sleep hygiene.. It's impossible because there's so much on their minds. So I assume that I can take one zopiclone every night to sleep for 1-2 years until I fix my mental health - I estimate that that's how long it's going to take - Cons
idering how well my mental health has been getting the past 3-4 years. It's like a moderate benzo cuz it doesn't work for anxiety - Just as a hypnotic. And my dads friend took one zopiclone for 15 years and it put him to sleep every time. He remembers everything and tells stories like they happened yesterday so there's no problem with his memory or cognition. Some people say that zopiclone makes them feel stupid in the morning but a coffee helps me. There's so many scare stories about benzos and although they are true - Only in high doses every day. Newtus took 0.5mg of Xanax 4x a day and then had to stop cold turkey (Like many doctors do to people) - So there's one bit of second hand information."

175969365,"You've got two things going on: pain and anxiety. That's a very tough combination! I don't have significant pain, so I can't be of any help there, except to empathize. about anxiety, I had moderately debilitating anxiety. I've tried Pamelor (one of the tricyclics like you are taking) and it didn't work; in fact, I couldn't sleep well when on that drug. I've also taken Zoloft, which was okay, but I didn't stay on it too long. Ten years ago, when my elderly parents needed care and moved to be near us--and job stress--I knew I needed to take something to dampen the anxiety. Citalopram, which is FDA approved for anxiety, worked well after the initial adjustment period, and has ever since, although I upped the dose from 20 mg to 40 mg about 5 years ago. I have not seen a psychiatrist, though my internal medicine doctor and sleep doctor both suggested one of the newer anti-anxiety meds (citalopram). I have seen a psychologist to learn CBT (cognitive behavior therapy). The medication to me is a anti-anxie
ty foundation that I have built on with other coping skills. It's been hard work, but worth it. On a non-anxious/calm scale of 1 to 10 most days are 7 or above. The excrement still hits the ventilation system now and then, but that's life. The important thing is that I know what to do to get back on track."

175969406,"Hey Maryland2020. I'm sorry that your son is going through this. Covid has had an impact on everyone's mental health. For people that have suffered from mental illness in the past I think it is that much harder. Routines have been interrupted, the help that we receive has to be modified and the list goes on. When I was 19 and in college I didn't have any friends. I just had people I went to class with. If you added the virus in I would have really struggled. My best piece of advice is to make sure that he knows that you are there for him and that you won't judge him. As a parent myself, I'm sure that you already do that. Sometimes it just helps to look back on how we felt telling our mothers things :). I would tell him about your concerns if you haven't already. Sometimes to hear the concerns of someone you care about can give a person the push that they need to get help. If he doesn't want to go to a dr to prescribe him medication then a therapist is always an option. Depending on the restrictions 
right now is could be virtual or in person. For me, a therapist gave me someone else to be accountable to. It gives me a routine that I really need (may not be something your son needs). I always put in my posts that I am an open book. If you have anything that I can help you with shoot me a message or reply on here. I always follow the thread I comment on and I am on here most nights."
175969407,"I'm stressing myself out about the whole moving thing. It wouldn't be till june at the earliest so I'm trying to just distract myself from all the anxiety inducing thoughts. 175969454,"My thoughts on it are: It grasps at the truths of the meaning of human suffering and its relationship to meaning. It details a psychiatrist's journey through concentration camps and Nazi Germany to finding what makes life worth living. It's not a linear path, and I don't think the book was intended to be one. Rather, it shows by way of example and also through other means, why life matters. He discusses the concept of logotherapy -- which is essentially ""meaning""-therapy. I thought it was a worthwhile read for those reasons. It's also fairly short as far as impactful books go. Hopefully that will help you determine whether you want to read it or not."

175969506,"ihave many years experience with buspar. first -its not even close to the strength of klonopin(which i also have tons of experience with), i have used Buspar prn for ever and its works well for me this way but isnt strong enough to stop a panic attack. your dr if first i ever heard prescribe it prn and bid. i think its a wise move and more should do it. i use a 1/3 pill for mild episodes and 1/2 for worse attacks of anxiety. buspar is a mild and very safe drug and mixes well with every ssri i know of so i dont think that your issue. but prozac is much stronger ssri than i like to take . i did take it for a few months and its very effective for depression. drs are reluctant now to prscribe many benzos now and they can be a nightnare or blessing depending on how you use them, i say use your old pills for rescue and your and your dr work out a solution for a replacement. a large percentage report buspar as ineffective but for me it works very well. i only use it prn and see no need to have it constant

175969507,"Well, there are two schools of thought here... So, pre-DSM-III, schizoid PD, schizotypal PD and avoidant PD were considered the same disorder. Some people are still mad about it. Anyway, as you probably know, both schizoid PD and avoidant PD sufferers typically want to spend time alone, but the reasons they give for wanting to be alone are very different. Schizoids typically say they do not like spending time with others, while avoidants do want relationships with others but fear ridicule or rejection. Another contrast is that avoidants seem really sensitive to criticism while schizoids seem unaffected by praise or criticism. So, we have some dramatic opposites. Some psychoanalysts like to argue that schizoids are really just avoidants who are denying or repressing their fears of abandonment and judgement, but personally, I do not have any respect for psychoanalytics."

175969637,"I like Flowerblossoms' idea about one thing a day with your daughter. I might add, one thing a day for you. The thing for you might require you to row against a strong tide pulling you in the direction of I don't want to! Or, I can't! But, maybe if you wrote a list of these things, the next day choose from the list and accomplish it perhaps in baby steps, you might feel some satisfaction. Say, the thing with your daughter is baking cookies. You'll have the cookies! And you'll have fun with your daughter. It will drain you. So the thing for yourself should be small. Maybe create a count my blessings scrapbook page. I read that one should create an hour a day to feel really horrible about everything so after that hour you have to wait until the next day to dwell on the virus, etc. It sounded a little unrealistic to me, but perhaps give it a try? I hope these ideas are not too lame. I actually gave some similar thoughts to a friend on the phone and he kept responding, I'm not going to do that. Finally
, I said, that is the definition of crazy. Doing the same thing over and over, and expecting a different outcome. So try to break a pattern, do something different, see how it makes you feel. 175969640,"Hello fellow Schizoids / PsychForum , I'm a diagnosed 29 year old schizoid with a sorted mental health history, including periods of depression, anxiety, substance use and a long list of other possible pathologies which (I think) were just regressions from attempts to relieve my ""schizoidness"" that were misunderstood, diagnosed and so treated with medications without real consideration. We've all got our schizoid origins story and mine starts with my parents.. You might could say I have a lot of experience with mental health systems in the US I've been pouring over your board for a couple months now and really liked some of what I read. We're an introspective people (sort of by definition) and other member's interpretations of their lives has been really illuminating for me. Especially helpful has been the talk of fantasies because for the longest time I wasn't sure I ticked that box. I oscillate between reality and my fantasy quite a lot though, it turns out, and this realization was what made m
e believe I might ever get better. As a high-functioning schizoid who tried everything he could think of to feel 'Ok' I think maybe I can help other schizoids here too. So, hello. I'm OutsideIn and I'm glad to have joined your group ?"
175969641,Have you tried employment agencies? I’ve got several jobs from employment agencies. You just go in and fill out some initial paperwork and they find the job for you. In my neck of the woods we have employment agencies specifically for the disabled. They can either find you a regular job without telling the employer you’re disabled or they could find a company who hires the disabled.

175969684,"Though I haven't figured out the ""so what"" approach, I've noticed I get a surge of adrenaline sometimes when I'm reacting to things and I spend a surprising amount of time in that mode even if it's in connection to situations rather than what people say. I've made a point to ask questions instead of charging in. As a result, I've not gotten into any squabbles today and haven't made others on the defensive as much either. Also, trying to understand things that are illogical makes them less frustrating than judging them does. Tangenting over to: sleep deprived I'm going to collapse. I've barely slept and I can barely think or see straight and it causes the following to be on my mind along with everything else... There's a pillow. A spot of black catches my focus as it suddenly goes scurrying across it. It's a male falsewidow spider * yes, I can tell the difference - females have the stereotypical blackwidow shape. On on the other hand, male falsewidows do not, and like male blackwidows, their fangs 
can't break skin to envomate humans. Nonetheless, I hurriedly grab the pillow before he eight-leggedly crawls onto the bed. ""Why is he not in a cobweb?"" I muse to myself He speeds up his meandering into a trot hoping to make the jump over the ever increasing gap as I move his standing point further and further from his goal. The movement startles him. He transitions into a full-fledged gallop towards the higher ground with spindley legs flying everywhere, which coincidentally, is where my hand is. I half drop, half throw the pillow onto the floor. For a moment peace fills the room, but then I become worried as to whether he survived the landing. I rush over to it, just as he triumphantly climbs up towards me to reassure me that he survived. I start shaking and gently hitting his pillow against the ground trying to knock him off of it. It doesn't work. I don't want to lose sight of him, but I need to go get a cup to put him outside. First, I grab something to sweep him off what's mine. I've already referred 
to it as his (the arachnid's) pillow once. I hear a curious thud as he hits the floor. Again, I worry about the impact, but soon enough, he gathers his wits - and is off to the races again. I search around desperately for something I can put over him to no avail. I look back and he's gone. I ######6 hate it when I lose spiders."

175969712,"Hello, all! I'm new to this forum. Got Schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type. I feel comfortable here; I like it. As I'm moving along I'm striving for some self-discovery. That means to utilize things that I seem to hold dear. I would like to be able to discuss my illness with individuals who have been there and back again. I don't go to therapy currently, so this is a step that I hope to take for my well-being. I went through a period of being so down on myself. It seemed like no one was there for me, but I just sort of shirked away everything that people tried to throw at me. I try not to be an emotional person -- or something like that. When it all comes boiling over the way it did, I really wish there was somebody to hold onto. So, here is my chance to have some comforting words my way. I feel lost in the woods, and my illness is some vampire or sprite chasing after me with all its devouring and intimidation. It's attitude to me is like it isn't even me. And I did take psychology classes, but 
what it is is one big beast. I got my Invega shot though. They went up on the dose. I'm feeling like in the next few days, it's going to be alright. I'm feeling the affects off it more and more. I'm so glad they decided to put me on Invega. I really did pray they would. (I did not think I could just ask them for some reason). Low and behold, prayer answered. I'm actually feeling safe and sound. Like I don't need to fight back on anything since it is all attacking me. I really want to quit smoking also. I think that I finally made the decision to quit it forever. I have a pack and a little bit of another pack. Stupidly went to a gas station when I had my mind set on quitting. This habit comprises over half the time I'm awake, and it's time to quit. I'm no distinguished woman because I smoke cigarettes. Have to get it through my head. I'm putting off the de-addiction process because I just think that it will be excruciating. And I did it all these years. I think it's going to be fear of God like. But the doctor
s at the hospital when I got admitted in July 2019 made me a not addict of cigarettes. And it wasn't excruciating. Bless them. Went back to the cigarettes in July 2020. Stupidly. I feel like I need guidance for this (because I really got it in my mind I can't do this alone). I have it in mind that I am blindly grasping at straws. I love the sunlight now. One doctor told me to get some sunlight. And I was like a vampire with my sparkling skin because I hardly ever stepped outside. That is my reason for keeping with cigarettes. I am part Native American and my skin is an interesting color. My Grandma _NAME_ would tell stories of being a half Native American Indian. I look at my skin now and I'm like, ""Yes, you can tell it."" I cannot wait to tan this summer. I think I'm going to go outside and take pictures of the sun from the backyard again. And quit the smoking. Definitely. Maybe my Mom is more wisdom-atic than I believe about this. On a Facebook scan of my profile picture, supposed to tell what peoples from 
what countries you look like said, Polish, Swedish, Irish, and German. And my Grandpa was part Swiss by a family tree look at. Dad's, if I recollect well, his DNA testing, said Caucasian Mountains -- so I thought Turkey. I cannot remember what else. My sister's said ""Scandinavia"". She made a big show of it. And my Mom's family sigil said English with a wolf on it! I've never done a real family genealogy based on DNA obviously. I'm piecing together this stuff."

175969754,"Yeah it's hard. Also, give yourself some compassion. First off, dating is hard. Second, you are dealing with mental health issues. So give yourself an extra break for both of those things. I find the less I concentrate on dating, the more things go naturally. I know it's kind of a strange thing to try to express, but the less I worry about it, perhaps, the more things flow. That said, I haven't really been able to have a steady relationship ever. Also, I'm not opposed to the idea of being alone later in life, though I know you expressed the desire to be with someone. About revealing the diagnosis--don't treat it as an obligation--treat it as something you will reveal to whomever you're dating at the right moment when you feel comfortable. You don't need to tell everything on the first date (or even the second, or third, or fourth, etc.) All you really need to do when you're just starting to date someone is to see if you have a connection or not. If so, great. If not, then move on. Funny how I can g
ive dating advice but yet I've never had a real relationship."

175969772,"Of course, we all have social anxieties. However, serious shyness/severe social anxiety can be a real problem for those who suffer from it. Those who are rather shy in general are less likely to have lots of good quality relationships with friends. They're also more likely to get married later on in life than those who aren't shy. And they're less likely to get married at all compared to those who aren't shy. So if you're shy, I think it's a good idea to try to overcome it sooner in your life rather than putting it off later on. And if that means seeing a therapist or having to go on medication, then so be it. I just suggest this because if you're shy, I'd hate to see you miss out."

175969843,"Metal Illness.... there are no easy answers when up is down and light is dark. I think it's most important to recognize what her triggers may or may not be, what medication if any is or isn't having an affect positive or negative, and perhaps most importantly what if anything calms her down. You and your father need to emphasize and reinforce her understanding of your love for her, and that it is her condition that blinds her and misleads her to feel unloved. Help her be comfortable talking openly about what happens when she loses it. What brings on this panic of rejection? Discuss feelings and emotions in terms of trigger words or phrases that may inadvertently upset her, and discuss safe words and phrases that remind her that she can be calm and in control, that she is always loved, avid she is not defined by her illness. As a former teacher, counselor, and manager; one of the time tested approaches to dealing with difficult outbursts, troubled minds, or more unpredictable personalities is to giv
e them more responsibility... that you need her help with this, not the other way around. It may sound a little like letting the inmates run the asylum, but put her in charge of your family approach. Empower her with this leadership role. Have her show you where to tack up the safe words and phrases all over your home, even frame them if you fancy or even paint rooms new colors she likes. The positives will come from incorporating her and making it more of a family effort that she takes charge of.... Responsibility instills esteem and confidence. Decide on a ""safe zone"" for her to go to in the house that makes her comfortable as you all work together making her (and yourselves) more comfortable. Let her be the architect of your family's tranquility. I hope my words may be of some help on this Mothers Day. Strength & Hope - cres"

175969887,"I have such deep existential questions about myself lately. This whole thing, going into this school, has me questioning my identity as an individual. I can feel my brain morphing into this existential being. Not literally feel, but like sense or recognize, I mean. The whole past 5 years I’ve tried to keep my life superficial in my interests. Superficial, as in, not having my interests go deep like I did when I was sick. Because going too deep would cause psychosis. So I’d watch keeping up with kardashians, my 600 lb life, etc. Play stupid burner games like cheap games that only play to my interests for a week or so. I kinda kept away from books or read books that I already knew how they turned out, so it wouldn’t be a surprise to my psyche. Now...idk. I feel myself wanting to challenge myself again. Challenge my intelligence and build my knowledge. And For the first time in my life I’m actively reading a multitude of books. Not just one. And I’m actually reading them. Not just saying I a
m and hopefully meaning to get around to them. I wonder if it’s not a big deal to open my psyche/mind back open to new ideas about the world, or just to actively read the challenges of other people, etc, anything that challenges my brain capabilities/capacity. Not like reading/watching horror-type stuff that would put me into psychosis but just opening up to books that make me think deep again. No I’m not psychotic right now. If anything hypo, but this is something I that has been going on since I been in recovery. For a reason. When I would read my philosophy books again, I’d get into a conspiracy mode of thinking. But I don’t seem to now."

175969916,"So I've known this woman for almost two years. From the first time I saw her I knew there was something special about her. Last year we had a few attempts that fell through. It was just bad timing. She got involved with someone and I ""moved on"", while trying to remain friends. This spring she had some problems, at some point that relationship ended. I did what I could to support her. But, with the attempt at romancing her in my past, I was afraid my motives might be suspect. But it did lead to us slowly getting closer over the summer. In the fall we made plans to take a day trip together. It, didn't work out. Then we made some plans for dinner, they didn't work out. We made some plans for December, and also some plans to hang out. The hangout didn't work either. I tried several more times, but we just kept talking, and didn't get together. In our talk she showed me that she really is as special as I felt. I confessed those feelings to her. She said she wasn't interested in anyone right now. And a
sked to stay friends. Early December she hinted at developing a crush on me. I was afraid to move to soon and push her away. She slowed down how often she talked to me. The day of our plans came, and it was absolutely wonderful. It goes down as one of, if not the, best day of my life. It ended with a very nice hug. When she left I broke down into sobbing tears because I had never been that happy. She accidentally left something at my place, and said she would get it ""next time"". A few days later, she hinted that the dinner I had planned for Christmas sounded good. So I offered to cook it for her that night instead. She took me up on the offer. Then canceled 30 minutes before she was set to come over. It hurt, I asked if I could call her later, because I needed to talk to her about the effect all the cancelations were having on me. She didn't respond. I had a habit of telling her good morning and good night each day. She stopped replying to them to. Didn't respond over Christmas. The day after Christmas I wa
s just so tied up in knots I decided to do it through text. She didn't respond to that either. I saw her at work one day, neither of us had time to talk, but she seemed happy to see me. Then Monday I talked to my psychologist, she recommended that I give her space, stop sending good mornings/nights. My main worry was that any time in the past if I missed one, or wasn't as cheerful, she would get concerned. So I wrote an explanation for why I was stepping back. She didn't respond. The last words she's said to me were that she wouldn't be able to make it to dinner. She did post some things on her wall about depression. I did tell her good night that night, because I knew it would be something I miss. But the next morning I didn't even want to wake up... Just seemed pointless without saying good morning. And the next night was a living hell. She's an overthinker with depression. I understand that is probably why she cancels plans. And I feel horrible for confronting her about canceling again. Now I'm terrified t
hat at some point I hurt her, and this was the final straw. She hasn't blocked me, she still opens my messages. She just doesn't respond anymore. It's killing me, because... She's... I've never met anyone like her. The warmth I feel when I'm around her, it burns away everything else. For those precious moments I actually forget other people exist. I live in that moment. I'm still quiet and shy, but I'm not worried about the future... or reliving the past. The only thing that matters to me is right there. Not feeling her presence the world feels cold and dark, lightless and hopeless."

175969944,"I think the situation may have been miscommunicated here. I did something that was perceived to be possibly dodgy and it was flagged. It has been investigated and those batting my corner have waved it away. Something similar came to light afterwards and so it was brought up again. The question of my character/intent came up after that. The conversation was with a mentor who is batting for me. We had a quiet conversation about it and what's happening and what I need to do and he was giving the the inside scoop of what the others involved in the decision are thinking, where they are in the process, etc. Our conversation on be being reserved I think was good in intent. He said it wasn't a problem but that it might be better if I allowed others to engage with me more personally. Explicitly, he's said that he's quite happy for me to do my thing and go home. On the other hand, he said, it leaves me in situations like this where people don't know where to stand because they don't have a firm impression of 
me even after a couple of years. I came into the company and immediately was a top sales performer. I've been consistently the best since I got here and then there is murmur about it not all being above board. It's clear how that can lead to suspicion, especially if all they have to go off is a stellar sales record, reputation of somebody who has turned up to work high and slept around but otherwise no contact beyond talking to people who've been upset by my having ghosted them. The rest, about isolation, I think was just an offering of advice he wish he'd had at my age. I don't resent it and won't be seeking recourse for somebody explaining how they have related to the way I think and later have found that they were missing something then telling me that it may be worth considering if I am missing out too. The claims for my attention and to get to know me from coworkers aren't a pervasive issue nor is my reluctance to be involved (most of the time, since I do engage on some level). It was just an observation 
that's been gently made to me as a reminder that I might have an easier time if I was more open to volunteering myself. It's a valid point. If I had done that, the precarious situation wouldn't be, since there'd be more confidence in my character if people felt they know me better. I only really bothered with people I was interested in and it's clear how that might be an issue. I'm sure he doesn't think I'm on the verge of breakdown I think he just wanted to open up to me and let me know something private and personal that not many others know, in a show of trust and extension of an _NAME_ branch for me to have somebody there if I need it, even if I don't think I will."

175969955,"health.clevelandclinic.org 1. Some types of chest pain should send you to the emergency room immediately. 2. If you experience new or unexplained pain, pressure or discomfort in the center of your chest or in your arms, back, jaw, neck or upper stomach — along with shortness of breath, a cold sweat, nausea, fatigue or lightheadedness — for at least five minutes, call 911. These symptoms may signal a heart attack, or myocardial infarction. Immediate treatment is essential to save heart muscle. But when chest aches and pains are fleeting, it’s often something different. Symptoms that suggest another problem Cardiologist _NAME_, MD, notes that the following symptoms are unlikely to signal a heart attack: 1. Momentary chest discomfort, often characterized as a lightning bolt or electrical shock. Heart discomfort or pain is unrelenting, typically for several minutes. Momentary chest discomfort is more likely to result from musculoskeletal injury or inflammation, or nerve pain (e.g., a cracked rib, 
a pulled muscle in the chest wall or shingles involving the chest.) 2. Pinpoint chest discomfort that worsens with positional changes in breathing. Heart pain is usually diffuse, or radiating. Pinpoint discomfort that worsens with chest expansion (breathing, for instance) is more likely to involve the lungs. 3. Chest discomfort that gets better with exercise. Heart-related pain typically worsens with exercise. Sharp chest pain that improves with movement is more likely to have other causes (e.g., acid reflux.)"

175969973,I used to take .5 mg of Ativan (lorazepam) for a few years every night just to help me sleep and I took it for panic attacks. I have a different dr now who won’t prescribe me but a few at a time for panic attacks. I am ok with that and have ambien to help with sleep. If it helps you cope then I wouldn’t worry about the risks of being on it. That’s just my opinion though.

175969984,"I think all of us who long to be mothers feel this way at some point. Why do you think you will have postpartum depression (PND)? If you have high risk factors for it, do you have family support and what is the mother health support like in your area? I was average risk because of family history - I had had no depression but 3 of my siblings have it. When I was pregnant with my first because of my profession and that I was older everyone around me thought I was likely to get it. So after he was born they were all gently watching for signs, about once a week someone would pop in with a meal for us. However I was fine, I was so happy to finally be a mum and have had a healthy normal baby. Despite lack of sleep ( he didn't sleep through until 4years!!), which can kick PND off in people with no genetic history, I was ok. So we had number two 17 months later, this time only my new midwife was worried about PND but I was okay-ish. Remember if mums are honest most of us are really only ok-ish after the ba
by is born! Then when he was about 5 months old too many things happened at once - my eldest become a terror tot (normal toddler behaviour)my husband was away for work overseas for weeks at a time and both boys got croup, one after the other. So I got little sleep for weeks as I listened to their breathing all night long. Then I got full blown PND. My boys are 11 and 12, they are great, I am not 100% all the time but with light dose meds, friends to talk to and doing things that make me happy more often I am mostly ok. Which is realistic I think! Before you give up on your dream of a family, assess your support networks. How helpful will your husband be - be realistic here and do not expect too much - I thought mine would be great but alas no, did not got understand my depression at all, probably made me feel worse!! Do you have family who will help if things are hard - and if they are not? Are there people around you you trust to keep an eye out for you? I have been teaching for 20 years in some pretty tough 
areas and wealthy too, I have met very few terrible parents. Aside from addicts the worst parents are the selfish ones who cannot put their children first, who do not seem to be able to show them love with time. You already love the children you want to have, you'll be okay."

175970012,"It's good that you’re writing in. You said, “I can hear my heart beating in my ear,” under that title in the search engine, Health.harvard.edu says: “A. What (the patient who wrote into the Harvard website) describe(s) sounds like pulsatile tinnitus (pronounced TIN-nih-tus or tin-NITE-us). It is a type of rhythmic thumping, pulsing, throbbing, or whooshing only you can hear that is often in time with the heartbeat. ""Most people with pulsatile tinnitus hear the sound in one ear, though some hear it in both. The sound is the result of turbulent flow in blood vessels in the neck or head. The most common causes of pulsatile tinnitus include the following: (included) high blood pressure What is your blood pressure? Net says normal is below 120 (top number) and below 80. Elevated is 120-129 and below 80. High is 130-139 and 80-89. Things which can make tinnitus (ear condition) worse are: Alcohol, caffeine, sugar, nicotine, loud noise. Because I have tinnitus (ringing in the ears), I know those t
hings can make it worse and from seeing that on the net. Again, the website said it’s usually heard in one ear, and you said, “One morning last week I woke up hearing my heartbeat in my left ear” You said, “I have been having chest pain for a couple of weeks now on and off. Yes I went to dr. But she said it’s from my anxiety tensing up my chest walls and stress can cause it too. So my question is for those who have had a heart attack. How can I tel the difference between heart attack or just stress pain ????” I have chest pain from time to time, the last time about a month ago, and when it gets bad enough, I just go to the ER. I’ve done that 4 or 5 times and they test me and then tell me I’m OK. But what Health.harvard.edu says is: Heart attack: sensation of pain, or of pressure, tightness, squeezing, or burning; the gradual onset of pain over the course of a few minutes; pain that extends to the left arm, neck, jaw, or back; pain or pressure that appears during or after physical exertion or e
motional stress or while you are at rest. Symptoms that are less likely to be heart attack include: sharp or knifelike pain brought on by breathing or coughing; sudden stabbing pain that lasts only a few seconds; pain clearly on one side or another; pain confined to one small spot; pain that lasts for many hours or days without any other symptoms; pain reproduced by pressing on the chest or with body movement. You said, “I am in stressful situation my anxiety is through the roof.” I, also, think that is what causes a lot of my chest pain. You said, “No I’m very negative person and always think the worst. I have always been like this. _NAME_ I feel so scared and alone even though I’m married with children.” This website stresses positive thinking as part of the healing process. They call it CBT (Cerebral Behavior Therapy). I’ve found that positive thinking helps me tremendously after having come across a column on being positive before you go into a problem that you can solve it. This sets you un
conscious to looking for victory, rather than defeat, which is the way we were raised. So, it's not just a mystical way of thinking, including when you have an illness, that you're going to a speedy recovery. It sets your mind to looking for ways to solve the problem, including when you're trying to recovered from a medical situation. Were you raised in a negative household? Medicalnewstoday.com says one of the possible side-effects of Escitalopram is racing heartbeat, high or low b/p. Do you have a psychiatrist? When do you see them next? How long have you been on Escitalopram?"

175970024,"Well that's one of the main ""potential trap ahead"" types of things that he talks about, for good reason. The role of structure is to eliminate that need to force yourself to get into any particular kind of mood to begin with. Any intended mood (or needed mood, like ""the mood to sleep"") is supposed to be elicited by the structure itself. It's not about one activity leading into another. That's optional. It's about the setting. If you spend time ""getting in the mood to do things"", then you really are wasting your time. That's the whole point. The more consistent your structure is, the less you need to think about doing things, and the more you just do them. But if you lack structure, then you need to create it first. And figuring it out when you don't have it isn't an easy task, because you have no baseline to compare to. That's where physical activity enters the scene. It's a reliable anchor. So it's the opposite of ""life hacks"", it's foundations. I think it's particularly important for anyo
ne dealing with daily apathy. Because aimlessness tends to average out into more apathy. When you compartmentalize drudgery from enjoyment consistently, you get to actually enjoy the enjoyment, even if it's outweighed by the drudgery on the whole. And you get to get the drudgery done without any expectations that it could or should be enjoyable, you just do it and forget about it. You don't get that if your subconscious isn't convinced that you're in the right setting for each of those ""moods"". We're all _PERSON_ dogs, and it pays to remember it."

175970047,"Hello, Sounds like you’re ready to make some changes and you don’t know how or what direction to go. My experience is when I’m in fear, I’m no where near loving me, loving my partner, or making good decisions. 175970094,"It seems that reaching out to find both a place of expression and a community of support are great ways to progress forward into better states of being. Seeing as your perception is that everyone is against you (extremely common with your symptoms) I would consult a case worker about being discriminated by your partner and his family and ask that your primary focus to be on resolving that relationship struggle. It's extremely common for a mentally ill patient to experience what you're describing and worse from the other people in their lives. Reaching out to those who understand the various sides of you that may emerge during an episode, even hypo-manic, is possible, including if necessary going to a shelter for battered women (even if the battering is mostly psychological.) If you can manage to strike out on your own, even going back to Mississippi if you prefer, that would probably be a good idea even if you're trying to salvage your current relationship after some distance. But it could be dange
rous to keep fighting the fight you're enduring there, as it is now. All the best,"

174361784,"Gang Stalking: Real-Life Harassment or Textbook Paranoia? | Psychology Today What Is Gang Stalking? Reports of “gang stalking"" (a.k.a. ""gang-stalking"" or ""gangstalking"") began emerging at least 15 years ago by self-described “targeted individuals” (“T.I.s”) claiming to be followed, surveilled, harassed, and otherwise victimized by unknown forces wielding high-tech weapons of “mind control.” Since then, much more has been written about this phenomenon, especially over the past few years, with national attention devoted to a few notable cases of violence and mass shootings perpetrated by people identifying as T.I.s.1 These journalistic accounts—in the mainstream press, as well as in self-publication sites like Medium.com and two Vice documentary features (for a chronological bibliography, see the references section at the end of this blogpost)—offer intimate, sympathetic, and compelling portraits of those who identify as victims of gang stalking. By way of summary, T.I.s typica
lly describe living in a state of constant fear, seeing evidence of being followed by unmarked police cars in every black SUV that drives by, of being zapped by “extremely low-frequency” (ELF) radiation or “Voice to Skull” (V2K) technology in every tingling sensation or bodily ache, and of malevolent intentions in other people’s every gesture. Interviews often note that T.I.s don’t appear “unusual,” “disheveled,” or otherwise “crazy” and that some of them are doctors, acclaimed novelists, and other reasonably well-functioning professionals. Indeed, the T.I. community is comprised of thousands of diverse individuals, coming from all walks of life, with similarly diverse accounts of who might be harassing them and why. For example, the “who” is variably attributed to neighbors, ex-boyfriends, employers, police and other law enforcement agencies, “the financial elite,” or less conventional sources, like Freemasons and space aliens. The “why” is often attributed to retaliation 
for ending relationships, acting as whistleblowers at work, political activism, having run-ins with the law, or being privy to secret information. Seemingly motiveless harassment is chalked up to being hapless victims of experimentation by government agencies testing new techniques of surveillance or mind control. If there’s a common thread to the accounts of gang stalking, it’s that T.I.s describe considerable suffering not only as a result of ongoing concerns about being harassed, but also from the experience of physical symptoms, like pain and “hearing voices,” and the significant social _USER_ID_ associated with sharing their claims with family, friends, or mental health professionals who routinely dismiss them as “crazy.” As a result, T.I.s have found solace on the internet, where they share ""war stories"" and survival strategies with like-minded individuals who have similarly found themselves at the center of a vast conspiracy theory. _NAME_/Pixabay Source: _NAME_ The Subjective Reality of 
Paranoia Of course, stalking by a single individual is a dangerous reality for some—especially women fleeing abusive relationships and other targets of erotomania. And bullying by a group of individuals (a.k.a. “mobbing”) is increasingly recognized as a school and workplace hazard. In an episode called ""Trust Fall,"" the NPR Invisibilia podcast recently highlighted a seemingly improbable case of internet harassment that turned out to be real after all. A recent New York Times article detailed another real-life case of ""cyberstalking"" and in-person surveillance by employees at eBay. And yes, a few real events in history, such as the CIA’s MK-Ultra “mind control” program and the FBI’s COINTELPRO surveillance program of the 1950s, have occurred, just as the modern-day mass manipulation of human behavior through social media is a reality in which we all now live. But if you aren’t personally experiencing gang stalking, it’s hard for an outsider, much less a psychiatrist, to accept it as anyth
ing other than a textbook example of paranoia. Indeed, that’s been the conclusion of the few mental health researchers that have examined gang stalking to date. In 2006, Dr. _NAME_ Bell and colleagues published an analysis of 10 online accounts of “mind control experiences” consistent with gang stalking (though they didn’t mention that word explicitly).2 When assessed by three independent psychiatrists, all of the accounts were classified as consistent with the evidence of a psychotic disorder. In 2015, Drs. _NAME_ and _NAME_ conducted an analysis of 128 responses to a survey about stalking that similarly concluded that 100 percent of cases involving gang stalking by multiple coordinated individuals reflected paranoid delusions (in contrast, only 4 percent of those reporting stalking by a single individual were deemed to be delusional).3 In both of these studies, gang stalking claims were attributed to paranoia because they defied credulity, often due to the sheer amount of resources or level of coord
inated organization that would be necessary to carry out what was claimed. As a psychiatrist, it’s nearly impossible to disagree with those conclusions. Delusions are defined in psychiatry as “fixed, false beliefs,” with paranoia representing a classic version in which one believes they’re being followed, harassed, or otherwise persecuted. Vigilance—keeping an eye out for and being generally wary of potential threats—is normal and can transform into exaggerated hypervigilance under various conditions, such as having been an actual victim of violence. At the extreme, full-blown paranoia of delusional intensity can be understood as that same evolutionary warning system gone completely awry, to the point of seeing the evidence and believing that such threats are almost everywhere. And despite stigmatizing stereotypes about psychotic disorders like schizophrenia, those whose paranoia is part of “delusional disorder”—where “non-bizarre” or plausible delusions are the only symptoms—don’t t
ypically appear “bizarre or odd” and have functioning that’s relatively intact, according to traditional diagnostic criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM). (For an excellent portrayal of what it’s like to be married to someone with delusional disorder, listen to this episode of This American Life called “You Can’t Handle The Truth.”) This helps to explain why, aside from their idiosyncratic beliefs, many T.I.s don’t appear obviously psychotic—there is no such thing! But digging deeper tells a different story. Many T.I.s report concerns not only about gang stalking but other common symptoms of mental illness, such as auditory hallucinations or voice-hearing and even less plausible beliefs, such as having “implants” inside their bodies that can control their thoughts or that people have been replaced by aliens. But even those with “pure” paranoia appear to display textbook examples of delusional thinking. Throughout my career, I’ve worked with hun
dreds if not thousands of people with paranoid delusions, including but not limited to those who have claimed to be victims of gang stalking. In such cases, claims of persecution defy credulity on several grounds. First, there’s the unbelievably vast extent of what’s claimed… fleets of black SUVs with tinted windows, persecutors in disguise on every street corner, and futuristic secret technology being deployed from God knows where. Second, there’s a lack of any obvious or credible motive for the persecution… why would the CIA be devoting considerable resources to keep an “average _NAME_” under constant surveillance for years on end (note that paranoia and grandiosity—an exaggerated sense of self-importance—often go hand-in-hand)? Third, the persecutory experiences continue regardless of attempts to escape or relocate, including when hospitalized in the inpatient psychiatry ward, and are contradicted by acquaintances or family and friends living in close proximity. And so, by process of elim
ination as well as recognition as a textbook case, paranoid delusions often offer the best explanation for most gang stalking claims. Of course, it’s the rule rather than the exception that people with delusional disorder avoid being labeled as mentally ill and spurn referrals to psychiatry. But one more thing that can help to clarify that persecutory concerns are delusional is that paranoia often resolves when its underlying causes are actually treated, whether by participating in psychotherapy that challenges cognitive distortions in the face of evidence, taking medications for psychotic disorders like schizophrenia, or stopping the use of illicit drugs well-known to cause paranoia, like methamphetamines, cocaine, and sometimes marijuana or alcohol (many benefit from a combination of these interventions). Once treated, people sometimes develop insight that the experience wasn’t real after all and is best explained by paranoia. But just as often, a delusional belief may not be fully relinquished as an ex
planation for past events, so much as someone is simply relieved and thankful that for whatever reason, the persecution has stopped. Beliefs, whether those of T.I.s or psychiatrists, are ultimately probability judgments where the distinction between a delusion and a normal belief is the difference between what could be true and what's likely to be true and the associated level of conviction for that judgment. By definition, people with delusions hold beliefs with unwarranted levels of conviction, with the main “evidence” for the belief lying almost exclusively within the subjective experience. They often reason that “I can’t be crazy because it seems so real” (if they didn’t, they wouldn’t be delusional—in other words, if you believe you’re paranoid, you’re not!). By way of contrast, clinicians assessing delusions must be open to and investigate the potential reality of seemingly unfounded beliefs (recall that in Dr. _NAME_’s study, 96 percent of individual stalking claims were judged to 
be real), making probabilistic judgments based on objective evidence. By most accounts, gang stalking doesn’t hold up to such objective analysis for anyone other than those experiencing it. That’s the confounding reality of delusions—they’re ultimately grounded in subjective experience, whereas the truth is objective. Serving in the privileged position of authority as an arbiter of what’s credible or not—of the truth—requires that one be open-minded about what’s possible in the universe, aware of the breadth of culturally sanctioned beliefs, and humble about the limits of human knowledge. And so, rather than succumbing to the binary bias, perhaps we should consider whether gang stalking might not be quite so black and white after all. Maybe it’s not as simple as a question of paranoia or not. In Part 2 of this series, ""Gang Stalking: Conspiracy, Delusion, and Shared Belief,"" I’ll examine a third possibility, revisiting the intersection of conspiracy theories and shared delusions in the d
igital age. References Media coverage of gangstalking in the popular press and online (in chronological order): _PERSON_ New on the Internet: a community of people who believe the government is beaming voices into their minds. The Washington Post; January 14, 2007. https://www.washingtonpost.com/archi...-2a3ebc56df9d/ _PERSON_. Sharing their demons on the web. The New York Times; November 12, 2008. 175970254,"I have health anxiety as well. It is under control now, but it took a lot of work. Here are some suggestions: Say good-bye and good riddance to Dr. _PERSON_. Googling your symptoms will only show you the worst case scenarios. You can’t do this alone. Find a good CBT therapist. Every time you worry about physical symptoms becoming dangerous you are using catastrophic thinking and fortune telling. You need to work on these distortions. Commit the following to memory: Our bodies are very noisy. Healthy people produce all sorts of physical symptoms that might be uncomfortable, unexpected and unwanted all the time. They are not dangerous! Good luck and I hope you feel better soon."

175970256,"Sorry to drop off the face of the Earth. I'm doing better though I believe it'll be a while until I feel I can set commit time to the forum again. It turned out all of my health issues including the plethora I didn't mention on PF were related. Summary: I have been _NAME_ due to circulation/malaise/practically in a coma related issues. Aside from extreme energy loss, I didn't know everything going on at first, and didn't want to confuse with misinformation (not that I'm an expert). Turns out I have a rare genetic mutation that causes an enormous lack of collagen that leads everything to not work the way it should. It's rare, yet at some point in every appointment I get assured me they've dealt with someone ""just this week"" who has it. I'm sure this is totally legit and not trying to seem like they are talking out of their #$%. I'll probably make a post about it when I can commit to foruming again but even the name of the thing...ok seriously, ""Ehler-Danlos syndrome hyper-mobility type"". It took 
me about week to get around it the pronunciation and yeah, it ends in type. Why? Because there are 13 different !$%ing versions. Thankfully it can be shortened to hEDS. Funnily enough the meds I got prescribed before the hEDS dx were ones I should be taking anyway. Seems the lack of collagen covering my nerves sends way too much stimulus to my brain which gives me what I guess can still technically be considered bipolar. My bipolar meds were already originally epilepsy drugs so it worked out. My adhd meds helped because my body basically makes everything other than that type of collagen and adores not transporting any of the essentials through my blood stream. I had been lowering my adhd meds until the worsened circulation issues. This was caused between not having manic high energy anymore plus I don't have great upper body circulation due to dislocations when I lift things...I even found out that my poor posture and neck pain was because I've had dislocated shoulders for exactly since I can remember. Well, 
that's fixed, yet still very frustrating and disturbing. I think the name should be changed to reluctant contortionist syndrome. Joint braces and strength training through pilates have worked along with a supplement called VesselMax. I expect after a lot of physical therapy, I can get blood flow going and I might be able to drop the adhd meds. I've been lowering the dosage again so I'm guessing about 6 months to a year. Also, now due to lots of management my bipolar meds dosage went from 300 to now 25. Amazing what happens when your body gets what it needs. Equally amazing is how everything works better when you don't just eat right and exercise but when you do it to your body's very own special tailored !%#$ing snowflake needs. Anyway thought I'd stop by to let folks know I'm still alive and doing better. Sorry it took so long."

174361846,"Hi, I came on here today because I am feeling very nervous about my mental health. I have delusions on a day to day basis, this is common and I have done very well with learning to ignore/not feed into the voices and delusions in my mind. I am experiencing new delusions again, they are ramping up and I am now noticing myself drifting off into them more willingly, and last night I searched the house for something that the ""voices"" reminded me of. The fact that I am engaging with the delusions and acting based off of those thoughts is was has me most concerned. I suffer with Bipolar type Schizoaffective Disorder. The way I try to interpret my psychotic features of delusion/hallucination is that logically I know they aren't real/possible/etc., however my brain processes them as truth absolutely. I am beginning into the phase of self isolation. At this point in past breaks I have delved much deeper past this point. I have experienced these episodes enough times to know the initial phases that lead to 
extreme delusion. I have what I call ""false memories"". There are memories I have, even entire relationships that my memories do not make sense without the delusions being true. This is what makes it so difficult to not give in to believing these things are real, as my cognitive abilities have always remained sharp to the degree that I can explain very effectively how I see these experiences as illogical, my initial reaction to my first major episode was to go see a psychiatrist. This has been my biggest challenge in diagnosis and grounding myself in reality. My current treatments and tools I use are medications, weekly visit with therapist, and techniques I have learned over the years through experience and sessions with my psychotherapist. I currently take Lamotragine for mood stabilizer, hydroxazine for anxiety, trazadone for insomnia, and olanzapine for psychosis. For the first time ever I have found a solid treatment for my anxiety and mood, and in the past olanzapine has helped me immensely, this time 
however it is not seeming to work as effectively and I becoming more and more distracted. My biggest concern right now is the urge to isolate myself from friends and family. I don't really want to see anyone, talk to anyone. Not even my boyfriend or best friends even though I adore them. It makes me very uncomfortable as I don't have the ability to remain present. My delusions are on track to effect me 24/7. Not for so many years, that as each friend passed away, I'll never fill it with another. I haven't made a new friend in over 20 years. I have had a close relationship with God in my past. Now I feel anger. I know I need to trust Him again but it's not 
something I can make myself do. I feel so empty. Having lost 2 brothers then losing my homes to flooding in 2015 and 2016, and then finding out I have COPD, which led to me having to terminate all the clients it took 20 years to build, I am only able to talk about these things cause it's with no feelings. But the feelings are somewhere and I have to distract myself constantly cause I can't think of any one of these things for more than a few seconds before my mind automatically distracts itself or I dissociate. I'm living w my last living friend and her perverted dad. It's a terrible situation which is much harder being a victim of incest starting when I was 2 till I was 13. By my dad. My reason for living has nothing to do with hope. It has everything to do with my love for my sons. I do not want to leave them by suicide. Every part of me wants to die. I pray I don't wake up on the nights I do sleep. It's not that my sons would not suffer my loss, but suicide would be much harder on them. It's very hard to l
ive so others don't suffer. I believe in what you say about putting my faith in Jesus, I pray still that I will find a way. I just don't know how to. I'm scared to. If I do survive this, maybe I'll see I have some purpose. I want there to be a reason for this terrible pain. If not for my sons, I would not be here."

175970325,"Hello everyone, I'm looking for sone advice on friendship, I do feel emotions, but most of my emotional reactions or expressions are faked or extremely over exaggerated to seem less strange to others. Lately I’ve been unable to keep the mask up for as long as I could before, and people are starting to notice the lack of emotion or reactions when we talk, or how I can’t fake caring about things like I used to be able to. I may have set the bar too high; people seem to see me as kind of strange or eccentric, but normal enough for them not to be disturbed by me, but it’s getting harder and harder to keep up. Around my late teens, people used to describe me as cold, unfeeling, selfish, reclusive, eccentric, odd or off socially, constantly looking angry, etc, so I learned to fake the kind of reactions people were expecting to see, and I got decently good at it. Growing up, I couldn’t make friends even on a surface level because I was so shy and awkward, whereas now I make the shallow kinds of fr
iends easily, then have to break it off before it gets too real, because I don’t want an actual friendship, just to keep the peace and not seem like a complete asshole. I seem to have a high level of cognitive empathy and can read people pretty well, even if I think their emotions are irrational or inconsequential, I understand their reasoning and tell them what they want to hear, but I don’t seem to have any affective empathy at all. Even for something I would care about if it happened to me, I can’t summon the ability to care if it happens to someone else, and other people’s emotions don’t make me feel anything. I try not to hurt people mostly for logical reasons; if someone is innocent and something terrible happens to them, I would be upset because of the lack of justice, but not feel those emotions myself. If someone such as a pedophile was murdered in an overly cruel way, that doesn’t bother me at all, they got what they deserved and emotion doesn’t need to come into it at all. For the sam
e reason, laws don’t have much meaning to me; I follow them if they’re convenient, the punishment is something I don’t want to risk, or they cross one of the few moral lines I have for myself, such as pedophelia, sexual assault, child abuse or unecessary animal cruelty. For a while, I did some research into sociopathy, but I don’t think I’m antisocial enough to go out of my way to hurt someone, mostly I just would rather not interact with them at all. I do have the tendency to use people for my own benefit, more in a Machiavellian way than psychopathic, because there is a certain limit on the damage I’m willing to cause another person to get what I want, but I also don’t feel guilty about smaller things like telling people what they want to hear or playing on their emotions or the reactions and instincts ingrained in most people, if it will help me without them realizing. I only spend time with three people, who I also live with, mostly because of the proximity; my brother, who is the only perso
n I’m truly comfortable around, his girlfriend, who is basically extended family now, and my “best friend”, who I also work with. I have one other person I consider a friend, but after we became close, I started distancing myself, sometimes taking weeks to text him back, and we haven’t seen each other in months. If I don’t see a person on a regular basis, either because of work or us living together, they’re pretty much out of sight, out of mind. When I’m with someone, I’m thinking about them, and when I’m not, I don’t really wonder how they’re doing or miss them very much. I don’t keep up with hardly anyone from my hometown, even relatives, because when I moved away, those people became my past, and the people where I currently live are the present. If I happen to go back to my hometown, maybe we’ll get together, but otherwise, I don’t really feel anything for them anymore. If we’re together, I’ll be in the moment with them, if we’re not, they’re barely even an afterthough
t. I also don’t really text or use social media because I have no need to keep in contact with people when we’re not actually together, in person. In a year or so, I’ll be moving across the country with my brother and his girlfriend, and probably will not keep in touch with anyone from where I live now, except for maybe visiting every few years, because they will be in the past, and whoever I interact with in the new town will be the new present. I’m a very live in the moment type of person, especially in relationships, and usually don’t get bothered if I completely stop seeing someone I used to be close to, sometimes I don’t even notice for months or longer that we’re not talking anymore. It’s starting to feel like I’ve made too many connections in this town, and now people expect things relationship-wise that I really can’t give them. One of my roommates I refer to as my best friend, although I don’t feel close to him and don’t think I’ll miss him that much when I move. Recently, w
e didn’t see each other for four days because of different work schedules, and the next time we had a day off together, he hugged me and said how he’d missed me so much. I feel kind of bad that I honestly hadn’t noticed and had hardly thought about him at all, because he seemed so happy to be hanging out. We have fun together, but I’m pretty indifferent to it; I’d mostly rather be alone, and seeing him doesn’t make me happier than not seeing him. I’ve started avoiding him because I’m constantly hurting his feelings, but I just don’t care about his problems the way I should as a friend or as much as he cares about mine. This morning, he was talking about how lonely he was, how long it’s been since he’s had a girlfriend, and he feels like a loser as the last one in his family to still be single, and I couldn’t think of a single thing to say other than “yeah” and nodding over and over again to make it seem like I was sympathetic. Rationally, I understand what he’s upset about, but i
t doesn’t affect me on a personal level, and it’s completely foreign to anything I’ve ever thought. I’d rather him be happy than not, the same with anyone else, friends, relatives, or strangers, but also I don’t really care either way, if that makes any sense. I’m partially looking forward to moving as a way to cut ties and start over with less of a mask somewhere else; staying in the same town the rest of my life, I wouldn’t be able to keep up the facade or those relationships in a way that would seem normal to most people, and I probably would end up unintentionally hurting them much more than just moving and cutting ties would. The only person who I can genuinely say I enjoy their company as much as being alone is my brother, other than that, if it was a choice, I’d rather be alone. The few girlfriends I’ve had were people who went out of their way to pursue me, and while we did have fun together sometimes, the whole time we were in a relationship, I wished I was single, and once it ended
, I stayed single until someone else came along who was overly invested in being with me. I’m asexual and kind of repulsed by the whole idea, so that’s not a concern. I can’t seem to get invested in anyone, but at least with relatives, we can not see each other for months or years at a time and still be related and have some kind of connection; I have a big extended family and will never run out of people to be around, if I had the desire to. With friends and coworkers and everyone else, most people aren’t content to see each other only once a month or two, and not talk at all in between. I’m mostly just wondering if I should be doing something about this, because it doesn’t really bother me, but I feel like it should. Right now I’m keeping things under control, but worry that it will eventually get to the point that I can’t function in normal society at all. Thanks in advance for the advice."

175970340,"Hi spjm40, Here is what works for me; Exercise any kind. I do stretching exercises. This works for me. I Do small amounts through out the day. I go out side even if it is in the back yard. With your level of stress I would not go by other people to go outside. I go out in the sun even if it is for 15 minutes. We literally were created by the sun so this is like going home. If possible maybe get you sons involved. I put things in perspective. The media is negative in this situation to get people motivated to do something. Unfortunately people are mostly motivated out of fear and death. I don't watch news that much. It mostly talks about the sames things over and over. There are positives stories. I watch comedies and true story movies. Nothing negative. I look at past epidemics to see what really happened. For instance the 1918 Spanish flu killed 50 million world wide, yet only 1% of the deaths occurred in the US. They did social distancing, closed stores, stopped pubic transportation. Essentially a 
lock down. Not to make light of it but the US did an amazing job. I would get a short term medication like Xanax. This will chill you nicely and the family as well. If you are calm they will be calm. Your primary doctor probably would prescribe it over the phone. If you don't have insurance it is not expensive. When this is over and you still have anxiety I would go to a psychiatrist or psychologist or both to find a long term solution. I learned that most people can not handle the anxiety in other people because they have there own anxiety to deal with. So when someone loves somebody who has a lot of anxiety it overwhelms them. They shut down. So the hard truth is you are mostly on your own until your husband comes around. Yes some guys are jerks but most just can't handle it. Doctors, friends and others can fill the gap. I listen to my favorite music of my teenage years. Get your whole family involve. It is just fun to go back and it gets your juices flowing again. Realize that every crisis is a chance to r
einvent yourself. Good always comes out of tragedy. The government learns how to do a better job, people learn how to protect themselves and people learn as always love is the answer. I know you can get through this. I learned taking action is the best medicine even if it is half-assed. When this is over you will have a new better life!"

175970360,"That is tough. I think finding a new psychiatrist sounds good. Some years ago I found out that I did better with a female psychiatrist than a male. You can look those up on the search engine of your computer by typing in ""psychiatrist for your home town."" You can go through the list and write down the names and addresses of those which interest you, then go through your list and pick the one you like the best. If you have a women's health center in your town, maybe at a hospital, you could call the director and ask if she can recommend a psychiatrist. Look up local hospitals on the search engine, then go to their websites and see which ones have a women's health center. Write down the phone number then call the ones that have that. I know this is not easy to do when you're sick, which is when you need it the most. I was in that situation and put it off until I had a nervous breakdown. This website recommends CBT (cognitive behavioral therapy) in its resources, which is talked about in the area ju
st above the names of people who have written in. It's saying that one's attitude about the illness, or other problem, is very important. I believe that also, and since reading information about that, I try to be positive going into a problem that I can solve it. This puts my mind into looking for ways to solve it, rather than looking for ways to lose to the problem, which is the way I use to look at it in my negative mind state. Big difference. Same brain, just looking for ways to win rather than looking for ways to lose."

175970384,"I also have PTSD from childhood trauma, and what I usually do is I try to distract myself. I will usually watch documentaries, YouTube videos, take a walk outside, sleep, draw, play with my pets, or talk to friends. The best thing to do when you have PTSD is to be constantly distracted, because if your brain isn’t busy focusing on a particular thing, it will go off and start to unravel intrusive thoughts and repressed memories. Keeping the brain constantly busy with a hobby is a must when it comes to PTSD"

174362122,"Hey _AT_MENTION_: What is microdosing? I know people like to look at LSD as not harmful, a party drug, a hippie drug or more ""natural"" then drugs like meth. LSD: Effects and hazards This almost sounds like flashbacks.Because of the way LSD works in the brain and its affect on serotonin levels, you run the risk of Serotonin syndrome. LSD also affects the dopamine receptors{the feel good part of the brain} and Norepinephrine. Anything that screws with your receptors is dangerous. When it comes to serotonin, with LSD it causes the brain to flood you with excess amounts of serotonin which can go beyond the trip. Many people report depression and mood disturbances with chronic LSD use. And it can happen at anytime. You may thing you are ""dosing"" correctly but there is no correct dose. Even if you use the same amount or the same ""dose"" on different occasions, negative affects can happen. There is no way to prevent this."

I have found that people who do not suffer from anxiety and other mental disorders just do not get it!!!!!!! That took me years to accept as my family tells me to just get over it (which made me feel even worse). My husband is very supportive and for that I am grateful. I did start eating less junk food and limited my caffine intake and I have noticed a little dif
ference. How are you sleeping??? Insomnia is one of the worse things for people like us. Lastly, I lose motivation often, heck I don't work and have no excuse and that is one of the reasons I joined this site. I don't do social media and I'll save that story for another day...lol I'll just say it makes me feel sad.. Society rates us on our accomplishments, like being the CEO of a corporation or getting degrees in college. I DO NOT buy into any of that!! We are all individuals and are free to make our own choices about what we do in life. I firmly believe that if you ARE TRUE TO YOURSELF, you will find happiness. Shame on society and people who rate success by the size of our wallet or status in like a big company. To be honest, I think they are the saddest people because they are doing what others expect them to do, not what they really want to do. You do not need to figure it all out at one t
ime either, just take it one day at a time. Just take a deep breath, breathe and look in the mirror and say to yourself, I am beautiful and smart inside and out!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Please, just try it!! Then tomorrow, do it again, and so on and soon you will believe the truth about who you are. I know this because you joined this site and reached out for help. I'm not ashamed of telling my story to anyone who will listen and rather proud to know the truth about dealing with mental illness. You will get through this my friend. I'm praying for you _NAME_:))) God Bless, _USER_ID_"

175970530,"So for those of you that do not know I have been on zyprexa for 14 years. Currently doing 5mg. After 7 years of zyprexa I developed drug-induced insomnia and other rather serious side-effects like constant restlessness and brain discomforts, including sometimes pain. Somehow I discovered that certain herbs seemed to help me with a state of phyisical discomfort in my brain and a never ending restlessness. After a while I came to realise after some research that all of these herbs seemed to have one thing in common. They somehow stimulated or worked as a agonist on the gaba-system in the brain. So why not just take a gaba supplement? Well…apparently most(or all) atypical antipsychotics have a antagonist effect on the gaba system. I haven’t researched this extensively, but I think the reason is to reduce the possibilty of developing tardive dyskinea. There is a much greater risk of developing dyskinea when taking first generation antipsychotics, because they don’t have any antagonist action on t
he gaba system. Normal levels of GABA while taking a antipsychotic seems to promote tardive dyskinea. So I took a 750mg dose of pure GABA supplement. And sure enough, on day two or three I think it was I developed uncontrollable movement in my left hand. So naturally I had to stop. I have later re introduced GABA, but now taking only 250mg a day. I have done that for about a week and so far I have not had any trouble with involuntary movements. When it comes to the herbs that modulate the GABA system their effect on me is that they seem to calm down my overactive mind. It is easier to stay calm and focused in the daytime, it takes away discomfort in my brain and I am able to relax in the daytime. For example before I started taking these herbs it was impossible to lie down on a sofa and relax. My mind simply could not rest. Now however this is possible. I can take naps and my quality of life is better. My general health seems to be improved and more normal, combating side-effects from medication. So herbs tha
t can be helpful are: licorice root, _NAME_ bark, chamomille, valerian root and lemon balm to mention a few. Here is a study discussing herbs that works on the gaba-systems anti-insomnia properties which is related to what I’m talking about regarding relaxation. A lot of the herbs they discuss are not common remedies. I never heard of most of them, but there are also a few common ones like licorice root and valerian root in the study. I guess what I’m talking about can be useful to look into if any of you guys struggle with the same things I do. PubMed Central (PMC) Herbal Insomnia Medications that Target _USER_ID_ Systems: A Review of the... Insomnia is a common sleep disorder which is prevalent in women and the elderly. Current insomnia drugs mainly target the ?-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptor, melatonin receptor, histamine receptor, orexin, and serotonin receptor. GABA[A] ..."
