175972125,"Sunflower - Hello... chronic anxiety sucks. I've lived with it for a long time. Aside from going down the medication avenue, there are a couple things I picked up from the frustration of your post. #1. Whether you realize it or not, you are taking the most important step already. You are expressing yourself in a healthy forum here. A. You have recognized there is an anxiety/depression issue to address B. You acknowledge you're not efforting enough keep your body as healthy as you should. C. You already possess some innate understanding that deep breathing could possibly help. #2. You correct on all counts! Kudos, take a bow, force a smile please. A. Figure what is really at the root of this depression that symptomatically expresses itself as anything from an elevated heart rate to loss of appetite to perhaps some fears of loneliness and/or panic attacks. B. Time to going since the going got tough. Do you absolutely NEED to see a therapeutic specialist of some sort and get on medications right away?
?? Personally, I don't think that's the best first answer until you can really look yourself honestly in the mirror after 3 months and say that you you really are trying your best. Can you say that right now? Without any intended offense, it doesn't sound like it at present.... and that's okay too! Ya gotta start somewhere, right? Right!!! Ok then! C. You gotta start forcing yourself to get out more, eat, eat more, and eat healthy. Begin a light exercise regimen in the morning that starts with quietly sitting at peace with yourself and focus on that deep breathing before you do virtually anything! Ok you can brush your teeth, please smile. Now ask yourself, what on God's green Earth would make you think that deep breathing would be an immediate anodyne to your anxiety? Because you're instinctively intelligent, that's why! But In the midst of an anxiety attack, this isn't going to resolve everything all at once. However, what I am getting at here is, is that you're not wrong, nor all that abnormal necessarily, 
or even requiring that much more beyond what you can do for yourself _PERSON_. One should always start with making an effort to love themself more.... Focus on the deep breathing, not a panic induced last resort, but make it part of your routine and do it casually every day, in the morning, at before lunch, and before dinner. Maybe 20 minutes each, that's all. It doesn't have to be some big production. Light exercise I enjoy takes me exploring on walks. Sometimes, I find myself daydreaming in front of a bookstore display, or some architecture, or listening to music or an audio book. You must make the effort to reclaim your lovable you! I love movies so I watch a lot of them. Books and movies are a great way to get out of one's own head and allow your imagination to roam free. I like to write, but I probably don't write as much as I should, so hell, I'm writing to you! This is what doing for you looks like and the rest will come easier regardless of whether you seek out some prescription or therapy. The real a
nswers to your issues are already within you. Sometimes people do need a little extra nudge (myself included), but I still remain a firm believer that the heart of it all rests with not losing faith in yourself. And if you mess up, or forget stuff, or allow yourself to let panic get the best of you... slowly drink a couple glasses of water. Visualize water and yourself breathing calmly, slowly underneath it as if it were air. You got this Sunshine... shine on! ~ cres"

175972135,"The first thing I would ask is: who diagnosed you with Psychosis NOS? A therapist? The same therapist as you had been seeing who refused to keep seeing you? Oftentimes therapists will do things like that. In my experience, I've had several therapists just say, ""Enough is enough,"" and that they can't deal with me anymore. It is a road block but it is not something that worries me that much anymore. Let me explain: I mean, I don't go out seeking for therapists that will end up quitting on me. Rather, I think that some therapists get me and some do not. Of course, it's more nuanced than that. But what I mean is, there are some people out there that are going to act like they cannot deal with your delusions (you do say they are delusions, right?) and some who actually can help you deal with those feelings. It's your task to find the person (or people) who will help you deal with those. Also, it would help to know if that therapist you were seeing is the one who diagnosed you with Psychosis NOS, becau
se that would be helpful to know, as if she did diagnose you with that, and then proceeded to not help you with it, then you should not be that worried about the whole situation. You should just seek out someone who does understand what you're going through. I know it's easier said than done, but that is how I would proceed in your shoes."

Like car dealerships have openings for Internet sales for people who send inquiries about cars and financing? Or in construction supply stores, they have front desk sales and back office/warehouse sales where you would pull the orders for the customers instead of dealing with them directly. Maybe that is something you would be interested in. As far as the anxiety, I hope you are seeking some kind of treatment or therapy for it because as you know, if you don't, you could land the perfect job for you, but if your anxiety is untreated, it won't matter and you'll be back in the same place, if not worse. Doing little things like looking for jobs as I mentioned, taking some time to exercise, even if it's for a walk around the block, setting a schedule for yourself can help you feel a measure of control. And for things that you cannot control such 
as customers, COVID, career advancement, please remember this saying from _NAME_ 6:34 So never be anxious about the next day, for the next day will have its own anxieties. Each day has enough of its own troubles. Or as my mom likes to say, don't go borrowing trouble. Take each day at a time and try not to waste your energy on things that may never happen tomorrow or in the future. That robs you of peace in the present. I hope you are able to find something and to treat your anxiety and that everything will be alright soon. Best wishes."

175972333,"Hi Everyone, I would like to help if I can. I have degenerative disc disease and have had spinal fusion with discs taken out and metal hardware put in. I have taken Gabapentin in the past so here is my take on this med. It works well for nerve pain which is what I am left with after surgery. I still have more levels which need to be fused and will get this done after my cancer surgery I hope. Gabapentin is used off label for anxiety/depression. Now for how it worked for me. When I first start taking this med it definitely takes the edge off my anxiety. I was on a baby dose of 3 capsules per day. Each has 100mg. My dr then increased this to 2 capsules 3 times per day. No side effects which are horrible. You will feel a bit tired and your cognitive abilities are slowed quite a bit. It does a good job of ending my anxiety periods. The bad news is the longer I take it the less effective it is for anxiety. If you come off it for a month then start over it works great, at least it did for me. I am happy 
to answer any questions. I hope this helps anyone thinking of taking this med. I am of course not a dr and this is just my personal experience. God bless us all."

175972357,"""Mental illness is a main cause of lack of self-awareness, however it is nearly impossible for a functioning human being to survive without some type of awareness over its environment and behavior. Some reasons for lack of self-awareness may be: -Impulsiveness: Not recognizing the consequences of one’s actions and continuing to behave in the same manner over and over again. -Lack of Morals: Ethics are not prioritized therefore one chooses not to do anything about it even if it is detrimental. -Lack of Consciousness: No desire/will/drive to expand one’s thinking or perception of world around them. -Lack of connection with Emotions: One cannot sympathize with oneself or others around them. -Isolation: Little to no communication with other human beings leads to little understanding of how to fit in with social constructs/beliefs/trends. -Underdeveloped Understanding of Behavior: If one has not taken the time to get to know oneself, they will not know why they do the things they do."""

Additional effects may include dystonia (muscle spasms or contractions), akathisia (restless legs syndrome), and dyskinesia (involuntary movements)."" 175972378,"Hi All, Post Traumatic Stress Disorder is a very serious issue for all age individuals. In the process of survival, humans tend to let go of the mental bruises they have experienced because of several unwanted incidents in their lives. This let go works for a few , however many keep this mental or physical stain within themselves and fall trap to the bigger issues of depression and anxiety in the longer run. PTSD is not something that happens overnight or because of an immediate or recent experience. We all tend to burden all the abuse and _USER_ID_ within ourselves and tend to unknowingly move ourselves into the realm of depression. PTSD till date is still a grey area where the diagnosis and treatment is still not clear. The Internet will reflect upon many treatments however there isn't much knowledge amongst the masses as to which would be an effective one on the specific individual. Also Quarterly and yearly treatment courses are not easily affordable by all. The needy ones who actually are the 
main victims of PTSD, **Can they actually afford them? Do they actually know whether they have PTSD or not?** Anyone can help on the treatment types on PTSD which is in real effective as well as affordable?"

175972431,"For me the anxiety seemed to stem from the uncertainty of my future, and lack of confidence this brings. Again, health issues were at the root of my distress/anxiety as it puts so many question marks into your life....how much can I work, what activities will I have to forego that I love doing, etc. I found that once I got relief from the medication (in my case adderall for the fatigue, zoloft for the vestibular issues) things seemed to build. I gained some reassurance that things would not be as bad as I thought they would be, a baseline that I could count on in regard to functioning (socially this was huge, I could still do things I loved, just not to the same extent). Mentally the doubt about my life and what I could do/not do started to fade. Sure, I get jolted from life when things happen (like taking antibiotics and being affected negatively) but I have to remember I made it through other darker situations and came out ok. Therefore I can do it again. Hope this perspective helps!"

175972476,"Psychiatric medications work quite well for many. But they aren't cure-alls. 175972479,"i have been hearing voices almost everyday sense 1971. I wish there was a great answer to your question but i will tell you some of the things that over time i have used. when they first started i talked back to them but early on they weren't that threatening. Mostly making me do dumb things like riding my bike down to a local villiage to cut down a small scotch pine tree to bring home to have a christmas tree in my room. I did this in the middle of the night if i would have been old enough to think the whole thing thru i wouldn't have drug the tree thru the house and up the stairs without wrapping it in a sheet, my mother yelled up the stairs the next morning you better get that tree out of this house. Ha i decorated it and it was epic. Ok back to how to handle them, the got more serious around say 1982 when they would use harsh meds at high strengths. During that time i used weird but useful coping strategies , i would go into myself and try to understand them, try to become one with them. I gues
s befriend them. Due to that strategy i became catatonic at times and it ended me up in the state hospital for 6 months. Today i just let them wash over me not take over me like back then. But you have to understand back in the 80s treatment of the mentally ill was far harsher than today. Straight jackets , 5 point restraints and heavy chemical restraints were used regularly and sometimes for no apparent reason. So the catatonia was used by me to survive. For 47 years I have lived with this and it is my normal, I find it sweet that my current medical team really thinks we can change this from my normal to a new normal. After awhile with voices or other hallucinations it gets to be what you know and you don't fight it so hard, the days were its silent or clear i get nervous that something is wrong so i guess they have become part of what is me. I'm sorry i didn't give you much to hold onto but roll with the voices remember they are just voices they can't hurt you make sure they know you make the choices and wo
n't be controlled by them. Tell them you are the BOSS! warmest regards, tams you can ask me anything, if i can help you i'd be honored."

175972487,"Anyone experience relationship anxiety? I'm in my late 30s and this is something I have dealt with for as long as I can remember. I had SEVERE separation issues from my mom as a kid. I read a lot about attachment and I believe I have anxious-avoidant which is a combo of both anxious and avoidant. Almost like ""come here, get away from me"".. is the best way to describe it. I am a very intuitive person and always trust my gut. With the new guy I am seeing I don't believe it is my gut. I believe it is anxiety. I tend to nitpick once I start to like someone and the stuff I nitpick about is so not even important. I think once I get close to someone, I subconsciously turn off as a defense or way to not get hurt or abandoned. I have a fear of loss. I am so aware of my issues and right now I see no red flags in the person I am dating. We have been seeing each other a month and it is early but... he has been the sweetest, most validating man and we just click. Things have felt right ( when I'm not nitpicki
ng and anxious). Yesterday I had a therapy session with my therapist who is a marriage and family therapist. She wanted to challenge my anxiety and asked me... do you feel great in your heart or in your head ? I immediately had a wave of anxiety and started doubting whether I even like this person or care. Meanwhile, before this question, I was happy and talking about how the relationship with this guy feels so different and real unlike other relationships, and how part of me has felt like this may be someone I see as ""the one"" . I like this guy and see so much potential, and vice versa because he has told me. I don't want to sabotage anything. But today my anxiety is so debilitating that I feel like I need to run. 175972551,"My husband, _NAME_ is prescribed Xanax 0.5mg/twice daily (Qty: 60 tabs per month) and has been for over 6 years now. He has monthly psychiatry appointments in order to get refill of the Xanax as well as Adderall 30mg/twice daily (Qty: 60 instant release tabs per month). At first he really wasn’t thrilled at the thought of being on “these” medications considering their high potential for addiction/abuse. His doctor convinced him that in combination, the two meds would “balance each other out” and leave him in a laidback yet extremely focused state which per his doctor, was where he needed to be ...how he needed to behave, I guess. He was extremely responsible and immediately responsive positively within 1.5-2 weeks of beginning medications daily. He felt calmer, driven, purposeful and more than anything...he actually felt normal for once. It was great. Now, 6 years later (72 months - approx. 2,160 days - and 144 combined prescript ions of Xanax and Adderall)...it’s now definitely causing 
more bad than good. Yes, it helps his anxiety and ADHD issues. Yes, he feels great and that makes me happy for him but...4 days of the 30 day month he is living on top of his world in a xanaxed trance and the other 26 days he is actively and consistently searching for them from other ppl, which ends up being extremely costly. I guess, I want to know if anyone has any POSITIVE suggestions and/or similar experiences to this? He takes his Adderall as prescribed. It’s never been an issue for him with that med. only the Xanax. Rather than him stop taking them cold turkey, which could cause a scary variety of side effects including seizures, are there any anxiety meds his doctor and him could consider as a safer, yet similar, alternative? Any help is greatly appreciated. Thank you."

175972602,"I appreciate everything that everybody has said and the encouraging words given. Even though I haven't heard exactly what I wanted, what I needed was the truth, not a sugar coated version of reality that paints the perfect picture. To be honest I didn't expect so many words of encouragement from these responses, I was fully prepared to be chastised by some saying I should be more supportive of my fiance and the struggle he has with his anxiety and that I was selfish to be so concerned with my own wants. When I read the very first response I received from _PERSON_ about narcissistic abuse my immediate reaction was to believe it was me being referred to as narcissistic and that I was hurting my fiance for trying to prioritize myself and I immediately felt defensive. I'm glad I waited to respond and asked for clarity because the fact that it wasn't showed me how quick I am to make myself out to be the bad guy in my own head and villainize myself, which is something I clearly need to work on. Based on 
some of the responses, though, I think there are some things I need to clarify. This pressure that I feel to always put my fiance's feelings before my own is something that I have done to myself and I fully admit that. These feelings weren't caused by him abusing or guilting me, they are feelings that I've never expressed to him that I've put on myself to try and be the best partner I can be to him. I have the personality of a protector who takes on the role of putting those around me first and considering myself last. This may sound strange, but I am almost incapable of being selfish. I think that the two of us can absolutely have a successful and happy relationship, but I also think it's time to admit to him how I've been feeling and start working on myself to become comfortable with the idea of being selfish every once and a while, because that's healthy. The other thing, though, that I've taken away from this and need to address with him is that I can't allow myself to feel like it's my responsibility to 
""fix"" him or take on the role of a therapist. I need to seek out my own help to try and adjust the self sacrificing mindset I've always had, but he also needs to address his issues so that I can have peace of mind that if I say the wrong thing by accident it won't send him into a spiral and be able to let down my guard. I think if we both can get the help we need on our own then our relationship will only get stronger."

175972676,"As far as sleep, I take Melatonin from the health food store, or from the health section at the grocery or drug store, or over the net. It didn't work without me first taking med for my bipolar (Mirtazapine anti-depressant, and then Lithium stabilizer, which keeps the anti-depressant from throwing me into mania or anxiety attacks). As for how much Melatonin, I take 4, 1 mg. pills. I take them an hour or two before bedtime, then take a 5th an hour or two later just before I go to bed, to give me a booster. If I wake up some hours later and can't go back to sleep, I can take another 1 mg. pill. That's just a general, ballpark number. I would start with a lower number. As for the difficulty, I try to get into a positive frame of mind that I can solve the problem before I start to try to solve the problem. This puts my unconscious into looking for solutions, whereas before my unconscious was set on negative, and it was looking for ways to lose like I had programed it because of childhood training and/o
r bipolar. I now tell myself, ""Think positive,"" before beginning to think about the problem."

Now that I’m at home and unemployed I have more time to think about those 4 years I lived under the same roof with the monster whom still haunts my dreams. He took everything from me, my virginity, my childhood, my self love. And when he would get angry drunk I would get physically abused if I didn’t do what he asked of me. For the longest time I wondered if my mother was in on it meaning being ok with his treatment towards me because she never really tried to stop him other than say “enough” when he would beat me up. I wondered how was it that she didn’t know that he was molesting me under one roof. I am the 3rd child out of 4 siblings. Th
e only girl. We lived poor, always in a 2 bedroom apartment. At the age of 17, he was finally arrested and deported. For years I lived in fear of the thought of him possibly come back into the states. It wasn’t until he died that’s when I was finally able to somewhat Rest In Peace. The memories come back constantly the pain will never go away. Maybe it is time to be medicated? I have lived with this pain med free . I start therapy next week. Sometimes I think what kind of human am I, am I even normal?"

175972746,"Hi JRF, I am so sorry to hear about your dad's health scare, and the natural effect it has had on you. You had to be really strong the whole time your dad was in the hospital, and there was a lot of uncertainty that you were dealing with, not knowing if he would recover. Therefore the way you are feeling is absolutely normal. As people with anxiety, we sometimes forget that feeling anxious is an appropriate response to situations like the one you are facing! We tend to want to make it go away, when in fact, it is just part of our human condition that does actually serve a purpose. Of course when anxiety takes over our ability to function and robs us of our quality of life, then of course we need to work to find solutions... ...but in a situational/temporary circumstance such as with a sick loved one, some time may be all you need. Hopefully now that the crisis is starting to calm down, so will your anxiety. You will probably find in the coming week or two, that you will feel comfortable with daily 
check in with your dad/brother to know that he is recovering well...and give you peace of mind. Wishing your whole family well. Keep us updated and we will keep you in support. S.C."

175972752,"_PERSON_, I want to be gentle here. When you and your fiance' have disagreements are you experiencing fear he will give up on you? It took me a long time to realize that upsets between my husband and I were never as bad as I imagined. A strong fear of rejection was what I would find in myself. Even though in reality it never played a part. I had to learn that just because there was a fight it did not mean it would be the end of us. One day I heard a line in a song...""You're supposed to know I love you."" Maybe you will not feel such desperation if you remember that your fiance' loves you. That you're supposed to know he loves you. When you say you messed up so badly. Is this something your fiance' has spoken to you? Sometimes one should take a break from feeling responsible for their fears and insecurities. Yet if you are speaking truth to your fiance' then do not back down. Stand your ground. If he loves you he will struggle with himself to understand you and to help you understand him. Then toge
ther you two can find common ground to share rather then a tearing apart of the relationship. It can take real work...but so worth every minute getting there. Try to understand your feelings, try to find what it is that you are wanting and trying to say. What is feeding those feelings? Perhaps you are not messing up but instead crying out to have your feelings understood. It is not always an easy thing to do. To understand and to be understood while in a relationship. Don't give up. Learn about one another and look not at WHO IS RIGHT but rather WHAT IS RIGHT. At times we do not even know what it is we are doing. These times can be filled with many challenges that we set for ourselves. It makes it all the harder when we also are taking in criticism from family members. _PERSON_, in time you will become a wealth of information and have real compassion for others stumbling through what you may be stumbling through right now. Try to calm yourself, learn to trust your feelings. After all, your feelings are trying 
to communicate with you! Some of your feelings will be well-grounded and come with sound thinking. Some of your feelings will need to be discarded...such as self hatred, or feelings of wanting or needing to harm yourself, feelings of being frowned upon by others. You have a right to live this life. Find the strength within yourself and learn not to need validation from others. You are you!!! _PERSON_, you validate you!!!! I am sure there is a lot of good to say about you. Stand up for yourself and protect yourself. No need to sacrifice yourself for the approval of others. _PERSON_"

To me, masks are often a mockery of authenticity. People don't even make their own anymore! They go to the store on Halloween and buy the same cheap, factory-made, trendy and meaningless one everyone else bought. Rules to being a ""good"" person, rules to being a ""bad"" person, rules to being ""normal"" and rules to being ""weird"" or ""crazy;"" rules t
o being ""independent,"" rules to being a ""follower,"" rules to being ""authentic"" Rules everywhere. They're just backwards now. Your character in your video clip said something to the effect of even ""criminals ... used to believe..."" = code of conduct. I find this to be true to across all ""primate"" walks of life. I struggle sitting through movies do I haven't seen it, but for example, the joker you keep going back to seems to offer lessons (the way the archetype would suggest it should) and a while back you said something to the effect that in order to devalue something, you'd had to have had to have held it in high esteem at once point. cter you keep referring to. ^ Regression of rules even in movie theme over time. Then I look at closer to home: ^ Where I used to live, code of conduct was black humor, call people out of their $#%^, not worry so much about social acceptability and even to an extent, morals (unless it really hurt someone). ^ Fast forward to where I live now, code of conduct look and act socially acceptable and fit in. You can do all sorts of ###$ up things behind closed doors and no one will have a problem with you as long as you act right in front of them. ^ Where I used to live, you'd call out the person who does ###$ up things behind everyone's back but apparently that's ""wrong"" where I am now and you'll get punished. How do you mean it's not the mask but the people behind it? Like if the swastika was a mask: At one point, it was spiritual, life-affirming and then it was warped into violence, constriction, and mass murder. No matter what, the ""mask"" is ruined now. The energy it evokes is heavy, the people it primarily 
draws are not spiritual or life affirming. As a ""mask"" it is no good regardless of the original ideals behind it and what was supposed to mean. I'm believing that terms like morals, empathy, and the like, are also becoming empty (albeit not violently like my example) However, I do acknowledge society needs rules to survive. This goes back to a few falling through the net of what works for many. I'll have to look up the term ""dead faith"" I expect persons to have a couple brain cells and some personality - otherwise I prefer the mask. So the masks may be compatible but what's underneath repels the other, and these uncomfortable ""contracts"" are instances where the mask is more desirable than the self behind it. 175972780,"I hear you. I have been on a few medications in my life but I am trying to manage my depression without them. I'm not saying I don't ever get depressed or anxious, but it's not as crippling as when I was younger. It takes a lot of work for me to feel even the slightest bit normal and out of that dark place. If I'm feeling depressed for an extended time I find that a combination of meditation, exercise, working on art, being outside, and spending time with my daughter helps. Take it one day at a time, and if that's too much than take it moment by moment. I also find it helpful when my relationship with my husband is struggling, to think or journal about what I'm grateful for about him. Turning your negative thoughts into daily affirmations might trick your brain into thinking positive. Hang in there, you are far from alone."

175972806,"What I would keep in mind is that no one can read yours! In other words, whatever negative, self-defeating thoughts you're having in the moment; those are not visible to others. Most people are so stuck in their own heads, so self-absorbed and not in tune with the people around them, that if you do show any outward signs of anxiousness, they're not going to pick up on it. You can be yourself! And if you find yourself feeling pressured into small talk, keep it light and get the other person talking about themselves. Hope this helps!"

175972929,"I don’t really open up. I make them open up to me first. Most people like to talk about themselves and like to be taken care of, so I focus on listening to their story while giving them some good experiences. “What kind of food do you like? Have you tried this restaurant?”, “How was your day at work? Ah sorry it was stressful, hey let’s go to the Karaoke that’ll probably cheer you up a bit”, “Oh you want to go shopping? Let me help picking up clothes for you”, “You feel overwhelmed? I know this swimming pool that barely has people in it and it has a good view, we can talk there while relaxing at the same time”. I do things like that (won’t do things that I personally don’t like though, so I suggest things that I know I would enjoy as well). Some people say they hate small talks but I think small talks is like a door for the real conversation. We don’t come up to people we just meet and ask them about their childhood traumas or political views for example. It’s just not 
realistic. Once I become friends with people for a while though, when I open up it’s just natural."

174365437,"Hello everyone, I'm schizophrenic. I may soon be entering a career program at a local college. What's more, it would be (mostly) free. This is terrifying because: 1) I don't know if I'll be able to handle the mental strain of school again. 2) If I fail, I won't get another chance like this. It's also exhilarating because: 1) If I'm able to complete the program, I'll be able to support myself for the first time in my life. 2) It would be a career I would genuinely enjoy. I'm in a relatively stable place in life. I'm still poor, but my physical needs are met and the storm in my brain seems to have weakened. But I've never accomplished anything I'm proud of, and have come to doubt my ability to do so. I feel like the kid at the top of the slide holding up the other kids because she's afraid to go down."

175972961,"I’m 35. I have three wonderful children. They’re all healthy, well-adjusted, doing very well in preschool or middle school. My eldest is 13, he’s in the gifted programs at school. My two youngest( boy, then the baby is my girl) are “Irish twins “. That’s what the nurse at the hospital called them. Because they’re less than 12 months apart. They were born 11 months almost apart. So, every year there is a 3 1/2 week period, where they are the same age. But my youngest turned 5, and 4, this past year. I’m adopted. So is my older brother. I was adopted when I was five weeks old. I grew up in a very healthy, stable, loving family. My parents are my parents I love them dearly. Almost codependent. I went to private schools, went to college. Have seen a therapist for my situational depression, since I was 13. Same therapist. He’s on my speed dial. I’ve taken Adderall since I was 12. it helps me. I have ADD/ADHD. situational depression and a spatial disorder.( I don’t like people in my 
face, if they were not invited to be in my face. I.e. I have to be sedated to go to the dentist, etc.) My children are the exception. I want snuggles and hugs and kisses from them 24/7. They are the lights of my life. However I’ve noticed recently, I’m becoming more and more prone to panic attacks and then anxiety attacks, just going to the grocery store or going to get gas. going to Walgreens. Going to pick the babies up from daycare. I like being by myself, as an adult. When I was a teenager and early 20s-I was a social butterfly. Very comfortable being out and about. I was raised socially, from a wealthy family in the south. I was a debutante. as I’ve gotten older I truly enjoy my own company and the company of my family. But it’s getting harder and harder to get in the car or even go outside. Now more so recently, on the days when I don’t have my children, because they’re with their dad, I can’t even leave my house. I can go to my front porch. And that’s it. I haven’t been in my backyard

The Fool - Fruitsbasket YouTube _PERSON_ has a point Once upon a time, there was a foolish traveler who had gone on a journey. Why was he foolish? Well, because he was fooled by everyone he met! ""Please, some money for medicine...?"" Everywhere he went, people made up all kinds of sad stories to tell him, and the traveler fell for every one of them. ""I have a sick younger sister..."" ""I don't have money to buy seeds to plant in my fields."" Pretty soon, his money, his clothes, even his shoes had been cheated away from him. But the foolish traveler was always glad to help. And he always told the people the same thing. He said: ""I wish you happiness."" But by this point, though, the traveler was completely naked, and with nothing left to cover himself, he decided to leave the main r
oad and travel through the dense forest, where no one could see him... But soon, he was discovered by the goblins that lived in the woods. The goblins wanted to eat the traveler's body, so they begged and pleaded, and used kind words to try and trick him... Of course, the traveler was fooled. First, he let the goblins eat one of his legs. Then an arm. Then more and more... Before it was over, all that the traveler had left was his head. He'd even given his eyes away to the last of the goblins... And as that last goblin was eating the traveler's eyes, he turned and said ""Thank you, traveler. In return, I leave you this present."" What the goblin left was a slip of paper, with the word ""fool"" written on it. The traveler couldn't see it. He didn't know what it was. Even so, tears began to flow down his face. ""Thank you,"" he said. ""This is the first present anyone ever gave me. I'm so happy. I'm so happy. Thank you."" Even without his eyes, he cried and cried, great tears of joy. Then, the traveler died, th
e smile still on his face. see? loss, hardship, things like that? you can’t only focus on them. the traveler didn’t…he never thought about his own troubles at all. i imagine that it probably does sound really foolish to some people. but i don’t think he’s foolish at all. even though other people probably think he was being tricked? i don’t think he was. i think he did exactly what he wanted to do. i think, more than anything, he just wanted to make others happy."

175973099,"Hello, First I should point out that I am a schizoid that has been married to a woman with bpd for the past 13 years. And while I’m not sure as to the frequency of these relationships I can provide some context based on my experience. The primary thing to understand is that, ( while I doubt it’s psychologically healthy. ), these two conditions compliment each other in the following ways. 1: They are both schismatic personality disorders that shift between desire and withdrawal. Although in completely different ways. 2: The schizoids external self is extremely adaptive when dealing with individuals. So long as there is no demand for genuine emotional connection. In covert schizoids this external adaptation can become so complex that they can, to some extent, get lost in the illusion. Because people with BPD are hyper emotional, the schizoid takes on simulated emotional traits that for a time provide an illusion of the emotional connection they so desperately desire. In short wether it’s a good 
or bad experience it make us feel temporarily human. If the illusion becomes to intense or runs the risk of generating a real emotional response, the schizoid shuts down. 3: Schizoids have a rather unique ability to intellectually understand the psychological pathology of others to an immense degree, yet are incapable of empathy. As a result of this the partner with BPD finds in the schizoid a partner that understands them in a way that very few others do. 4: The primary issue for people with BPD in regards to a relationship is finding a partner that is psychologically capable of dealing with their ever shifting hyper emotional episodes. This makes the schizoid unique in regards to other partners, as their own internal defense mechanism will disassociate from the emotional onslaught upon the partner leaving or if things get to intense. As a result when the partner with BPDs episode ends, they find that their partner appears all but unaffected, even though at times they are. 5: Another thing to understand is t
hat schizoids rarely directly end relationships. 9 times out of 10 if a schizoid ends a relationship is isn’t because they have been contemplating ending it, but rather because their partner made the suggestion, often as a means of contextualizing the severity of the current issue. And the schizoid, not understanding that this is more of a scare tactic than an actual desire to end the relationship, simply agrees and moves on. In the case of the schizoid/BPD relationship, the partner with BPD is extremely codependent. Often going to extreme lengths to maintain a relationship. As a result of this they tend to overlook the schizoids emotional neglect, no matter how isolated it makes them feel. And so long as the schizoid isn’t pressured to leave, they will stay regardless of any internal emotional damage they may suffer as a result of their partners outbursts. In the end, While not psychologically healthy for either partner, the Schizoid/BPD relationship does provide a form of pseudo relationship in which ne
eds are provided for, that often cannot be provided by other partners. The Schizoid gains a partner, That while like all partners, they are incapable of truly connecting with does ; allow them to feel temporarily human, puts little pressure on them to leave, and is willing to overlook their forced state of emotional neglect. While the BPD partner gains a partner that; Has a very high degree of understanding regarding who they are, is able ride out the emotional storm of their episodes, and will never leave unless pressured to do."

I feel this a lot with general symbolism as well and the combination of scenes or objects that elicit an experience within my mind. I'm doing pretty good now. I used to think about what happened all the time and now I can go most days without thinking about it."

175973231,"Averugen, Accepting help from others who want the best for you can feel weighty. Feeling like you are in the spotlight and feeling like others are watching and evaluating your every move can cause one to want to rebel and give in to certain failure. I would think feeling like that would cause you to resent others and bring about anger in you which you use to lash out at them. Consider this, people help people because they care. That is always a good and kind thing. Gratitude for someone's help is also a good thing. Perhaps there is always something wrong with the help because you may be resenting that help. You probably are frustrated with yourself because you might be feeling like, ""Why don't I just take care of this myself?"" Feeling dead inside is understandable when you are feeling you've let yourself down before you even really get started. Accepting help from others is not a failure. It merely helps you in getting going. Focus on a plan and use shear bullheadedness to get you to the furthest 
reaches of that plan. It does not need to be a huge plan, a successful small plan which you come up with and you shaped will bring to you a small joy about yourself. There must be something in life that sparks an interest in you. Art, children, the outdoors, animals... The list is endless though it may feel like a short list. There are so many unknown choices out there; things you would never, ever, even imagine. Most of these unknown choices people discover along the way. Finding the right niche in this world can be tricky but never impossible! There are 100's of thousands of choices out there and one is the right one for you. Don't panic if it is not right there out in front of you. You will find your way. Start out small and keep the victories at a low level. It is something like climbing a mountain. Your eyes can scan quickly to the top of a majestic mountain, but getting there will take one small step at a time. And if you keeping taking those small, small steps, one behind the other you will reach the t
op of that mountain. Trust in yourself. Remember each small step is a small victory and each victory will get you closer to the summit. Use your own ideas, you can do this; believe in yourself. And never forget that people lose their footing at times and slip or fall while climbing up their chosen mountain. Just keep at it and remember as long as you are trying to move forward and up than you are being successful. _PERSON_"

175973292,"Hi there, a very interesting subject indeed. The thought patterns in Neuroplasticity subject are the default patterns of thoughts. The thoughts on those lines (I would call them lines) are, as far as I am informed, totally re-trainable. It's all about training them for thinking a different thought when triggers come. For example when you see a cup of _NAME_ smoothie makes you think of poison and throws you into anxiety, you get the habit or reminding yourself that the cup is full of delicious and healthy vegetables and nothing is poisonous there. When you do that every time you see a cup of green juice for a number of times, in the end you start thinking of vegetables when you see the cup first. Instead of poison. Same goes for anxiety thoughts (all sorts) just training your brain to connect to the positive thought immediately first. I know its complicated but this technique is used in many CBT related treatments. Just needs lots of practicing :P"

175973296,"I have been addicted since I was 14. All the years of my life revolved around drugs and how to get more. I was able to get into a court diversion program and the program after my 5th possecion of cds charge and it has changed my life. At the beginning I had no idea how to do normal daily living in recovery. But the treatment and support I had guided me even when I would relapse. They understood that someone like me that was a heavy multiple drug abuser would have a harder time than someone who accidentally got hooked on lortab or oxy after having a baby. I am 40 years old and drugs had been the center of my existence all my life. I was raised in a drug culture. My mother was a heroin addict and my father died from drinking and driving. I even chose drugs over my own children. But over the past 2 years I was able to get into an apartment and I had a serious injury repaired, I dont have any clean days right now but due to my treatment provider and the diversion court understanding and having the know
ledge to help me through these setbacks I have the desire to keep going and learning and the courage to beat this thing. And if sharing my story and experiences helps somebody through their dark days I am willing to help in any way i can."

This doesn't fit the Avpd criteria as I understand people with Avpd actually yearn for friendship but avoid people through fear of rejection. I used to desire friendship but I was repeatedly rejected throughout my school years and the few friends I did have used me and were generally not real friends - belittled me, just wanted me to do chores for them and constantly making fun of me (and saying they're only joking! such a classic cop out). 175973319,you are not sleeping despite the meds because your dr was right about your mild depression. I went tru exactly same senerio and even ambien wasn't putting me out for the entire nite. once your depression lifts-normal sleep will return. trazadone is hit or miss for many. didn't work at all for me. what did was doxepin. its in the sAME class as trazadone but really put me out. a real heavy weight is remerion. will knock a horse out but you will have trouble functioning next day. now that I am depression and anxiety free -o sleep like a baby every night -all night. I suffered tru insomnia for months and know what you are going tru. . getting drs to prescribe real sleep meds is hard these days and trazadone is their go to drug . doxepin was MUCH better for me you may want to ask about it if no success with traz. its an old antidepressant and when used in low doses is effective for insomnia. traz is the same kind of drug.

175973436,"Hey there, I've had pretty bad anxiety my whole life as well as panic attacks. Last week was really stressful (just dealings with life, work, and an ulcerative colitis flare). And for the past few days, I've been in this constant daze-- like feeling a sort of disassociation from my body. I slip in and out of the world. There are a few things that I can do (e.g. listing out all my worries, taking a Xanax, talking things out) that can help get me out of it but it's pretty scary. I can best describe it as when you're at the height of a panic attack and you feel like your perception of the world is off, except it's this ongoing feeling. I went to urgent care and they tested my blood and gave me basic brain functioning tests and everything was fine. But it keeps happening. Has anyone else felt this? It feels like a vicious cycle, that when I feel it coming on, my anxiety kicks in even more and makes it worse. No other symptoms (no pain, no double vision, no motor function problems, sleep is decent). It'
s just really scary. I don't want to become a different person and slip into a nervous breakdown. It should be noted I've been on Prednisone for two months for my flare. Anyways, this is a lot of information. Hopefully someone has felt something similar and realized it's temporary. Thanks, D"

175973447,"People that say that take personal responsibility for their own actions, its pretty much a given for most people, and it works quite well. Of course if someone is only driven by other people, or socially driven, it won't work, and all that is left is trying to manipulate others to make them drive you, which inevitably fails and creates resentments or discontent. So it is a hopeless endeavor, and destroys more lives that can be counted. The only real solution to an external locus of control is an internal one, which means owning what one does. Its actually the opposite of wishful thinking. Wishful thinking is to believe the world can be a better place, and will magically make one happy. Realistic thinking is to realize the world is full of hardship, but that if you are going to so something, to it well, and leave something withchy. But nobody is forcing anybody to do stuff, this is just self-imposed oppression."

""Do androids dream of electric Kool-Aid acid tests? If thereÂ’s to be any hope for us, they will. That is the message of _NAME_’s splendidly mind-bending book, which mashes up _NAME_, The Matrix, _PERSON_, Â“zombie AIÂ”, _PERSON_, and research on psychedelic drugs. In our age of techno-utopianism, we are routinely told in crypto-religious terms about the coming Â“SingularityÂ” Â– the creation of superintelligent, conscious machines. One problem with superintelligent conscious machines, however _PERSON_– as SF writers down the ages and some modern philosophers agree _PERSON_– is that they might very well choose to destroy all humans. How to stop the godlike robots wiping us out? The best way, Smart suggests, might be to give them a dose of digital LSD to force open their doors of perception. That might sound like far-out hippy futuris
m, but much of this book is devoted to unravelling the woolly thinking of machine intelligence enthusiasts themselves. Against widely held modern assumptions, Smart advances the following claims: one, information does not really exist; two, computation does not happen in the human brain; three, computation does not even happen in computers. LetÂ’s take these in turn. First, it is fashionable in some quarters to believe that Â“informationÂ” is a fundamental entity in the universe. (This may be because such theorists are unconsciously projecting our own societyÂ’s love affair with Â“informationÂ” on to the rest of reality.) But in _PERSON_’s reasonable view, information only makes sense in the context of a conscious observer. If there were no minds in the universe, there would be no information. So Â“informationÂ” is a useful shorthand for talking about the ways we interact with reality, but it is not reality in itself. What about the idea that our brains do computations? This is obvio
usly another metaphor taken from developments in industrial society. But, as Smart shows, it is misleading to think of the brain as a machine that runs algorithms on sets of data. (Indeed, he observes, this is a form of Â“dualismÂ”.) No one knows how consciousness works, Smart adds, and what our brains do might be uncomputable in principle. Researchers hope one day to model an entire human brain in software, but the gulf in complexity between a brain and any computer currently imaginable is even vaster than we had thought. (As Smart points out, youÂ’d probably have to model not only the billions of neurons and trillions of synapses but the dendrites on the neurons, and the dendritic spines that grow on the dendrites.) The problem for neuroscience, Smart argues, is that _PERSON_“we do not currently have any story about the mind that is not computational. We might be at a similar stage in neuroscience that physics was in before quantum physics.Â” Sign up for Bookmarks: discover new books in our we
ekly email Read more Surely, though, we can at least say that computations are happening inside computers? (After all, there is a designer of algorithms, the programmer.) Not really, Smart insists. In a bravura section, he explains how circuits and microchips actually work, which is far from being as clean and precise a matter as we suppose. ItÂ’s a messy soup of electrons, and the supposedly binary values of one and zero (or on and off) are not the only option in town. (Because of the vagaries of voltage, a logic gate, Smart explains, can effectively be stuck on Â“halfÂ”.) All that is happening inside a computer is that electricity is being pushed around. You need a conscious observer to interpret it as a dance of computation and information. So far, then, _PERSON_’s book is devoted to undermining ungrounded nostrums about Â“machine intelligenceÂ” and arguing that any conscious computer will probably be much further in the future than the mid-21st century predicted by technomystics such as _
PERSON_, GoogleÂ’s director of engineering. (People at Google, Smart wryly suggests, ought to be more interested in fundamental philosophy than they seem to be.) But of course, predicting that something will never happen is likely to be a losing bet. So Smart now accepts for the sake of argument that one day there might be machines that seem to us as though they are conscious. What then? The famous Â“Turing testÂ” for machine intelligence stipulates that we may as well accept that a machine is conscious if, in conversation, an impartial human interlocutor cannot tell the difference between it and a real person. Smart thinks a better test is: can the machine experience altered states of consciousness? LSD, in the authorÂ’s own experience and according to cognitive science research, does very interesting things both subjectively to the mind and objectively to patterns of neuronal activation in the brain. Only a conscious being can experience a trip. So if we feed a computer some digital LSD equivale
nt and it reports a weird experience, that may be a better test of consciousness than mere conversation. WhatÂ’s more, on _PERSON_’s view, this may save the human species. For people who take LSD report feelings of wonder, oneness with the universe, and concern for all things. Induce the same feelings in a superintelligent conscious computer and it may, after all, be inclined to help and nurture its creators rather than eliminate them. ItÂ’s a nice idea, though I couldnÂ’t help thinking that a superintelligent computer would also be clever enough to tell us exactly what we want to hear, shortly before it unleashes Armageddon."" and ""Autopilot: The Art and Science of Doing Nothing by _NAME_ Smart"". ""_NAME_ Smart wants you to sit and do nothing much more oftenÂ—and he has the science to explain why. At every turn we're pushed to do more, faster, and more efficiently: That drumbeat resounds throughout our wage-slave society. Multitasking is not only a virtue, it's a necessity. Books such as Gett
ing Things Done, The One Minute Manager, and The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People regularly top the best seller lists, and have spawned a considerable industry. But _NAME_ Smart argues that slackers may have the last laugh. The latest neuroscience shows that the ""culture of effectiveness"" is not only ineffective, it can be harmful to your well-being. He makes a compelling caseÂ—backed by scienceÂ—that filling life with activity at work and at home actually hurts your brain. A survivor of corporate-mandated ""Six Sigma"" training to improve efficiency, Smart has channeled a self-described ""loathing"" of the time-management industry into a witty, informative, and wide-ranging audiobook that draws on the most recent research into brain power. 174366351,"Subtyping schizophrenia can be very tricky as there may be overlap in symptoms from one subtype to another. You could read about th DXM-V criteria for schizophrenia and see what they are, if you want to learn more about all this. Just google it. I have bipolar type 1, but I spend a ton of time psychotic, so, have much in common with people with schz. It has just been my experience, knowing a bunch of people with these illnesses over the years, that some are very open with their delusions, want to convince others they are true, etc., and others are not. I suppose the paranoid schizophrenic may be more inclined to the latter, but the experts here can say more on that much more reliably than me. Good luck to you and your dad. Very glad he is getting some help."

175973672,"Provided there is nothing wrong with your throat (which you said you were going to get checked out) yes it is normal and common symptom of anxiety. It could be Globus hystericus which can range from feeling like something is stuck there to a lump sensation that never quite goes away. Again, provided there is nothing physically wrong it is just very annoying. Also if you have anxiety that your breathing pattern (short shallow breaths) is drying out your throat which doesn't help the sensation. Mine was brought on after cold/upper respiratory thing and gradually went away. Also my silent GERD was exacerbating it. Might want to get checked for GERD/Silent GERD as well. A third option could be tonsil stones which will work themselves out eventually. I don't think I have ever had these but an ENT could diagnose and flush/remove if necessary. I could drink hot or cold liquids but some people with GH might have difficulty with either or both. If that is the case drink room temp or lukewarm beverages. I wi
ll also note when I had it at its worst I could eat and swallow food just fine. It just FELT like something was caught there. According to internet research almost half the population will experience globus hystericus at some point so if there is nothing physically wrong then just be patient and it will resolve eventually. You have my empathy with how annoying and irritating it can be."
174366338,"This research material presents firsthand experiences of people who observed an unrecognized/unidentified phenomenon on Earth. This phenomenon gives false evidence supporting these delusions and can be recognized as synchronicities. The existence of these unique synchronicities goes back to the 17th/18th century. A researcher who critically analyzes these human experiences will understand that the cause behind these synchronicities is affecting the thoughts and actions of human beings in extremely complicated ways. Due to this nature, these unique synchronicities could easily make you believe that people know your thoughts, and they are indirectly referring to your thoughts and/or they indirectly talk about you. Therefore, these synchronicities are able to establish strongly held false beliefs in an observer's mind. A Brief Introduction: In my main research material, I stated that I observed a phenomenon that was not known to humanity prior I end up concluding that people know my thoughts. Source: 
The Deceptive Nature Of Synchronicities Sheds Light Into The Gangstalking Phenomenon, Schizophrenia, And Our Delusions! – The Ultimate Disclosure Of the Man-Made Phenomena! I observed this phenomenon again and again, and it provided me false evidence supporting the view that ""people know my thoughts."" In other words, at times, people actually reacted to my thoughts within seconds, and these reactions gave me convincing evidence for me to conclude that ""people know my thoughts."" But then again, at times, after I was thinking something, I observed a meaningful event which correlated with my thoughts a few minutes, a few hours or a few days later. These events gave me convincing evidence for me to conclude that ""people know my thoughts."" I faced an extremely high number of such synchronistic events (sometimes more than 15 cases per day). Therefore, these events cannot be considered as mere coincidences. Human thoughts and actions are getting affected due to an unknown reason to humanity. However, this do
es not mean that people know your actual thoughts. Once I managed to correct my false conclusions (delusions), I carried out extensive research, there I came to know that human beings around the world have been observing the same phenomenon. And they also have ended up concluding that ""people know my thoughts"" by observing the phenomenon. Once the false belief which is ""people know my thoughts"" have been established in human minds, some of them also have ended up concluding that ""my thoughts are broadcasting."" I came to an understanding that they have made this conclusion by trying to understand their observations. (For example, if so many people know my thoughts, then my thoughts could be broadcasting.) (Note that people who observe these synchronistic events will first start believing that people know my thoughts. Once this view is established in their minds, they would even claim that ""my thoughts are broadcasting"", ""people could read my mind"", ""I'm a telepathic"", ""my mind is a transmitter of 
thoughts"", I'm a psychic, I'm experiencing Artificial/Synthetic Telepathy developed by NSA/CIA/MI5, etc.) Therefore, these so-called unshakeable delusions are nothing more than erroneous conclusions. Dr. _NAME_ used the word ""synchronicity"" to explain meaningful coincidences/events in his book ""Synchronicity: An acausal connecting principle."" This phenomenon that human beings observe can be recognized as synchronicities or meaningful coincidences/events. Observing a high number of unique synchronicities is the cause behind these delusions. These synchronicities or meaningful coincidences/events can be recognized further as meaningful verbal and nonverbal events (synchronicities will fall under these two communication categories). The person who observes these meaningful verbal and nonverbal events will see clear correlations to his/her thoughts. Since these are independent events, but yet it occurs in such a way where the event will deliver a specific meaning to the observer(s), these events are synchron
icities. For example: While you are thinking of a particular movie, your friend who is next to you start talking about the same movie. Although the word synchronicity is used to explain meaningful coincidences or meaningful events, there's a huge difference between a true coincidence and a synchronicity or a synchronistic event. A true coincidence is an extremely rare event. However, synchronicities or synchronistic events are not rare. Sometimes you would experience 10, 15+ synchronicities during a day. Therefore, the driving force behind synchronistic events is not the same as true coincidences. When you experience such a high number of meaningful coincidences or meaningful events, then you would understand that you are facing synchronistic events and these are not true coincidences. For example, this individual is facing synchronicities, and these are not true coincidences: Source: Original Synchronicity Stories 1 This strange phenomenon could happen with live TV/Radio presenters, TV/Radio commercials, or 
even with TV shows. Assume you are reading something and that has the word ""key terms"" in it. By the time you read that unique text, you hear live TV presenter uses the same word at the exact moment or just seconds after that, in his spoken words. This timing activity could happen with TV commercials. By the time you are about to read the word ""key terms"" in the sentence, the right TV commercial also gets aired which has the word ""key terms"" in its script. Then by the time you read the word, the TV commercial also gets aligned in such a way, where you will get to hear TV commercial saying ""key terms"" at the exact moment of just seconds after that. This same thing could happen with TV shows as well. When you analyze these events deeply, you will understand that your thoughts and actions are being affected mysteriously. Further, according to Dr. _NAME_ survey, the most frequent coincidence was: - I think of an idea and hear or see it on the radio, TV or internet. (Out of 1500 people who has visited the 
site, 200 (13%) had taken the weird coincidence survey) Source: Weird Coincidence Survey Results - Connecting with Coincidence (Dr. _NAME_ is a visiting professor at the University of _NAME_ and a former chair of the Department of Psychiatry at the University of Missouri-Colombia) When it comes to the delusions mentioned in this research material, the following are examples of meaningful verbal and nonverbal events or synchronistic events that you would observe: Verbal Events: Spoken words of a person(spoken words in a face to face conversation, TV/ Radio presenters speech, telephone conversations, etc.), written notes and emails, etc. An Individual would observe such an event by correlating to a thought that the individual had. For example: i). While you are thinking something, the person who stays next to you start talking about the same thing or would say something that would correlate with your thoughts. ii). The person who is next to you would write something, and that will correlate with your thoughts, 
or you receive an email where its title or body would show correlations to your thought. Nonverbal Events: Sudden Facial expressions (smiling, laughing, frowning, etc.), Sudden Gestures, Signs, Sudden Eye contacts, Sudden Behavioral changes, Paralinguistic events (ex: tone and loudness of spoken speech). For example: i). You got a negative thought in your mind about the person who is sitting next to you, and you observe that person suddenly look into your eyes and frown or move away from you. ii). While you are thinking of something, the person who is next to you say something in a sarcastic (voice tone) manner or that person would suddenly smile or laugh, and you see a clear correlation to your thought. How to understand if you are facing synchronicities and that your belief or conclusion is not true: I). You will observe a high number of meaningful coincidences/events. II). You will have to give so many references for your belief to another person when explaining the reasoning behind your conclusion. The me
dical community will consider these references as ideas of references and delusions of references. III). These events can be recognized as meaningful verbal & nonverbal events. Most of the time, it would be like people are indirectly referring to your thoughts / life events. IV). These observable events will make you believe that people know your thoughts / know you / know your life events. V). So many people will reject your claims, accusations, or your beliefs. VI). You will see that your conclusions are controversial yet these unusual events will still convince you. VII). Certain events can even make you think that your government, police officers, people in streets, corporations, your family members, friends etc. are conspiring against you / harassing you on purpose or even monitoring you. VIII). What you observe is not a normal human experience. IX). The medical community has recognized your claim as a delusion. If your experience shows the above characteristics, what you are observing is synchronicities
. People are not aware of your thoughts. Neither your thoughts are broadcasting. The cause behind synchronicities is actually affecting human thoughts and actions, and it will create meaningful events. These meaningful events would correlate with your thoughts. Therefore, these events will give you false evidence to make you believe that people know your thoughts. But in reality, your thoughts are not known by others, so they would reject your claim. These synchronicities or verbal and nonverbal events that correlate with our thoughts are being observed by people around the world who have these delusions. These so-called unshakeable delusions are nothing more than erroneous conclusions made by the observers of the phenomenon. To understand the below human experiences, you may assume that your thoughts are actually broadcasting. I). If so, do you think people would laugh at your thoughts? Will they smile? Will they get angry and show an angry face? Will they move away from you? Will they show a surprising look 
just because you had such a thought? - All these are meaningful nonverbal events or synchronicities that you would observe if your thoughts are actually broadcasting. II). Will they say something meaningful in replying to your thoughts? Will they repeat what you just thought? These are meaningful verbal events or synchronicities that you would observe if your thoughts are actually broadcasting. (By using the words ""Synchronistic Events / Synchronicities"" this material would refer to such meaningful verbal and nonverbal events. The observer will see these events always correlating to his/her thoughts when it occurs.) Human beings who claim that people know my thoughts/ my thoughts are broadcasting is observing a high number of such synchronistic events. 175973701,"I read a study a few months ago which stated that high consumption of low ph drinks (soda) combined with caffeine, and also cns stimulating nicotine from cigarettes/vapes can reduce the efficacy of antipsychotics by up to 99%. Does this happen to any of you guys or is it just me? Can’t remember the link to the study, but if you search for it using ‘aps efficacy inefficient’ you may find it. I don’t get any extra pyramidal symptoms on aps due to cigarettes, vaping and coffee/coke/energy drinks. Let me know what you guys think."
175973702,"I will add some perspective of the astranged ""child"" ...I'm 48. I think it's likely difficult all the way around for everyone. Without knowing the catalyst or v specifics of either of your situations, it's hard for me to say something like, ""It's never too late."" But I do think parents are caught in a Catch 22 being fanned if they do reach out and rammed if they don't. I think the important thing to remember is, ""There's no winning and no prize for giving up."" To heal, effort must shown regardless of the immediate result. Broken trust and broken people don't mend without unyielding sacrifice of sincere effort without expectation ofv anything in return. Not accommodation or recognition of emotions or even acknowledgment that the hope to heal sorrow exists in the other's heart. The point I'm trying to make is forgiveness is not necessarily the end game. The end game is mastering the self-discipline to show your love as parents regardless of rejection, spite, rage, or disdain. If you as parents 
truly possess the love you profess to have for your children; it must be given over without the expectation of reciprocation. It must be without conditions, caveats, or fear of consequence. It must be given over to them in this way because it is your love that is in question. If one needs a return on their gestures, a validation of their sentiments, a proof of purchase if you will... then that really isn't lovev at all. It's self pity. And that's the last thing an astranged parent should want to project upon their child."

175973723,"THIS UN REPORT INCLUDE A DEFINITION OF “CYBERTORTURE” BY THE UN SPECIAL RAPPORTEUR ON TORTURE. On February 28, 2020, the UN Special Rapporteur on Torture, Professor _PERSON_, issued his World Report on “Torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.” This report included a definition of “Cybertorture,” the Crime Against Humanity where millions of targeted victims worldwide are remotely assaulted with Electromagnetic Weapons in actions directed via computer, often from Supercomputers. (A/HRC/43/49) Cybertorture: 1. A particular area of concern, which does not appear to have received sufficient attention, is the possible use of various forms of information and communication technology (“cybertechnology”) for the purposes of torture. Although the promotion, protection and enjoyment of human rights on the internet has been repeatedly addressed by the Human Rights Council (A/HRC/32/L.20; A/HRC/38/L.10/Rev.1), torture has been understood primarily as a tool used to 
_USER_ID_ the exercise of the right to freedom of expression on the internet, and not as a violation of human rights that could be committed through the use of cybertechnology. 2. This seems surprising given that some of the characteristics of cyber-space make it an environment highly conducive to abuse and exploitation, most notably a vast power asymmetry, virtually guaranteed anonymity, and almost complete impunity. States, corporate actors and organized criminals not only have the capacity to conduct cyberoperations inflicting severe suffering on countless individuals, but may well decide to do so for any of the purposes of torture. It is therefore necessary to briefly explore, in a preliminary manner, the conceivability and basic contours of what could be described as “cybertorture”. 3. In practice, cybertechnology already plays the role of an “enabler” in the perpetration of both physical and psychological forms of torture, most notably through the collection and transmission of surveillance info
rmation and instructions to interrogators, through the dissemination of audio or video recordings of torture or murder for the purposes of intimidation, or even live streaming of child sexual abuse “on demand” of voyeuristic clients (A/HRC/28/56, para.71), and increasingly also through the remote control or manipulation of stun belts (A/72/178, para.51), medical implants and, conceivably, nanotechnological or neurotechnological devices.1 Cybertechnology can also be used to inflict, or contribute to, severe mental suffering while avoiding the conduit of the physical body, most notably through intimidation, harassment, surveillance, public shaming and defamation, as well as appropriation, deletion or manipulation of information. 4. The delivery of serious threats through anonymous phone calls has long been a widespread method of remotely inflicting fear. With the advent of the internet, State security services in particular have been reported to use cybertechnology, both in their own territory and abroad, f
or the systematic surveillance of a wide range of individuals and/or for direct interference with their unhindered access to cyber technology.2 Electronic communication services, social media platforms and search engines provide an ideal environment both for the anonymous delivery of targeted threats, sexual harassment and extortion and for the mass dissemination of intimidating, defamatory, degrading, deceptive or discriminatory narratives. 5. Individuals or groups systematically targeted by cybersurveillance and cyberharassment are generally left without any effective means of defence, escape, or self-protection and, at least in this respect, often find themselves in a situation of “powerlessness” comparable to physical custody. Depending on the circumstances, the physical absence and anonymity of the perpetrator may even exacerbate the victim’s emotions of helplessness, loss of control, and vulnerability, not unlike the stress-augmenting effect of blindfolding or hooding during physical torture. Like
wise, the generalized shame inflicted by public exposure, defamation and degradation can be just as traumatic as direct humiliation by perpetrators in a closed environment.3 As various studies on cyber-bullying have shown, already harassment in comparatively limited environments can expose targeted individuals to extremely elevated and prolonged levels of anxiety, stress, social isolation and depression, and significantly increases the risk of suicide.4 Arguably, therefore, much more systematic, government-sponsored threats and harassment delivered through cybertechnologies not only entail a situation of effective powerlessness, but may well inflict levels of anxiety, stress, shame and guilt amounting to “severe mental suffering” as required for a finding of torture.5 6. More generally, in order to ensure the adequate implementation of the prohibition of torture and related legal obligations in present and future circumstances, its interpretation should evolve in line with new challenges and capabilities 
arising in relation to emerging technologies not only in cyberspace, but also in areas such as artificial intelligence, robotics, nanotechnology and neurotechnology, or pharmaceutical and biomedical sciences, including so-called “human enhancement”. 1. _PERSON_, “Next-generation nonsurgical neurotechnology”, Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, available at https://www.darpa.mil/program/next-g...eurotechnology 2 See Human Rights Council resolutions 32/13 and 38/7. See, most notably, the 2013 disclosures by _NAME_ of the global surveillance activities conducted by the United States National Security Agency and its international partners, see _PERSON_ and _NAME_ Dance, “NSA files: decoded – what the revelations mean for you”, The Guardian, 1 November 2013. 3 _PERSON_Sales, “Internet and torture” (forthcoming). 4 _NAME_ and others, “Self-harm, suicidal behaviours, and cyberbullying in children and young people: systematic review”, Journal of Medical Internet Research, vol. 20, No. 4 (
2018); _PERSON_ and others, “The emotional impact of bullying and cyberbullying on victims: a European cross-national study”, Aggressive Behavior, vol. 38, No. 5 (September/October 2012). 5 _NAME_ and _NAME_, “A torture-free cyber space: a human right”, 2017."

But! Know this I love you EXACTLY as you are ALWAYS! Sassy Linking bipolar disorder and alcohol use disorder Researchers haven’t identified a clear link between bipolar disorder and AUD, but there are some possibilities. Some theorize that when AUD appears first, it 
can trigger bipolar disorder. There’s no hard scientific evidence for this idea, though. Other theories suggest that people with bipolar disorder turn to alcohol in an attempt to quiet their symptoms, especially manic symptoms. Another explanation for the connection is that people with bipolar disorder exhibit reckless behavior, and AUD is consistent with this type of behavior. If you have both conditions, it matters which condition appears first. People who receive a diagnosis of AUD may recover faster than people who first receive a diagnosis of bipolar disorder. On the other hand, people who receive a diagnosis of bipolar disorder first are more likely to have difficulty with the symptoms of AUD."
