175974997,"I think that is very good. One of the things I would like to say is, when you go in to see the psychiatrist you’ll go in as depressed. He’ll sit there for 15-30 minutes and won’t say anything. He’ll write you out a script for a pill, he may mumble “anti-depressant.” You’re fixing to waste 15 years of your life being miss-diagnosed, miss-medicated and miserable. It’s just a wild guess. During those 15-30 minutes of being silent, he could have said, “Do you ever have a racing mind?” He could have thought, “Well, if she’s depressed, she could be manic-depressed, so why don’t I ask her if she’s ever had a racing mind, a sign of mania?” I don’t why they don’t ask that. So, you might want to go in prepared. You might want to download the signs of bipolar, including the signs of mania. Check off the ones you have and read them off to him. OK. Just a little preparation there. Also, if you type into the search engine, “Do I have biopolar?” or something like that. You’
re looking for a site that can ask you 20 questions and if you answer 15 of them in a certain way it may indicate you have bipolar. Again, take the list to the psychiatrist, one for you and one for him. See what he thinks and if you think he’s completely off base you can get another doctor. I have a female psychiatrist so I seem to be better with that. Also, medicine has side affects, but I choose to take the medicine because it helps. Also, I think the medicine will help, but at times I have to remind myself that I have a major mental illness, bipolar. I don’t think about it a lot of time, but I still have difficulties. Be myself, I often don’t feel my mental illness. In a social situation, I can. So, what I’m saying is, there can still be difficult times ahead, but I think if we think positive, we will do better, and maybe even give ourselves credit for doing well a lot of the time even though we do have a major mental illness. I use the positive thinking many times a day. If a container of water sp
ills on the floor, I immediately start the positive thinking, get some rags and clean it up. I can use that process 10 times in an hour, 10 times a project, as I break each part of the project down into one positive step. You say, “I wish I could give my kids the sense that they are okay as they are. But I don’t believe about myself.” Well, if you feel positive about yourself, you’ll feel the same way about them and they’ll feel the same away about themselves. And you can tell them directly, “You did a really good job with that.” And “I appreciate your help.” Look for an excuse to praise them. If you raise them negative they will be negative. Set up rewards such as popcorn and movie night, or bikes in the park or down a nearby road or in a nearby neighborhood. Use your worry and your positive thinking to think up what might be enjoyable for them five minutes from now, a week from now. If a bike needs fixing for that, think about fixing it. Maybe an above ground pool for the summer. You say, 
My “thing” is constant scanning and diagnosing: what’s wrong, what’s broken, how can I fix it, what can I do, what improvements next, etc. I’m always looking for solutions but at the expense of being okay with things as they are.” I don’t think there’s anything wrong with wanting to make things better. Here’s a saying: “And now that you don’t have to be perfect, you can be good.” —_NAME_ East of _NAME_ And “You are your best thing” Beloved, Author: _NAME_, 1987 And “Anyone who ever gave you confidence, you owe them a lot.” Breakfast At _NAME_'s _NAME_, 1958 And, “I know not all that may be coming, but be it what it will, I’ll go to it laughing.” _PERSON_ Author: _NAME_, Year: 1851 ""Even though the world doesn’t understand you, it needs you. It needs people like you because you give it balance, you give people hope and you remind people that it’s okay to real, soft and vulnerable. You remind people that it’s okay to be a non-perfect human being. — _PERSON_, To T
he Ones Who Are Tired Of Apologizing For Their Feelings ""At the end of the day, you’re entitled to every one of your feelings. Don’t allow anyone to belittle you for your sensitivity. 175975007,"Fortunately, cognitive therapies like CR and CBT are time-limited and results-oriented. Evaluating their success is more straight-forward than it is for many other forms of mental health treatment and support. How to Tell Cognitive Therapy is Working for You (or a Loved One) 1. You have learned new skills – A skill is observable, specific, and enduring. It is an ability that combines knowledge and behavior to do the things that make a difference in your life. Having a more positive attitude is not a skill. Using a Thought Record in CBT to evaluate and respond to automatic negative thoughts is. 2. You are making progress towards your long-term goals – Cognitive therapy for people with serious mental illness is most effective when it is linked to long-term goals for recovery such as finishing college or living independently. You can measure short-term progress by breaking these big recovery goals into smaller steps. Strengthening attention and working memory in CR can lead to improved prospects f
or success in college. 3. You can measure the results – It is the therapist’s responsibility to provide you a way to measure your progress. The computer-based drills of the Neuropsychological Educational Approach to Cognitive Remediation (NEAR) allow you to monitor weekly progress on those exercises. CR providers should also offer comprehensive testing that measures overall improvement in your thinking skills over the course of the entire program. In CBT, your therapist should help you set specific goals and a time frame for achieving them. Many CBT therapists assign homework at the end of sessions. Focusing on specific assignments, tasks, and exercises makes it easier for your therapist and you to measure the results. 4. Other people notice you are getting better – Cognitive therapy focuses on helping people achieve specific real-world goals. Once that happens people around you will start to notice and those who are closest to you will no doubt want to share their excitement at seeing the changes you h
ave made. 5. You look forward to the next session with enthusiasm – Cognitive therapy is not about hashing over old problems and feelings from the past. It’s about learning new skills and moving forward in your life. Chances are that if that’s happening in sessions you will feel good about them and want to return. This is the most important indicator of success: your own feeling that you are getting better. http://www.rtor.org/2016/10/18/cognitive-therapy-part-4 /"

175975096,"I think you ought to be given a medal for what you say you are going though. It’s good you are communicating with your therapist. Have you ever seen a psychiatrist to see what they may think? You list a number of negatives, but there are some positives. One is that you are reaching out for help, and you’re not having to leave your house as far as this website is concerned. You have to be very smart and level thinking to do that. Another positive is that you have a physical structure for you and your kids to live in and at no monetary cost. You have air conditioning , TV, stove, fridge, lights, furniture, roof over your head, floor, you are protected from the wind and the rain and the heat, and in the winter you will be protected from the cold. You are looking at every negative that you can find, and you are finding it. Your worst condition may be your attitude. I’ve had it myself, so I know that what that’s like. I know what it’s like to be your own worst enemy, for decades, I know that. 
You could be in a much worse situation. _PERSON_ says, “Do all you can to reduce your anxiety through self help we have some good links in our resources section so take a look and keep us posted we are here to help support you.” Those resources are located at the opening page of this forum, at the top of the list of people writing in with problems, titled “Anxiety-Panic Resources.” You can click on that. One of the suggestions is being positive. We can go to all the therapists we want, but if we aren’t positive, we’re still tripping ourselves up. Your description of being in the same room as a football game on TV is comical. tand living at someone else’s place, it’s his not mine, I’ve always had my own place but I’m finding things really stressful and makes me physically sick like how the interior is, how things are placed in the kitchen. The way he had his couch was so stressful and one day he changed it and I felt soooo much better."" You write like _PERSON_. 175975136,"You have depression , or bipolar disorder. And on some days, you feel like you’re treading water—at best. You’re tired of struggling. You’re tired of regularly feeling tired. You’re angry that your to-do list just keeps getting longer and longer. You’re angry that you have to deal with so much darkness day in and day out. Some days are just hard. Some days you feel so overwhelmed. It is on these days that you probably feel like the only person on the planet who’s struggling with persistent symptoms. Thankfully, you’re not. And thankfully, it will get better. We asked individuals who live with depression or bipolar disorder to share what they’d like others who are feeling overwhelmed with these same conditions to know. Most of the individuals are speakers from This Is My Brave , a fantastic nonprofit organization that hosts live events and aims to “end the _USER_ID_ surrounding mental illness through storytelling.” https://psychcentral.com/blog/what-i-want-someone-whos-overwhel
med-with-their-mood-disorder-to-know/"

175975138,I've put myself under so much stress.. What do I do? Should I read and ignore the world? I think I should do that
175975139,"Hi I'm new to this forum! So I'll just give you all some background information about when I got my panic disorder. I'm an English citizen that was at the time living in Australia. I was working a double shifts as an English Teacher at a language school doing day and night classes (14 hour working days) The job was both demanding and stressful. I've always been the kind of person that gets stressed very easily, particularly at work, but I've always managed it and it has never been chronic , debilitating or unhealthy. For example, I would have a bad day at work and go home stressed then the next day I'd be fine and back to my normal self. It was around March 20th when I experienced Panic Disorder. My work contract had finished and I'd planned to go up to the North of Australia for a holiday then travel around Asia and Dubai before coming home back home to the UK. I had paid for all of this trip already. It was the 23rd March (the day before I was set to leave for North Australia) that the Australian 
government decided to shut all the borders due to Covid. This meant that we were trapped where we were. The authorities told us that it was time for any expats to go home as it was no longer safe so we tried to book a 2000 dollar flight home and it was cancelled due to the Singapore borders being closed too. We were no longer welcome in Australia but we could not get home either and we couldn't get the money back that we had spent on these flights.This meant that we were trapped in our tiny apartment in Sydney with a significant amount of our savings lost. I'd felt upset and stressed about the situation but it wasn't anything unhealthy. I'd gone from working 14 hour days to spending all day in a flat during lockdown on my own with nothing to do. So one night I felt pretty relaxed. I sat watching a film that I was pretty into when all of a sudden it felt like a big lightning bolt had struck me. I felt this intense feeling of fear and panic that had came out of nowhere for no reason. I had to leave the room as 
I thought I was going crazy. I couldn't breathe, I felt like I didn't know who I was or where I was anymore, I can remember looking at my hands and they just didnt feel like mine. It was like a million voices screaming in my head and I tried to count through it but my mind just felt as if it was depleting and there was nothing I could do about it which was making me feel even more anxious as I was losing control. After coming in and out of this hell for hours into the night and contemlating A and E at times, I eventually fell asleep. I'd realised at this point that it was a panic attack. Sadly, I was hoping I'd wake up in the morning and the feeling would be gone but I still felt the same. I wasn't having a panic attack anymore but I can remember crying my eyes out because it felt like I wasn't me anymore and I thought I was going crazy. I felt constant crippling fear and derealization/ depersonalisation all the time. I didn't recognise myself anymore even though I could mimic the old me to other people, but 
the reality was that inside i just felt like an imposter in my own brain and I craved the old me, I had taken for granted who I was and how happy and healthy i was before; I had began to feel like i would never feel normal again. The feeling was so unfamiliar to me that I didn't know if it was anxiety or whether i was really going insane. I found every time I would try to do something nice to escape this feeling it would ruin my experiences by tainting me with fear and panic so I just couldn't live a normal life anymore. I couldn't eat solid food, I vomited most mornings and lost a lot of weight. I was sure I was going to starve to death. I remember thinking that the old me would have loved losing all this weight, I would be in the mirror trying all my clothes on to see how loose they were and planning my next night out,(when lockdown was over) but I was too scared to look in the mirrors anymore because the depersonalisation was so bad that I didn't recognise the person looking back. I started to get intrusiv
e thoughts. Imagine if you went crazy and they had to lock you away because you were so out of control- i would think, sometimes they would be disturbing and I couldn't watch anything particularly heavy on TV anymore, because I was worried about what weird thoughts my torturous brain would throw at me. I remember having a panic attack one day because I couldn't find my shopping bag which I was adamant I'd left in the kitchen, it made me feel like I was going insane and this triggered the attack, a normal person would have just realized I'd forgot I'd put it in the bedroom but because i felt so unstable I was thinking all kinds of weird things. My friend said I'd made her laugh once for dancing around the bedroom, I couldn't remember this memory so i was adamant that I was losing my mind and had another panic attack- funnily enough the memory actually came back to me later that day. Because of the derealisation I had a real sense that I was in some hyper-real world and those around me wern't real and this conv
inced me even more that I was losing the plot- so of course- I had more panic attacks. It was so irrational that sometimes when I was on the edge of a panic attack, experiencing this impending doom, I felt petrified and overwhelmed by absolutely everything, even hearing certain music, or smelling something deep fried, or seeing somebody in a facemask was all too much and I felt absolutely terrified. It was at night that things got even more scary. I used to get sleep starts and sleep tremors so bad that I would stay awake all night sometimes. I'd feel exhausted but when I tried to sleep my knee would jerk me back awake like an electric shock. Sometimes I would get woken up by nocturnal panic attacks and I swear it felt like I was hallucinating sometimes. My hands would be cold, sweaty and numb and I couldn't breathe. I still get restless leg syndrome, the overwhelming urge to move and kick your legs so much that you have to get up and move around. I would have terrible diarrea, sickness and excessive urinatio
n that I stopped wanting to drink liquid at times. While my symptoms are common to most people with panic disorder there are a few things that are slightly different. For example, most people with panic disorder feel a fear of going out in public places or going to events with lots of people because they feel trapped, I was the opposite. Whilst my panic attacks could come at any time for absolutely no reason. The thing I feared most was going to bed at night. Trapped in the dark with my own brain that had turned evil on me for some reason was the scariest thing. In terms of me getting myself out and about I actually enjoyed this because it would distract me from my intrusive thoughts and kept me busy. Most people say that they only feel safe in their beds but I'd do anything not to have to spend time in bed, alone, with my just my thoughts. I'd get up at the crack of dawn, throw up and then do anything to keep myself busy- one time I even wrote an english essay just to keep my mind occupied for a few hours. T
his was challenging especially during a lock down. It annoys me when people say that if you can go about your normal life then you don't have panic disorder because I went about my normal life but I suffered horrendous panic disorder in my brain and no one knew. i figured that even though I was having a mental crisis I would not stop living my life and I would always be a yes man and I actually think this helped me a lot. I remember being on a run one day, I had been experiencing severe anxiety every day for almost 3 weeks at this point, I was thinking, I am living in fear of fear. This is going to kill me. One of my good friends had committed suicide in January and I was starting to think that while I didn't feel depressed I will eventually become exhausted and maybe even suicidal (this was something I used to fear alongside going insane) and I need to get help because I wasn't getting any better and I was starting to think i had conditioned my brain to think like this forever. I needed to get it rewired bac
k to how it was before. Every night i'd go to sleep and think, please can I wake up feeling better tomorrow? And every morning I'd wake up with that nauseous feeling of debilitating anxiety. I'd started to realise that if i was ever going to get better this wouldn't disappear overnight, it would take time and professional help. The only thing I had on my side was that I didn't have depression but the anxiety and panic was so potent soon depression would follow if i didn't seek help. So that's exactly what I did. I will tell you more about this in my next post! But please share if you had any similar experiences, or if there is anything here that you felt too, or even any advice you may have! Thank you so much for reading!"

175975178,"Thank you. This is very helpful. I’m absolutely open to medicine, but I’ve had a hard time getting my doc to agree because of liver enzymes, desire to see if treating thyroid improves the mental/emotional symptoms, and general reluctance to believe that I’m “bad enough” to need help. I can behave functionally because of all my rehearsal pushing through extreme discomfort, but I’m not ok. Like, I gave unmedicated birth without showing unease. You have helped me see: I can schedule an appointment with someone else. My community is in desperate need for psychiatrists, and the wait is very long. Same for primary care physicians. There’s a town a couple hours away that might be worth the drive. It’s hard with kids though. I can figure something out. What you’re saying about positivity is true... I really try to stay positive and I’m currently trying to learn DNRS to try to retrain my brain to be less “activated”. My “thing” is constant scanning and diagnosing: what’s wrong, 
what’s broken, how can I fix it, what can I do, what improvements next, etc. I’m always looking for solutions but at the expense of being okay with things as they are. I wish I could give my kids the sense that they are okay as they are. But I don’t believe about myself. I’ll call for a psychiatrist now."
175975179,"I want to start by saying that I am a 24 year old white male who weighs 180 pounds and I do recognize that I have anxiety, but I feel like something else is going on with me. I’ve had 3 different doctors tell me that they believe that all I’m having is anxiety. For the last 4 years I get random chest pains in the center and left side of my chest. I can feel my pulse in my hands sometimes even when my heart rate is in the 60’s and 70’s. I yawn a lot sometimes which also scares me. And some days when I wake up I just feel like I can’t do anything without feeling like I’m weak and out of breath. I always watch my heart rate and it never jumps up real high randomly (which is what my doctor said is real bad.) The chest pains come randomly though, I can’t seem to find a pattern with them. Even when I don’t feel anxious at all my chest can still hurt off and on all day. I also want to say that on one occasion at the ER the doctor thought I had GERD. Well whenever I first had them I thought 
I was dying so I went to the ER and they did a EKG and bloodwork and said I had a panic attack then proceeded to send me home. A couple of months go by and nothing changes so I decide to go see my doctor. I tell him my symptoms and he listens to my heart then proceeds to say “You have the strongest heart I’ve ever heard, your chances of a heart attack are basement level.” So he prescribes me Prozac and Buspirone. I’ll be honest and say that I didn’t take the medicine like I was supposed to and things never really changed for me. So a couple of years after that I decide to change my doctor and get a different opinion on things. I visit my new doctor and he immediately makes me do a EKG, X-ray of my chest, and blood work. A couple of days later he says everything looks good but your vitamin D is just a tad bit low so that is probably what is making your chest hurt. So I leave there and start taking vitamin D pills but again nothing is really helping. Again after a couple of months I went to the ER in 
fear that something was wrong with my heart. That day, like most days I just “feel off” or like I’m going to just fall out and my chest begins the sharp pains. So I enter the triage shaking and they did a EKG and more bloodwork. They came to the conclusion that my heart and blood looked good and they thought I had (Costochondritis) which is pretty much just inflamed bones in your chest. Even after all of these people telling me they don’t think anything is wrong with my heart I still don’t believe them so I go find a new doctor. I went and seen him this Thursday and described most of my symptoms to him. He listened to my heart then proceeded to do a EKG and bloodwork on me. When the EKG test came back he told me that I have Respiratory Sinus Arrhythmia which is harmless and he assured me that nothing was wrong with my heart. He says that I have generalized anxiety disorder. I still feel like the only way I can rule out my heart is by seeing a cardiologist. Everyone around me says I’m being irratio
nal and that I’m totally fine. Please if anyone has been through this or has any advice it would be greatly appreciated!"

175975280,"Sometimes in psychological literature, schizoid is used as a descriptor and not a diagnosis. I find that many times in the literature, schizoid is either used as a descriptor for lack of affect, or for people who do not frequently socialize, regardless of the reason for this lack of socialization. I think it's less a function of ""are you schizoid? well, then you're more likely to be a serial killer"" than, ""have a messed up childhood? that's likely to impair your ability to relate to other people as an adult -- which could make you look like someone with SPD, which could also lead to sociopathy or psychopathy... and a bunch of other things."""

174368592,"PEACH COBBLER 2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons sugar 1 teaspoon salt 2 cups shortening or butter 1 egg 1/4 cold water 3 pounds fresh peaches, peeled, pitted, sliced 1/4 cup lemon juice 3/4 cup OJ 1/2 cup butter 2 cups sugar 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg 1 teasponn cinnamon 1 tablespoon cornstarch 1 tablespoon sugar 1 tablespoon melted butter Instructions: In a med. bowl, sift together flour, 3 T sugar, and salt. work in shortening or butter with a pastry blender until it forms coarse crumbs. In a cup, whisk egg and cold water, drip over flour mixture and work with hands until a dough forms. Put in fridge for 30 mins. Preheat oven to 350 F. Roll out dough to 1/8 inch thickness and place at bottom and halfway up sides of 9 x 13 baking dish. Bake for 20 mins. or until golden brown. Mix peaches, lemon juice, and OJ in large saucepan. Add 1/2 cup butter. Mix 2 cups sugar, cornstarch, nutmeg, and cinnamon in bowl. Once butter is melted, add sugar mixture. Remove from heat and pour into crust. With remain
ing crust, cut into 1/4 inch by 1/2 inch strips and form a lattice. Sprinkle with 1T sugar and 1T butter. Bake for 35-4- mins, or until top crust is golden."

175975305,"Hello Sunflower Of all the illnesses in the world I, believe depression is close to the worst! I have been there, and I never want to go back. It was many years ago, but I remember it well. It is interesting to read your post and to see that you recognize exactly how you got to this point. Are you aware that you know ""why""? You say ""I have had depression since at least high school, but I always hid it and kept it inside. I don't talk about my feelings or my emotions. I bottle everything up"". There is your answer Sunflower. The reason we humans do that is because we have this dumb idea that if we were to talk about our feelings that ""no one would understand, because other people DONOT FEEL THE SAME WAY!"" And that is so wrong! Our feelings are no different than other people's feelings....we are not weird or different or crazy! And what's more, if we share how we feel, it is extremely good for us, AND....it is even good for the other person. Our feelings need to come out and to see the light of 
day...not be hidden away in a dark corner, where they can become sick and give us more emotional pain. If it is possible for you to go for counselling...do it, but if that is not possible, look at Inspire as a good place to come and chat....right here on your thread, and talk about the things which bother you, and first thing you will know....YOU ARE NOT ALONE!"

175975389,"Let's just say I have grandchildren. Which is how I spend much of my time, writing family history and putting together photo albums for my grandchildren, for my grand nieces and nephews. Yeah, there ain't much going on this time around. I have ""Oh, my gosh!!"" reactions to things to. I panic and my thinking slows down. Just the other day, I had a health food pill I needed to take, but I only have 3 mg. tablets, and I needed 1 mg. and I was out of the 1 mg. My first reaction was to panic. It was a sleep aid tablet and I didn't want to take more than I needed. Then my positive thinking kicked in and actually overrode the panic, and I said, ""Cut the 3 mg. pill in half, and just pick out the pieces that look to total 1 mg."" And I did. And the next night I did the same thing. Then the next day, the neighbor who had been saying the 1 mg. sleep aid pills would be at his back door by delivery, came and said, ""Oh, those pills were delivered to my mailbox, not the back door as I said on the phone a coupl
e of times. "" So, I was very proud that I had not panicked but that, again, that my positive thinking had gotten through my confusion and concern, and turned a panic situation into a solution. That I had solved the problem on my own, using the brain that I have, by switching it to positive by saying, ""Think positive"" before going into the problem. I never thought of myself as a panic person until you wrote that about your family. That's the first time I've even thought of that. I just thought, my adrenalin gets to going to fast, I can't think. But again, my positive thinking l slipped through that and solved the problem. A time when it didn't slip through, I don't drive much and took a daring adventure with my dog to a nearby neighborhood. Like going to the moon for me, all the way to the next neighborhood. And driving. My dog and I took a walk around the block and I can't find the keys to the car. I freaked, and I just a few minutes ago realized this is the panic like you said you family did. I went knock
ing on doors in the dark of complete strangers asking them to take me home to the next neighborhood (with a busy 4-lane in between and I couldn't cross it). One did, I got in my kitchen, calmed down, looked in my top shirt pocket, not my pants pocket, and there were my keys. There was no problem, I just panicked. 175975405,"N., I do hope that your implant device is bringing about relief for you! In answer to your question, I know that the longer you are on a benzodiazepine (daily, not PNR) the harder it is to discontinue. It is always advised to do so with a doctor's supervision if fact. As far as the long term effects...I am not sure besides dependency. For this reason doctors are really scaling back in Rx-ing them. However, I do believe that they are still a valuable tool for panic issues and safe when taken as directed and only when needed during acute episodes. I hope that you are finding yourself in a place of good management currently!! Health and progress be yours! S.C."

175975408,"I almost didn't post that, thinking it was too, ""out there"". Wish I had 5 grand for every time someone told me I was too ""out there"". One of the people who said that was even a 'nam Vet who, ""fell out of (his) hooch and landed on (his) head"". Whenever someone returns one of my ""tennis serves"", it means I can't have left orbit completely, so thanks, salles, you made my day! That line is a heart stick. It pinpoints something omnipresent yet completely overlooked. I used to feel that way ALL the time. Interestingly, my schizoid friend and reading schizoid forums have introduced me to a new way of relating to my inner being, and I almost never feel that emptiness any more. The better I get to know my friend--and he has revealed an enormous amount about himself--the more I realize the way I feel is not and has never been even close to ""normal"". Yet that the way I am is perfectly fine, valid, and can be explored and swum around in like a coral reef. Honestly, I thought most of that article was 
excellent. The only parts I didn't care for were the obligatory, ""It's OK, you're not a freak."", boilerplate. Every psych author must worry that if they don't put that stuff in there, someone's gonna off themselves. However, there's only so many ways in which generic sympathy can be expressed and all have been sat on to the point the foam's lost its bounce. People with enduring psychological problems are WAY beyond the reach of banalities, but that's what teenagers are for--to eat up trends and to accept the banal as profound. It's on them to keep the psych industry afloat. This part surprised me: as it's my situation in a nutshell and I've never before seen it spelled out so bluntly by a professional. IF they have any concrete observations at all, I've found they usually beat around the bush. That specific ""reason"" for parental resentment™ is probably FAR more common than references to it would indicate. Many people never figure out who they are, what they love, or why they are alive. For such ""people
"", the birth of an unwanted child is actually a godsend, providing the perfect lightning rod for the self-loathing they clearly would have felt had they remained child-free. When you're child-free, you're in the chair under the hot lamp 24/365, and that's exactly how long it's gonna take to figure out what you need to do and to get it done."

175975429,"Hi LaoiseD and welcome! I am sorry to hear that you are dealing with such difficult physical symptoms! That sounds like a very frustrating issue...and one that is no doubt affecting your quality of life! I am glad to hear that you are seeing your doctor....simply because this is a good first step in order to confirm and anxiety dx. Also, once you rule out any physical cause...you can talk about a management plan to help you start to feel your best again. Most people find that medication and or therapy...or the combination of both is the way to find relief and recovery/management of the issue. Self help is another tool that everyone should practice as well IMO. You'll find great material for helpful exercises in our Resources at the top of the main forum page here, so be sure to check it out! Keep posting with us as well if you find it helpful. We understand, care and support is key! I will now lock this thread down due to age...so when posting back, just hit the Post New Topic icon and start your o
wn thread. Talk soon, _PERSON_ Cat"
175975430,"Wouldn't empathy be an expression of positive emotions? It may be born of negative ones, but to express it, you need to holster the positive ones. I'm thinking a schizoid's desk would have an overflowing in box and a practically empty out box. Or maybe it's the other way around, only the out box has a padlock on it and there are only a few isolated moments in the day when he remembers the combination. Well, we were in a relationship for almost five years. From when we were seventeen 'till about 22. This was before my PD traits were in full bloom, and I think of those years fondly because I was normal then. I could enjoy going out and the company of others. So in a way my thoughts of him are a memory of that, and a symbol of the hope that maybe one day I can regain some of that normalcy. And while the passing of time makes that seem exponentially more and more unlikely, I still have hope. Not to sound like a greeting card, but hope is a good thing. It's pretty much vital for me, or anyone who has a 
history of suicidal tendencies/idealization. But like I said, my find feelings for him are more about me than him. He's a badge for the fact that I was once less disordered. The fact that I've been able to keep a friend for almost forty years is a trophy more than anything else. You lost me with the second part of that question. If you're talking about appropriation, emotional or otherwise, I'm not sure that applies to schizoids. Most people cull their identities from their environment. Schizoids internalize everything, so even outside influences become uniquely their own, filtered through their sensibilities and then locked away from the world."

175975527,Could that have been a hallucination? I mean if you have the drain plugged with a stopper how would the bugs come up?
175975528,"The woman who wrote the column on being positive when trying to solve a problem, said in paraphrase: 1. Some people are good at solving problems, some aren’t.. 2. Solving problems is not a genetic trait. 3. Steps that can help: 4. Best thing for solving a problem is your attitude, times 10. 5. Think optimistically. If you think you aren’t going to solve the problem, you’re right. If you think you are going to solve the problem, you’re right. So, again, it’s not the problem, it’s what you’re thinking (unconsciously) about the problem going into it. 6. Being a pessimist is not genetic, it’s what we learned as children. 7. Problems often have more than one solution. 8. If you think in advance you’re going to solve the problem, you chances of solving it increase greatly. (Because your unconscious mind is dependent on what you think going into the problem. If you think you’re going to solve the problem your unconscious mind look for ways to do that. If you don’t believe you're goin
g to solve it, your same unconscious mind turns off it’s powers, obeys your childhood mindset of negative and looks for ways to fail.) 9. One step at a time. 10. Ask for help if you need it. Don’t ask for it if you don’t. 11. You’re not going to solve every problem, but you will gain experience. Which will help you with your next problem. 12. And lastly, if you can’t solve the problem, give yourself the same support you would give to any friend. One time, before I read this column, I had a big problem. Let’s say, I was in a dangerous situation in the room where I was. My conscious mind thought, open the door and walk out of the room. My unconscious, which had learned as a child to be negative, piped up with a counter-belief to that. It said, “The door is probably locked. Dive through the window.” I dove through the window (a negative because I got hurt), but I solved the problem because I got out of the room (a positive). This represented my mind (conscious is positive/unconscious is negative)
. I walked over to the door and turn the handle: it was unlocked the entire time. That’s a true story, in generalities. Two years later when I read the column and thought back to that tough situation, I saw my conscious mind at work. I remembered it saying: “open the door and walk out of danger.” I also saw my negative unconscious mind at work: “You can’t open the door and walk out of danger because…… (make up any excuse).” When you think positively before going into the problem that you can solve it, it opens up your unconscious that you can’t see, and your unconscious starts to look for solutions, rather than looking for defeat. If you’re negative unconsciously (and you don’t know because you can’t see it), it takes an actual key (“Think positive, Think positive, Think positive”) to open it. It will do either of those things equally well. But it must be set on positive before you begin looking at the problem. That’s why when thinking about how to get the car out of the back dri
veway, I did not think about getting the car out of the back driveway. I thought first about reading the column on being positive. And before I got to the fourth paragraph, my unconscious said, “_NAME_’s garage has a small wrecker. We’ve used it before.” While I was still consciously reading the column."

Everyday I long for the feeling of the pen in my hand and the catharsis of putting it to paper. Even though it has been over 20 years, I am still struggling to journal. Those detectives stole a large piece of who I am and robbed me of a vital coping mechanism. I even struggle writing papers in school but I still get them done. I feel pressured to perform, so I do. With that said I have decided that I need to approach journaling the same way I approach assignments in school; I will do it because I HAVE TO. While I do not get the same catharsis from typing as I do from writing, this journal entry is a step in my reclamation process. I am determined to take my life back and a crucial piece of who I am is writing. This is my first time using this platform, so I am not sure how this works. I have seen others write a daily affirmation so I will follow suit. Today's affirmation: I deserve 
a good life. I am worthy."

175975645,"Hi Ocean. Sorry to read that you are going through a difficult time. I understand how the issues you are dealing with at home, with your father-in-law, plus pain, plus a prostate cancer diagnosis, could cause you anxiety. Even if you do not have a pre-existing anxiety disorder, these events could cause you what is sometimes referred to as ""situational anxiety"" -- that is, anxiety brought on by specific events or circumstances. I also think there is a risk that various unrelated problems can become or at least seem -- overwhelming, if they occur around the same time. You might feel like you could deal with any one of the issues you are facing, if only the others did not exist at the same time. The answer may be to keep the various problems separate, to the extent possible, and make a plan to deal with them one at a time. With respect to the ""father in law situation,"" I wonder whether some counselling with you and your wife together could help. This might be relatively short term counselling, to 
help you come up with an approach that addresses the situation in way that you are both comfortable with, and that does not cause resentment or later regret. This sort of issue can be divisive and cause discord if it is left to fester. On the other hand, if you are able to find an approach that you are both comfortable with, it could make your marriage stronger. I have experienced vaguely similar marital issues and I found conjoint therapy (me and wife together) quite helpful. With respect to the prostate cancer issue, I see that you have posted on the HW prostate cancer board. There are a lot of very knowledgeable and helpful people on that board. It is a tremendous resource. My father had prostate cancer, and I have a high enough PSA to watch it carefully, so I am somewhat knowledgeable about prostate cancer. You are not alone among people with that diagnosis who have anxiety as a result of it -- especially during the time period when you are going through the process of selecting a treatment. Indeed, I thi
nk that sort of anxiety is the rule rather than the exception among men who are diagnosed with prostate cancer. You might want to see a therapist or a psychiatrist to help you deal with this issue. That might be someone separate from the ""marital therapist"" who helps you and your wife deal with the father in law situation. This person could help you process the feelings that arise from a cancer diagnosis, and if you are so inclined could recommend medication. There are a good number of guys with prostate cancer who take SSRIs or other meds. This may seem like ""a lot of therapy"" - with a marital therapist and a separate individual therapist. But it is what I have done and I do not regret it. Best wishes, my friend. Post Edited (medved) : 1/4/2020 10:05:07 AM (GMT-7)"

Now when the injection wears off, I get quasi-psychosis caused by autism which causes manic like symptoms. Then when it kicks in, my brain doesn't have enough neurotransmitters to BE MYSELF. 175975659,"Lorasplora: You mentioned your general practitioner suggested taking Paxil and Lexotan. By typing in Paxil in the search engine, one of the sites said that it is used for depression and anxiety. When I typed in Lexotan, myvmc.com said that this was a benzodiazepine. It then noted, ""In general, benzodiazepines such as Lexotan should be taken for short periods only (2 to 4 weeks, for example)."" ""Continuous long-term use is not recommended unless advised by your doctor."" ""This medicine may be addictive."" Well, you know, like you did go to a general practitioner. Is there anyway you can go to a psychiatrist? For one thing, your difficulty sleeping may not be the main problem. It may be a sign of a mental illness. In my case, it's not so much that I have trouble sleeping, it's that I have bipolar and I have trouble sleeping. To treat the symptom doesn't treat the main problem, it covers it up. If you get the wrong diagnosis, such as can't sleep, you get the wrong medicine. First, they have to diag
nosis what is the underlying problem. And then give you the right medicine for that. If you go to a psychiatrist, he or she will first want to try to determine if you have an overall mental condition like anxiety or depression. Then they can first give you an anti-depressant or anti-anxiety medicine, then maybe give you something for sleep, or like me, you could perhaps even take something like Melatonin from the health food store for a portion of the sleep problem. You said in your latest post, that Melatonin didn't work for you. I said in my reply that Melatonin wouldn't work for me, either, if I wasn't taking something for my bipolar (Lithium) and for my depression (Mirtazapine). So this indicates you have something more than just a sleep problem, for the Melatonin by itself didn't help you with sleep. As the net said, the benzodiazepines are for the short term. You need something for the long term. Again, can you look up ""psychiatrist for your hometown"" on your computer, or ""mental health or psychiatri
c clinic for your hometown"", which would have a sliding scale all the way down to zero? And set up an appointment? You think you can do that? ."

175975772,Yes I did
175975773,"""Because organizing your thoughts requires a lot of self-control and mindfulness, and because not so many people are actually capable of such a thing. Here are some tips from what I recently started to do in order to stop being a victim of invasive thoughts (a thing I’ve suffered for years and still deal with) : practice a form of activity that does not require you to think and, most of all, that can learn you how to stop thinking. I personnally chose yoga and meditation, because it was not far from home and it happened to be very surprising. The effects on your mind and body appear within 3 to 5 weeks depending on how regularly you practice it. Two times a week was a good start. Our yoga teacher taught us how to, instead of fighting against them, let the thoughts flow in your mind and body. Surprisingly, they vanish by themselves if you let them flow, whereas if you struggle against them, they will keep haunting you again and again, forever. Don’t forget that anyone who is vulnerable because 
of any situation often tends to keep bearing things that are negative for them. So I would suggest you to give this method a shot, if you have time for it of course. practice a form of activity that is properly physical, such as running, swimming, etc. It aims at bringing out some tiredness inside your body and mind, and thus all the thoughts that are difficult to get away from will then again vanish in your mind. Don’t forget that human modern ways of life usually lead to various worries and thoughts that would have nothing to do in the mind of someone who, at the end of the day, is tired enough both physically and mentally to stop thinking with negativity. Since I started to run along the sea 2 to 3 times a week, I feel like invasive thoughts are no longer a significant part of my mind. However, while running or swimming, you must let all your thoughts flow in. It really works. But as I said it, I have time to spend in such activities. last but not least, accept the fact that being able to organize your t
houghts can take a long, long time and persevere even if it doesn’t work immediately. Organizing someone’s thoughts would be comparable to organizing a messy room full of things you wouldn’t have even noticed was existing. It can also make you suffer, because as your “surface thoughts” flow and get away, they will reveal your deeper, intimate thoughts. And absolutely no one can predict what’s hiding here inside even when you think or try to convince yourself everything’s fine. Somedays it can be terrible to endure, but don’t feel discouraged. It is worth the journey. I really hope I’ve helped a little ! Have a nice day, _USER_ID_"""

175975831,"Have you noticed that along with your own diagnosis of Bipolar 1 or Bipolar 2, other symptoms or diagnosed illnesses come along for the ride. These illnesses say, “She does not have quite enough yet on her plate, what with the and all bipolar buiness, let’s add a little more.” Thank you , whoever you are. A comorbid condition can also be known as comorbidity. A lot are psychiatric but a some are medical as well. Regardless, you need to take them into consideration for the management of your own good health. The following is a list of some of the comorbid conditions of bipolar disorder. Substance Abuse Disorders About 60 percent of people with bipolar disorder have a problem with substance abuse. Substance abuse includes the over use of alcohol or the use of drugs, perhaps both. Often times a substance abuse problem will occur to someone who presented bipolar development at a young age. Those who experience mixed episodes and those who have a family history of substance abuse are also a target
TREATMENTS: Doctors stress that is important to treat both bipolar disorder and substance abuse disorders and that can occur in a dual diagnosis recovery program. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/being-bipolar/2019/07/06/comorbid-disorders-with-bipolar-disorder/?li_source=LI&li_medium=popular17"

The only thing I can say I don’t have is, financial security. But I swear to you, for my life anyway, might life is still far better. I’m not saying yours will be the exact same way and idk about anyone else here, but I personally was highly hindered by parents and them wanting things to go their way or what they thought was best for me. And it wasn’t I learned. Of course I still heed their precautions on what I do but I don’t like it hinder me from trying new things or business risks or moving risks etc. It’s been fun being independent!"

175975894,"Working, while living with bipolar disorder, can be a real challenge. Some of us are on disability because our illness disrupts our life so much that we cannot work. Even though we might be deemed disabled, we are still encouraged by Social Security to work. My most recent jobs ended due to my mental illnesses. A few years ago, I was working as a barista at a very busy coffee shop in Nashville. We had a line of customers at all times. I was usually on the register talking to the customer because, let’s be honest, I stunk at making espresso drinks. I was anxious at the job. Soon I was anxious on my way to work. Finally, I was anxious to go before I even left the house. I felt physical symptoms like the urge to throw up. It was like being a barista with stage fright. After a few months, I turned in my resignation. Picked up my last tips and moved on with my life. My next job, in Durham, North _USER_ID_, was at a brand new clothing boutique. During my interview, the owner told me she had goggled me 
and, thus, knew I was mentally ill, specifically with bipolar disorder. She was also a psychologist and had knowledge about mental illness. She asked me whether or not I was up to the task of working at her boutique. I told her I wanted the job and she hired me. My job was to be the lead fashion stylist for the shop – I thought that mainly meant dressing the mannequins and staging the front window, it also meant working the register. Right as I started the job, I was directed to change medications. As many of us will say, medication changes are the worst and with this one came the brain fog. This one made it especially hard for me to grasp how to use the register. For some reason, it was too complicated for my brain to figure out. She tested me once at the register when just she and I were working. I could not figure out the right way to navigate a sale. She “let me go.” She told me that as much as it hurt me, it hurt her more. Right. Do not get me wrong, a lot of people with mental illness work and do 
so successfully. I guess I wanted to share those two bits of information to say, “It is okay to fail or to not be able to do certain tasks or jobs because of our mental illnesses,” as well. There is a lot to consider when working and living with bipolar disorder. Consider the length of your workday and workweek. Is that something you can handle? Remember that some of your medications make you sleepy which could affect your work performance. Find a job that works with your lifestyle and schedule. For me, that is writing. I do it when I can, at times when I can. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/being-bipolar/2019/09/07/working-while-living-with-bipolar-disorder/"

175976015,"Thanks emillionth , that's a really good point. On reflection a lot of my feeling disconnected comes from expectations from others rather than a lack of connection. I feel like I'm expected to feel things or care about things that I just don't. I do feel connected to some people at some times though, particularly when binding over common interests. For example, I love the game where two people list book or tv interests till they find a match, and then recommend new things to each other. I guess I just assume that if I didn't make an effort, I'd start by feeling relaxed and comfortable, but I'd eventually become lonely and start obsessing over what I was missing out on. 175976094,"Typically, we like to leave inactive threads alone and just start a new thread instead. This is different than how some forums are run, but we do it this way because it frequently upsets users to have old topics revived when they are no longer relevant. It can also be frustrating to the person who revived the thread when they don’t get a reply, because the original poster is no longer active or no longer finds the topic relevant. Feel free to start a new thread on this topic. Thanks, Volunteer Moderator _AT_MENTION_"

175976123,"I'm trying to figure out how to download a meditation track from an app on a really old iPhone. I don't do iPhones anymore and that app is no longer available even if I did. Oh Google, what did I ever do without you? Once I was stuck and I changed a flat tire on my own because Google was there to show me how. Google wasn't there (at least not in the form of a smartphone internet app) when I was learning how to drive though. I shredded the rubber off a tire because it went flat and I had been driving on the rim without knowing what was going on. The car was vibrating so hard and making thumping sounds - it was disorienting and scary - what rough and callous payment I thought myself to be driving along Google wasn't by my side when I was learning how to handle a stick shift either. I would have my window rolled down and I'd yell at people who looked like they were going to get in my way to watch out as I went around corners because I was still too afraid to switch gears. Many years ago my friend gave 
me a giant (non-crack) rock as a gift to keep in my car. He later told me it was incase I went off the road into a body of water while he was in the vehicle with me (to break a window to swim out) ^ In the past, other friends said that I should line - any car I drive - with tires, so that it becomes a makeshift bumper car. I never decided if I was offended or enthralled by how fun that could be. I'm afraid to drive trucks because they're so big to try to take on, but I don't know how to blame Google for this. Google can't solve everything - even if he's right beside you: I was in a parking lot about to pull out of my spot and some guy stepped out into the lot in front on me. I put on my brakes and he stopped at the same time. We both laughed and beckoned the other to move. I waited for him to move, but he didn't, so I decided to go. He moved at the same time as I pressed my gas pedal which made it appear like I had just lurched towards him. I braked hard as he stopped. He looked at me beseechingly as if askin
g if I was trying to hurt him. I winced and laughed and mouthed ""sorry."" Relief pass across his face and we both paused again. He didn't do anything, so once again, I pressed my gas pedal to go. Unfortunately it coincided with him stepping forward. Again. By the end of our encounter, he had no trust left in his eyes, planted there like a vulnerable blade of grass on an island of pavement. My embarrassment and the humor of the situation had me giggling away. At that point, he appeared to be frozen in trepidation of the person who, not only drove towards him every time he tried to move, but who was now openly laughing about it. He was no longer smiling, No longer willing to accept my apologies or even move. I drove away a bit disheartened that I couldn't convince him that I wasn't trying to hurt him."

175976127,"Hello, my user name is _PERSON_, I am a registered nurse and a baccalaureate nursing student. I am interested in learning more about your experiences with anxiety/panic, and even depression. I was suppose to do a community project but Corona came and I had to cancel my plans. My teacher is willing to let us do an online project. My project is based on anxiety/panic, depression, early intervention, and prevention of lifelong illness.I recently learned about ACE's (Adverse Childhood Experiences), and that made me really think about my own life and how I became who I am. https://youtu.be/95ovIJ3dsNk I have several family members who have anxiety/panic, and depression. I have also developed anxiety over my lifetime, but I didnt know thats what was wrong with me. As a young person I suffered several traumatic events that lead to PTSD or whatever this is. I find my way of coping is to plan, list, overthink. I always thought this was a positive, proactive, taking the bull by the horns. I would analyze eve
rything from several vantage points, only acting when it was a sound choice. Maybe this was healthy. However, as I get older, my kids get older, problems get bigger and bigger. Coping is smaller and quieter. I have worked with a therapist for several years. Initially it was to help me support my child. But... after about 6-8 months I realized it was ME, I was the problem. So my question for the community is did you know you had anxiety, panic, or depression, or did you discover it later on? How did you get diagnosed? What could have happened as young person to better serve you? Did you feel there were enough providers, or did you go through many before someone understood what was wrong? Over time did you feel like they were still helpful, that they helped as much as they could and you took a break, or did you not go into therapy, and why? How could the community of providers/offices have done better? What about family, how could they have understood better? Any specific experience with someone who was spot on 
and was very helpful, understanding, supportive? What were the things that stood in the way from getting help or being helped? I had been to several therapists in the past who were not helpful at all. Early on this was not something paid for by insurance so access was very limited. And while insurance has come a long way, there is still a long way to go as far as payments, providers accepting insurance, etc. Luckily I found an amazing therapist who i have seen for years, taken a break when things got a little too deep, and went back to 3-4 times. Im on a break right now, and even though I need to see her I cant because of this virus. Im going to just keep going to work, working on school, taking care of me and my family, and taking time for myself as often as I can. I hope you are all well and have someone who is willing to suffer through this with you. That is probably the best thing we can hope for in life. Thanks for reading, and thanks in advance to anyone willing to share their story. VioMin."

175976134,"_PERSON_, a lot of doctors who can't look at you and diagnose you in their pre-determined medical book of diaganoises will say you're fine, and tell you to just get used to it or take antidepressants. For me and _PERSON_, and others I've spoken too, we never took antidepressants. So, while not entirely impossible to be YOUR cause, it wasn't ours. I will say, you should get off of anti-depressants with a set guideline to do so from your doctor. They're destructive and many have bad side effects and/or worsening of problems. Consider _NAME_ for a natural alternative for getting depression under-control. There's other options out there as well, for energy production and keeping your mind calm which all helps keep you well. Sadly, there's a lot of issues in the brain we can't see. MRI's are still incapable of going to a deep enough level to truly show everything. It's likely a brain problem, but that also means there can be a solution and coping through the brain. By not focusing on it, and negatively 
reacting to it, over a long period of time it does get better. It took me over a year, so it's not quick. Especially if you already suffer from anxiety and depression. Finding things that bring you joy, keeping yourself occupied and busy, are good ways to push through. Your mind is capable of ignoring things it doesn't find interesting or a threat. When we make it a threat, your mind will focus on it and you will get stuck in that cycle. It would be great if we could find a Neuro-otologist or Neurologist who CARED enough to involve themselves into this issue, but finding one who has the resources and expertise is difficult to find. 12345"

175976148,"OK, no history of dizziness. No history of anxiety, but yet you say you are anxious. Do you think your anxiousness caused your dizzy spell, as in psychosomatic? What do think your diagnosis is? Healthline.com says symptoms of anxiety disorder are: nervousness, restlessness, or being tense; feelings of danger, panic, or dread; rapid heart rate; rapid breathing, or hyperventilation; increased or heavy sweating trembling or muscle twitching; weakness and lethargy; difficulty focusing or thinking clearly about anything other than the thing you’re worried about ; insomnia; digestive or gastrointestinal problems, such as gas, constipation, or diarrhea; a strong desire to avoid the things that trigger your anxiety; obsessions about certain ideas, a sign of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD); performing certain behaviors over and over again; anxiety surrounding a particular life event or experience that has occurred in the past, especially indicative of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Is this wha
t you have?"

174369762,"Antipsychotics decrease connectivity in the brain to allow psychosis to decrease (Along with everything else - Which sucks) but as time goes on, neurogenesis happens (Especially if you're under 25) to cause a crystalized contact with reality. Withdrawal of the antipsychotics increase connectivity in the brain to more than it was before you started them, worsening psychosis (Withdrawal psychosis) so neuroplasticity happens to make the psychosis a more crystalized psychosis so when you start the antipsychotic again, it's less likely that the antipsychotic will work. If you use a psychedelic while in antipsychotic withdrawal, it causes neuroplasticity AND neurogenesis to a previously crystalized state of psychosis, causing irreversible psychosis and schizophrenia."

175976182,"RAD kids are often mistaken as psychopathic kids. I believe it's a cop out. Look at the 90's _NAME_ ""Child of Rage"" interviews on YouTube (not the acting movie, the interviews). By 6 years old, she was trying to kill her foster parents on a regular basis, sexually harming herself until needing to go to the hospital to treat the wounds, sexually and physically harming her baby brother and killing and torturing animals, etc. She was even playing with the fear she instilled in them. She talks about it completely non-chalantly too. People keep referring to her as psychopathic, but her real diagnosis was Reactive Attachment Disorder. She received and responded to treatment. Now as an adult, she's trained to work with kids with as severe RAD as she had. * To note: the person who she went to do her live-in treatment with, went on to develop ###$ up treatments and was later charged for murder because she and someone else suffocated some poor child during a ""rebirthing"" technique. Severe physical neglec
t with infants can cause physical developmental delays or permanent problems and a lack of emotional and intellectual stimulation can do the same on the brain's structural development. We aren't born with fully developed brains, and some theories assert our environments dictate a fair amount of its development (though I believe neuroplasticity is a beautiful thing and full of undiscovered potential). I don't know how neglect impacts structures like the _USER_ID_ (trauma does though), but the frontal lobe is definitely affected. My brief understanding of psychopathy is that it's being seen as a developmental disorder, so the biggest difference would be the (supposedly) inherent brain structural abnormalities and thus, not requiring RAD's prerequisites of neglect and maltreatment. However, I'm certain there's some significant overlap there too; example: most psychopathic serial killers have been very badly abused. I'm guessing ""pre-psychopathic"" would be through the lens of the Diathesis Stress Model, so the 
genetics are already there but things like environment will determine whether and how it manifests itself. https://dictionary.apa.org/diathesis-stress-model Any kid in a #######5 environment learns to read people well. RAD kids are the ones who learn it almost as if it's their first language. They have the potential of reading people so well (off of seemingly no information at all) that you'd think think they were psychic. Yet, they remain completely unreadable themselves at the same time and they tend to have the emotional detachment to go with it, so they'll capitalize off it quite well. They can have major charisma, charm, ""hustle,"" and the best street smarts you'll ever see. My fascination is not in disorder or psychopathy or even trauma, but rather by being deeply bothered by society's double standards in choosing who they write off and then bitching and complaining when it blows up in their faces. Even more so, my interest is in the incredible and unique skills that could be invested in - along with w
ondering what skills would be helpful and how to present them in a way that would be most appealing and effective to learn. Lolz. You'll notice I always bring conversations back to my interest in the matter."

175976245,"Hi WearyRA, Your post is just heartbreaking. I have read your messages and I know how horrible your last few years have been. All of life has a way of just beating us down. I think us older folks seem to know this much better than the younger generation. When we are younger we have more fight in us and are able to bounce back quicker. I know for myself I just don't have that ability any longer. Losing a child is such a terrible loss. It is unnatural for a parent to outlive their child. I grieve for you. I will certainly say a prayer for you. As for your new job--I know starting anything new is hard. I have gone through this many times myself. I have had sleepless nights before just changing locations within the same company. Those of us who suffer anxiety know how hard new things can be. It also sounds as if the person who is training you really is not interested in doing this. People can be so mean and unhelpful. I know this will be hard but please try to relax. I know its easier said than done. I 
am retired and so thankful I don't have to deal with stressful work and people who are only out to make themselves look better at the expense of others. Lastly I know how you feel about taking your meds namely Xanax. I used to be the same way about my pain meds. I didn't want to become addicted. I hated the _USER_ID_ attached to taking opiates. My own family would look down on me. In the end I took the meds and they have helped me so much. I will continue to take whatever will help me cope with life and take my chronic pain away. We are the ones living in our bodies. Please do what will make you feel better about yourself. My prayers and thoughts are with you. Bless you."

175976282,"My therapist lent it to me. Like most interactive/self-help books, it is not applicable to the way I think or live. I have to translate. But there are occasional nuggets of unintentional wisdom that I have been transcribing into a tiny notebook. Separated from their original context, they hold more weight, as the book is set up like a 12-step program. At the author's suggestion, I have replaced ""higher power"" with something more tangible, however I have been having difficulty inserting phrases like ""fried beef _USER_ID_"" or ""small, overly clingy carnivorous mammal"" into most sentences. FAQ? Fart Atop Queen? Facinorous Armed Queer? It used to be easy. Now it's nerve-wracking. I'm thinking about utilizing ambient temperature: impossible to paint in the winter as it's so cold in here the paper never dries. When my apartment reaches my comfort level, say 90º, it may get interesting. I've been wanting to do more abstract ideas, but that's taking a lot of trial and error. Most of the time it ends 
up looking like a used placemat. There probably is. Some kind of dissociation. I just call it zoning out. It's like a bad habit. The more you allow it to happen, the more it sneaks up on you. I paste notes to myself all over the apartment that say things like ""Be Present!"" ""Cognize!"" https://youtu.be/FxZUrWkWZpE?t=2982 #toolate As someone who experienced what I call minimal parenting (this extended to material items as well: ""Mom, buy me this record?"" ""Why don't you just use your tape recorder and record it off the radio?"") I never understood material minimalism. I like stuff. I want stuff. I pilfer small, useless items from my clients (""whoa. these people have too many steak knives. I'll fix that!"") At last we disagree: hoarded ideas and plans (read: goals) keep me going and assures me that the future is more than an inevitable void. btw, from where I stand, your contributions here have been frequently constructive and always enjoyable. True, but I myself am comfortable with the illusion of legacy. 
Let them forget. I won't know. I'll be dead."

175976370,"Loners isolate by choice. Schizoids isolate because not to do so would cause stress and discomfort. These people are either sociopathic or psychotic. The news media carelessly applies the 'loner' term because they seem to be conditioned to. Headlines and news bites must be simple and brief. Pulling off a mass shooting would probably entail too much social interaction/exposure for a schizoid to bother. Mostly disinterest, although that disinterest is a camouflage for anxiety. Perhaps feeling disinterest is a way to avoid that anxiety. Also, social interaction involves a good deal of give-and-take. By give, I mean sharing of and exposing myself to others. I prefer to keep my secrets to myself, and by secrets, I mean just about anything I am thinking/feeling. By sharing, I risk contaminating my inner world with the ugly banality of the outside world. Also, getting back to disinterest, I find most people aren't worthy of hearing what I have to say or think. I feel no need to disclose anything about mys
elf to someone I have no interest in communicating with, ever. Yet when I meet people who I find interesting or worthy of my interest, it's still not easy to share with them. It's like intense shyness but without self-doubt or fear."

I thought that was just laziness. I was bullied my mean women at my part time job for over 6 months. It was constant indirect harassment. I left and the one woman stalked me to the other job. She trashed me to all the surrounding businesses. People I didn’t even know were talking about me. She posted something about me on the internet which I don’t even know how to find. 175976388,"_AT_MENTION_ and _AT_MENTION_, I think that you are both right, and if I add your answers, I could solve the problem... thanks! On one hand, it's true that I don't trust my intuition enough, and that I should increase my self-esteem about social exchanges; on the other hand, objectively I need to know others' feelings and emotional needs, if I wish to bound. I can agree or disagree with their pov, but their sensitivity and way of being deserve respect - and if I wish their friendship, I esteem them. If they need more tact, privacy, or disinhibition,.. there isn't an objective meter for these things. It's not binary: I am wrong, or you are wrong. All that suggests me this solution: I shouldn't pose my question as a doubt about myself (indirectly calling for criticism), but as a clarification about one's needs and feelings! Instead of: “was I inopportune?”, I could ask: “would you need more privacy in these situations?”. It could work: people wouldn't fear to hurt me and would answer sincerel
y. I would have my feedback, and the exchange would increase my self- esteem in dealing with people and situations, without a self-destructive attitude."

174370129,"Wishy-washy. I have none of the light green traits (or maybe ""half"" of one of those), most of the dark green ones, and most of the brown ones. I don't live what people would usually call ""a normal life"" (well... except for these days, when my lifestyle is the norm ) and I'm only very marginally integrated in society. But I'm able to live independently, I'm content with my life, and I consider myself lucky even on bad days (because I know bad days are temporary). I'm yet to hear of someone with AvPD who would say the same. To be fair, I guess the word ""severity"" is very often used to mean ""degree of inability to integrate into society"". But that's because psychology in practice tends to be more concerned with making people ""productive"" rather than ""happy"". Those two things don't always align. So that usage of the word is deceptive. Yes, and I think that's what's most wishy-washy about it. SPD can be seen as ""in between"" AvPD and StPD in many ways, yes, but that's just because the conce
pt of SPD in itself is wishy-washy, so it ends up applying to different things that only look similar. AvPD and StPD aren't degrees of the same thing. StPD is very literally a less severe variant of schizophrenia. It can be complicated or alleviated by someone's upbringing or life circumstances, but it's highly genetic."

175976460,"Greetings folks. I used to post in another depression forum under the same _NAME_ but for some reason, find myself wading in unchartered territory now... Just a little history about me and my wife... My wife and I were first married in 2008. Then in around 2015, a church counsellor diagnosed her with depression(that made me sign up at a depression forum to know more) and also around the same time, she abandoned me. It was a whirlwind few months and before I knew it, my wife filed for divorce. At that time, I was unaware about her mental illness and thought she no longer loved me, so I agreed to it... : _ ( Many months later, while I was away at Army Reservist, she called me out of the blue, saying that she had been warded at IMH (Institute of Mental Health, in Singapore) for 30 days and had been diagnosed with Bipolar Disorder. That was how everything started to make sense. To cut the long story short, we reconciled and remarried in 2017. She was formerly on Olanzopin and Valproate (mood stabiliser 
I think), but due to her concerns with her weight gain, we discussed with the IMH doctor and the Olanzopin was slowly reduced to 0. And she managed fine with just the Valproate for at least almost a year. A few days ago (and over the course of a few days developing), she started to have mood changes, being suddenly energetic, suddenly lethargic, having impaired judgment, hearing voices, not sleeping at all for a few days, grand ideas about getting a new place and applying for new jobs, not being able to focus (blank stare), withdrawing from me and our activities totally, fingers twitching every few seconds, suddenly bursting into tears, irrational fear of dust mites and seeing black shadows in the room. PHEW I think that's about it. So again to cut the long story short, she abandoned me (again) 2 mornings ago at around 8am and I panicked a little when I found out after waking up. Went to NEX Shopping Mall to search for her all over as she said the night before that she would be there at McDonald's. Couldn't f
ind her there or anywhere. Called IMH A&E and IMH Crisis Hotline to enquire for advice. Received it. So yesterday, after she DID NOT return home, I filed a 'missing person' report at the police station. I'm now waiting and hoping for her mania or hypomania or depression to end and return home...so that I can quickly call for the ambulance and send her straight to IMH for assessment. I'm worried and anxious about a few things...namely her safety and well-being and longer-term, her perhaps filing for divorce again months down the road. : _ ( I love my wife a lot and unconditionally. She's my soul-mate and the love of my life. I'm a Christian and have faith in God, so I keep referring to this verse: ""4 Love is patient, love is kind. It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not proud. 5 It does not dishonour others, it is not self-seeking, it is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs. 6 Love does not delight in evil but rejoices with the truth. 7 It always protects, always trusts, always hopes, alway
s perseveres. 8 Love never fails."" Some people (like my mother) have asked me to give up and move on but I vehemently refuse. It's very selfish thinking. I will love my wife till the day I die, for better or for worse, in sickness and in health. If there is any man or woman out there in my predicament, take heart in the knowledge that you are not alone and I am struggling alongside you. I've read myriad posts about how so many caregivers want to give up, or file for divorce, or say that it will keep happening again and again so better bail out quickly. Well, I know what I'm in for but "" I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me"". This may sound obscure or absurd to non-Christians but it's part of what keeps me going...I'm sure you, the reader, have your own coping mechanism... I would like to hear any opinions or suggestions you have regarding my predicament. And please do not put me down and ask me to give up...if you have to do so, please try to do it in a constructive way; thanks very much a
nd I truly appreciate all your insights... Some questions: 1. How often does your Bipolar spouse return after leaving? How long does his/her mania state last? 2. Should I stop contacting her totally, or continue to sporadically message her once or twice a day (which I have been doing). I don't want to pressure her too much, and yet I want her to know that I'm there for her. 3. Do you feel like life is less stressful now that they have moved away, but feel guilty about it? 4. What do you do to take care of yourself while waiting interminably...? 5. If in the event she files for divorce again, what can I do to delay it this time? Or please feel free to share any insights or experiences; thanks! _PERSON_ from Singapore. Post Edited (_PERSON_) : 5/21/2019 12:55:31 PM (GMT-6)"
