175976480,"Hello all. I am desperate to seek answers any where I can as I’ve been racking my brain for a really long time wondering if it’s possible that some people with depression and anxiety just can’t be fixed. When I was a teenager I suffered horrible depression out of no where. I ended up in and out of mental hospitals. Definitely the worst years of my life. I finally found the right mix of medications and was in a really good point in my life and I never looked back. Fast forward to a few years ago my depression hit me out of nowhere again and my life is falling apart and it just seems to keep getting worse. I’m a migraine sufferer as well with no relief so I live in constant pain every day. I know that plays a huge role. I constantly don’t feel good my anxiety never leaves. I wanted more than anything to be a mother I struggled for two years and finally got the most beautiful daughter and now I can’t even take care of myself let alone her. I feel like such a failure. I’ve tried every med
ication for depression and anxiety there is out there and I’ve had no luck. Ones that have helped in the past just don’t work for me anymore. I do keep trying new ones but the Side effects are brutal and the withdrawals are even worse I feel like a lab rat I don’t wanna try anymore just to see if it’s gonna make me feel worse or not. I do believe in my heart of hearts that some people just can’t be helped that they have a chemical imbalance and no medication can fix that. I keep telling my husband and my family I can’t live like this anymore it’s not that I don’t want to be alive it’s that living in constant agony every day is not living i’m just existing. I have a psychiatrist and a therapist and they seem to be of no help. Doctors constantly tell me because I’m such a tough case they don’t know what else to do for me and give up so I don’t know why I should have hope if they don’t have hope for me. I just wanna feel better again and live a normal life. I’m not sure if thats pos
sible anymore. I feel alone, so scared and so helpless. Any advice would be greatly appreciated. I want so desperately to feel better again."

175976530,"Omelets are super easy to make, you start by mixing up your egg in a bowl like you do for scrambled eggs, add your veggies, and meats to it in small pieces, and pour it into a small skillet with plenty of butter melting in the pan. (you can use any size skillet though!). Let it cook for just a minute or two and then, add cheese to one side. Use a spatula to fold the non cheese side over the cheese side. It should look like any folded circle. Be careful how much longer you cook it. Cook until the inside is less runny. Then slide it into your plate or bowl! You can sprinkle it with parmesan cheese, or anything else you like."

175976609,"If it causes anxiety and the normal grooming does not work, it can. I am not really familiar with the concept. It would be part of it, but there is another way to look at it. Its just that people have a pre-moral filter, that filter out things automatically from consciousness, and I say moral in a very general way, but oddities are filtered out from people's consciousness automatically. If you don't have that filter, you deal with more information, so may come to different conclusions. Some things simply have to be denied in order to function in society, even if it is right there in front of you. And that is often where conspiracy theories start, an odd thing that cannot be explained in the appropriate narrative. So taking that thing into account would be inappropriate. That goes also for inappropriate connections. Just taking one example of aliens. it is a word used in normal speech to describe some people, but is also used in sci-fi. Mixing up the two would be inappropriate, yet this is what can 
happen, and writers do that often. People don't have a problem with it if it is in a kind of religious setting, like watching a movie, but outside of that setting, it is inappropriate. So people get confused, and end up having to reject one of the meaning, and they choose whatever fits them better. Psychiatrists tend to reject the normal meaning, normal people would tend towards the opposite. I think there is more to it than that, from what I read. Otherwise, it would only be logical mistakes that could be solved easily through cognitive therapy. Besides, people make those type of mistakes all the time, and it is not a problem, as long as it is an accepted mistake in the subculture. That is why there is a moral thing going on here. Part of it is also to think in stereotypes, which again are inappropriate in most circumstances, unless hidden or obfuscated and padded and flowered in poetry so people are not sure of the meaning. Again, it is a moral thing, which the greys will denounce as lacking in nuances. Rig
ht, that is how it will show. It can be done voluntarily. If you loose control or go too far, it can look like word salad, and can be as well if you loose logic entirely. Like if there is too much information or emotions, it can be impossible to tie up entirely and freeze for primate consumption. Its part of it, and yes, it is a bit like we are doing. And yes, I let myself go more than I would usually, since you seem perceptive. Its like a starving polar bear out of water. I don't mind, it has to be done sometimes, to save humanity. Its part of it. That's also true. There's a balance somewhere that is not easy to achieve."

175976621,"A couple months back I was numb and angry. I found a self help book ""feeling Good, the new mood therapy"" by _NAME_. I started reading about my self-defeating thoughts. How often I told my self: there is no point in doing anything. I don't have the energy. I am bored, tired, i have no life. Or self defeating action: I'll just stay in bed or on the sofa, avoid activities or people. I know with cov-19 we can't minge much. These type of thoughts just make you feel worse. Count the times you say these things to yourself per day. Recognize you are having these type of thought. Catch yourself and tell yourself something good about your life or make some plans, start a new hobbie. Organize your closet, what would you want to do when we all get out of quarantine. Keep your thoughts on the positive and it can help with depression. It did me. Good luck!"

175976645,"Long post ahead but I'm lost and don't know what to do. I've been dealing with chronic insomnia for decades. As I get older (just turned 58), the insomnia has really become unbearable. On a good night, I get maybe four or five hours of sleep and I can function pretty well throughout the day. But there are many bad nights when I get little to NO sleep at all. The days following those nights are unbearable. So about six months ago, I convinced my PCM to let me try some sleeping pills. I was prescribed with Lunexa - 3mg, daily. But as is well known, the Lunexa worked fine initially but as my tolerance to the drug built up my insomnia returned. Lately, there have been nights when I've taken 3, 4 or even 6mg of Lunexa and it had no effect on me. The lack of sleep has made me a very unhappy person to be around. I snap at the slightest things. One recent event: I took a trip to New _USER_ID_ to visit friends in a cancer support group I belong to. When I got to my destination, I went to the car rental coun
ter where I had reserved a car. When I got to the counter, there was no car. Although the guy behind the counter tried to help, I went ballistic. I was screaming and yelling, I was making a scene, etc. My wife was scared, she thought I was going to get arrested. I've always had a 'bad temper' but this was a nightmare. Reflecting on it now, I can't believe I was like that. So almost two weeks ago, I stopped the taking the Lunexa and I went back to see my doctor looking for help. The Lunesta was no longer working and my insomnia was taking a toll not only on me, but those around me. After filling out questionnaires asking me my medical history and talking with the doc for a bit, the doctor felt I had the classic signs of mild depression and generalized anxiety disorder. Accordingly, I've been prescribed bupropion, 150 mg each morning, along with 100mg of trazodone, which I am to take each night to help me sleep. In addition to the trazodone at bedtime, I am also taking 1.5mg of melatonin ('Midnite' sleep aid, a
lso contains lemon balm, chamomile and lavender) as well as some CBD tincture that I picked up at my local dispensary (one eye-dropper full under the tongue at bedtime). You would think with the trazodone, melatonin, and CBD tincture that I should easily fall asleep when i head to bed at 10:00 p.m. each night. But, nope, I rarely even feel drowsy. I cannot understand how nothing seems to help. I've been using an app on my phone to track my sleep. Here's what I've been dealing with for the past week: Nov 9 - 3 hours of sleep Nov 10 - 4 hours of sleep Nov 11 - 4.5 hours of sleep Nov 12 - 40 minutes of sleep Nov 13 - 4.5 hours of sleep Nov 14 - 2 hours of sleep I am unable to concentrate or focus at work. I'm a software engineer / computer programmer by trade so this is not good. Additionally, I have to drive to the office two days a week, 1.5 hours each way. Today while driving to work, I felt uncomfortable and unsafe. I'm worried that I'm going to get into an accident and hurt myself or others. I don't know wh
at to do. I know these drugs can take several weeks in order to start working but shouldn't I feel at least something by now?. I'm approaching two weeks on these drugs and so far I am not feeling any therapeutic effects. None. I don't know how much longer I can keep this up. _NAME_ - Colorado Springs, CO"

175976693,"Without knowing the details, I would say even if your mom appears to be trying to move on, you won't know until you sit down and talk to her and ask her how she is feeling and confess that you are still feeling plagued by guilt and unable to move on. 174370465,So you don’t really want to say much about delusions at all because they aren’t logical. You definitely don’t want to say anything that would make him believe you also believe the delusions. That can make the delusions worse. As far as cancelling could be so many things...a lot of people with sz are lacking in motivation or just don’t feel good that night. A lot of people in general have anxiety in social situations which can make going out anything but relaxing. Another possibility is adhd like symptoms.....I didn’t have adhd until I got psychosis and I’m not sure if it’s from the illness or the meds. Thing is we all have a range of symptoms and none of us have the same ones due to additional illness....some people also have ocd etc....it just seems to be really common to have additional illnesses with psychosis and sz.

175976720,"Preparing for meetings is very important, clearly. I, too, had a high-pressured job, indeed career (now retired), so I spent hours reading and writing before a meeting when I was ""up."" Having said that, however, no one can possibly anticipate all the questions that may be asked or withstand a barrage of criticisms. If that's how these meetings with your boss make you feel, then that's a failure of leadership. What I hope you can do is listen respectfully to all comments and questions, breathe, and then answer to the best of your ability. And don't be afraid to say, ""I don't know, I'll have to get back to you on that."" And then remember to follow up. You are not a walking encyclopedia. Be gracious but clear in what you know and don't know. You can even pay a compliment: ""That's a good question (or insight). I'd like to think more about that and get back to you."" There's no ticking time bomb for when you need to respond. At the same time, you may indeed find yourself under more pressure than is 
good for you or working under a boss that is unrelenting and over-demanding. Sometimes it is best to know when it's time to make a change. I agree therapy is key now to help you deal with the spikes in anxiety and to perhaps take medication to help you regulate. But I hope the more you take possession of what you can and can't give on the spot, in real time, the more you'll feel in some control and therefore less anxious. I feel for you. I'm happy, after 45 years, to be out of the pressure cooker...though my retirement coincided with the pandemic. Not too great, either!"

175976725,"Hi alohaknown, Sorry to hear about what you are going through. Anxiety can be compared to a battle that takes place in the mind, and perseverance is vital. Here is a thought that you might be able to relate to and a suggestion that might help: Rather than a single, mountainous problem, it is often the accumulation of small, seemingly insignificant distresses that induces panic—much like the way running too many individual electrical appliances on the same circuit can blow a fuse. One solution is to write down each problem on an index card and arrange them from the simplest problem to the most difficult. Tackle them one at a time. Writing out your distresses changes their makeup from what you fear and avoid to what you can see and resolve. Keeping you in my thoughts and prayers."

175976727,"I think sometimes as things go well in life we start getting scared that something is about to go wrong. We’re scared we are going to lose our peaceful life, the things we hold dear will disappear and thus our phobias and our disorders wake up seemingly out of nowhere. I, like you, have a wonderful family, no kids, but an amazing and supportive husband and great parents in law, brother and sister in law. It feels like everything should be good, I should be thankful for my life and yes I am thankful. But fears creep in, fear that I will lose the joy I have, that the things and people I hold so dear will get hurt or just disappear suddenly. I know, those fears are illogical at first sight. But, there is always a reason, it could be hidden. I realized I’m so dependent on my family, and they don’t mind. And if I don’t start acting more independently I feel my own character is going to get erased. I’m too vulnerable on my own, and so I started getting anxiety and depression. It is good that yo
u know what is happening to you. It’s good to catch those things before they get out of hand. My mum suffered from an awful debilitating agoraphobia. She was unable to leave the house for 2 years. But she was an old lady. You are still young, you’re strong, and I do believe you will get better. I wish the best for your family, for your kids. Don’t be scared. Phobias can be treated!"

175976918,"I'm not addicted to alprazolam whenever it wears off (Which is why people take it 3-4 times a day), - I'm dependent on the background tolerance (It's half life) so every 3-4 days, I'll take one. Add the flour, yeast, and salt to a large bowl and mix together. 2. In a separate bowl dissolve the honey in the warm water then pour the honey water into the flour mixture. 3. Add the spices and the oil to the mixture. Using a spoon, mix the ingredients thoroughly to create a sticky dough. 4. Line a 9 x 5 inch loaf pan with parchment paper. Transfer the dough to the pan and cover for 20 minutes to let rise. 5. Preheat the oven to 390 degrees F. Uncover and bake for 40 minutes. Serve warm. Enjoy!"

Some I really thought were helping and then others made me absolutely crazy. With mental illnesses you have to go along with the medicine guessing game until you find the one that works for you. up. Try to keep yourself busy if your unable to do so atleast try to keep you mind. Being the adept _USER_ID_ I am, along with trying to decipher his odd behavior, I suspiciously appraised the dark thickly rubbered gloved hand and searched for ribbing or any other bells and whistles (reminded me of a meme) - and then made a mental note to decrease the amount of time I look at weird stuff. I also noted to myself that a doctor asking to shake hands felt like a bit of a strange request in times like these. nkled into a friendly smile as I reached my hand towards his. 175977120,"So many different covers of this song Sweet Dreams - _NAME_ Perhaps I'm regressing since I seem to be transitioning backwards to older tool and from there, to older _NAME_ manson like the following from the Antichrist Superstar album Tourniquet - _NAME_ That old cabin I lived in, had a mural on the wall in different shades of blue and white that one of the previous tenants painted. I'd listen to tool's opiate ep and undertow and this album while smoking and drawing for hours and hours. These last few days, I've really felt like drawing. I've even pulled out my drawing stuff, but I don't know if it'll happen - creativity is like being possessed for me; it's rarely a choice The last time I attempted to ""draw"" was on a few of the glass beads I used to lampwork. You melt the bead and then use a really thin rod of glass near the torch to ""draw"" with it (melt it) onto your bead. One time, I caught my hair on fire. Another time, I managed to burn my lip and went to 12 Step meetings looking like I had 
a crack pipe burn on it which got me some concerned looks from people with whom I was aquianted. Anyways, on the topic of symbolism mentioned in the other thread, what I practiced drawing, were eyes for some reason. For drawing inspiration, I looked up Evil Eye - which online tends to be considered synonymous with the Eye of Horus - except in reality, the eye of horus was drawn for protection against ill intent / the ""evil eye"" Later down the road, I finally observed that people draw it in two directions and I wondered about the difference from a symbolic perspective. I learned that symbolically one side is the eye of horus and on the other side is the Eye of Ra, and I discovered I've always drawn the eye of ra on my beads. Both were believed to be protective - except the eye of horus is the receptive, feminine which was used with the hope of absorbing/neutralizing the ill intent (the ""evil eye"") Whilst the Eye of Ra (which I'd never heard of until then), was the projective, masculine aspect. Which makes 
sense since Thoth was the Egyptian version of Hermes, I think - and Hermeticism dictates that there's both gender and polarity in things. I transfer it into humans; that we're all comprised of and capable of both ""good"" and ""evil;"" however, I respect that many other individuals disagree, and I acknowledge that I may be abstracting the aforementioned concept to suit my liking. Unlike its benign counterpart, the eye of ra was drawn in hope of violently sending that ill intention (""evil eye"") back onto the original person like a ""curse."" That being said, I'm a type of Christian, so I prefer to avoid drawing symbols altogether these days - but they're certainly pretty to look at! Lol. I also have the ""I Want a Hippopotamus for Christmas"" song in my head. I don't think I want one though. I would love an Alligator, a Goliath Taranula and a pretty Pink and Black one too, one of those dinosaur style Shoebilled Storks and a Cobra (sadly these last two eat snakes, so I could never), an Armadillo, an outdoor P
ink Flamingo, a Black Tiger Snake (if it's not canabalistic), a Boelen's Python, a Boa Constrictor... I'd also like to meet a Giraffe. Why can't I stop procrastinating?"

175977150,"Haha I figured it might have been you. Likewise! I forgot to add this one to my previous post. Not a movie or TV series, but it kinda feels like one in some ways, except it's better: Night in the Woods. It's a really good game. It's not for everyone, but it is very much for people who struggle with aimlessness, purposelessness and being chronically out of place. It changed my general perspective on life in some permanent and significant ways. It's funny that while most reviews praise the game, they all say that ""the main character is very hard to sympathize with or relate to"", but to me the game was so significant exactly because of all the major ways how I did see myself in her. I've seen people dismissing it as ""cutesy"", but it's really not. It's about mental illness, alienation and social decay, and it makes it abundantly clear that it's about those things. One of my favorite parts, kinda sums it all up: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w1SmUTFZajA"

175977199,"Jered, I had long periods of deep self-hatred over my lifetime. What I learned is to let go of the feelings and thoughts about my past behaviors. It is most helpful if you simply recognize that you have tons and tons of company. People are very adept on hiding their terrible secrets from others. Some are out there for all to see. The two types are the same if they had been doing the same things. Doing foolish and regrettable things in life is quite normal behavior. No need in beating yourself up over a most human way of acting. Forget about the past and look forward. Free your heart and become your own best friend. So what about the past! It IS in the past. This day is the most important day of your life because it is now and you are still breathing. Letting go of past mistakes will allow your spirit to lift up. You may even find a smile when you look into the mirror. Just forget about the past, remember that was yesterday and you have a brand new day in today. It is your call what you will do with 
THIS day!! Make it a good day!! Hang in there things can go very well for you. Ahoyha"

175977241,"Quite often an irritated throat is caused by a nasal issue - very thin mucus dripping down the throat from the back of your sinuses (post nasal drip). That's why you feel the need to clear your throat - this thin mucus is running down your windpipe and aggravating your vocal chords. When I get this condition it is usually along with needing to blow my nose due to a very slight drippy nose. Besides just a cold, you might want to consider if something in your environment is causing the reaction, or even something you're eating."

175977245,"So after the realization a few days/weeks ago about how I’m out of touch with my emotions, here’s the keys I found on how to work on it. 1. Figuring out why you’re having the emotion 2. Figuring out what sensation in your body that you’re having 3. Thinking about the deeper meaning behind the emotion. Not just figuring out what triggers the emotion but also figuring out why’s that emotion that’s being triggered 4. Telling yourself that it’s safe to have that emotion 5. Finding out the proper way to direct your emotion 6. Putting the right emotion for things that are really matter in your life. After I got out of the numb feeling that I experienced for years, I became a ball of emotions. I cry, laugh, angry, etc easily. But it doesn’t mean that I’m consciously aware of my emotions. Therefore they just jump out of nowhere, exploding fast and messy, like when you shake a soda and pop it out. So yeah I hope by using these steps I can control my emotions better."

174371130,"Well, it sounds like you hit upon it. You said, ""Hmm...now that you put it this way, I do suspect that maybe she's schizo-affective...? Like maybe Bipolar + Schizophrenic...? Sigh...this doesn't make me feel better too..."" Well, it might not make you feel better but it does sound like you may have remembered what her condition has been called. Typing ""schizoaffective disorder"" into the search engine, it says in the _USER_ID_.org website: ""Schizoaffective disorder is a chronic mental health condition characterized primarily by symptoms of schizophrenia, such as hallucinations or delusions, and symptoms of a mood disorder, such as mania and depression. ""The symptoms of schizoaffective disorder can be severe and need to be monitored closely. Depending on the type of mood disorder diagnosed, depression or bipolar disorder, people will experience different symptoms: • Hallucinations, which are seeing or hearing things that aren’t there. • Delusions, which are false, fixed beliefs that are he
ld regardless of contradictory evidence. • Disorganized thinking. A person may switch very quickly from one topic to another or provide answers that are completely unrelated. • Depressed mood. If a person has been diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder depressive type they will experience feelings of sadness, emptiness, feelings of worthlessness or other symptoms of depression. • Manic behavior. If a person has been diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder: bipolar type they will experience feelings of euphoria, racing thoughts, increased risky behavior and other symptoms of mania. • A period during which there is a major mood disorder, either depression or mania, that occurs at the same time that symptoms of schizophrenia are present. • Delusions or hallucinations for two or more weeks in the absence of a major mood episode. • Symptoms that meet criteria for a major mood episode are present for the majority of the total duration of the illness. • The abuse of drugs or a medication are not respo
nsible for the symptoms. Treatment ""Schizoaffective disorder is treated and managed in several ways: • Medications, including mood stabilizers, antipsychotic medications and antidepressants"" So she may have had the right medicine, an antipsychotic, but she was also not given a mood stabilizer such as Lithium, which I'm on, or an antidepressant, which I'm on also (Mirtazapine). So maybe right diagnosis, wrong medicine. I don't know, but with her condition and mental state, and then her missing, something about that diagnosis/medication was way off, in my view. You said her condition was: ""mood changes, being suddenly energetic, suddenly lethargic, having impaired judgment, hearing voices, not sleeping at all for a few days, grand ideas about getting a new place and applying for new jobs, not being able to focus (blank stare), withdrawing from me and our activities totally, fingers twitching every few seconds, suddenly bursting into tears, irrational fear of dust mites and seeing black shadows in the room.
"" That seems to match schizoaffective disorder. You're wondering, ""Could it still be Bipolar...? Hm..."" I don't think it's bipolar. You asked, ""_NAME_ and _PERSON_, have you ever abandoned/left your spouses for days/weeks out of the blue...? And did you all ever return...? Thanks for the input ya."" I never did that, but that is a good question. I know you're pretty worried. Are you able to get some sleep? Are you getting any help yourself, or know where you can go to get help if you need it? Yes, I think you're right to message her from time to time. I wouldn't blame myself for feeling less stress that's she's away from the house. Are you able to stay busy? As for taking care of yourself, I would try to eat good meals, get enough sleep, work on other things. After all, it's her not you who is having the problems. I would also try to stay positive that you can get through this. If you stay positive, you're going to come up with more good ideas, for you are telling your mind, we can get through this. Post

and I eat regularly and sleep in a warm bed. 175977329,"I understood magical thinking to be more than that, so I looked around and am annoyed by the inconsistency. Now, I'm assuming that even though odd beliefs and magical thinking are in one criteria, they are separate? The APA's Dictionary definition (as do other sources) describes it the way you did: ""Magical Thinking the belief that events or the behavior of others can be influenced by one’s thoughts, wishes, or rituals."" The APA's DSM 5: ""2. Odd beliefs or magical thinking that influences behavior and is inconsistent with subcultural norms (e.g., superstitiousness, belief in clairvoyance, telepathy, or “sixth sense”: in children and adolescents, bizarre fantasies or preoccupations)."" I realize I emeshed the concept of ""Magical Thinking"" and ""Odd Beliefs"" together with ""Ideas of Reference"" I neglect most people even if I like them because the interactions are a lot of work with very little payoff; it's draining. The drain will cause me to not want to make eye contact or have flat aff
ect and avoid phone calls or social situations, etc. Sometimes I try to interact so I don't totally lose the relation, but they usually take offense (or we drift apart) at my avoidance or my inability to stir up enthusiasm or genuine interest. I wonder how many people have done this to me as well. If I believe something to be purposeful or meaningful, I can turn it all around and become everything I'm normally not - as long as I don't feel trapped. It's not very common for me to meet anyone who brings me enough pleasure to make me want to interact regularly with. I lack a certain level of emotional intelligence; however, I've been learning the last while that my empathy is still disturbingly intact - at least in regards to some populations. It must have just gone into a coma for half a decade or so, but is still alive. I'm understanding the meal analogy to mean that sometimes it's about convenience rather than quality. For me, it's the opposite (I think). If my environment doesn't trigger the mood/emotions I 
need, I go off into my own world to find them. Sometimes it serves as a ""jump start"" if I'm hitting a depression. More like treating a nutrient deficiency. Sounds bad. I don't have this. I experience the odd beliefs (and now learning not magical thinking very often). I'm also not a stranger to ideas of reference. I found that some of the most problematic symptoms I've experienced were full fledged delusions. Largely, because you can't hide them. They were harder to handle than visual ""perceptual disturbances"" I've decided, when at all possible, it's best to avoid picking up diagnoses (and the resulting prescriptions) - and, instead, manage my symptoms on my own (or my psychologist assisting with coping skills)."

Although i was made sure that we were safe i would not believe it. After about 30 days, our country made arrangements to evacuate us from Wuhan. 175977378,"*mod _USER_ID_* Note Dr. Stone didn't say the majority were loners, let alone all of them: he said half were. In debunking the myth that all serial killers are loners, the FBI's affirmation that the majority of serial killers are not loners doesn't seem to conflict with _PERSON_: indeed half is not a majority. But if instead the FBI really meant that loners are less than half, the difference of views could be explained by a difference in degrees: ""loners with mostly schizoid traits"" versus dysfunctional ""reclusive, social misfits who live alone"". For instance, _NAME_ is a poster child for the sadistic schizoid psychopath serial killer, but he lived with him mom... We're not talking about sexual activity per se but torture. If you don't know the difference between the two, I wouldn't want to have sex with you. But if you insist on assimilating torture to sex just because some people are sexually aroused by it, then it would be the most extreme form of sex imaginable; and if a killer needs to tor
ture to really get his rocks off, I think it speaks of a profound inability to feel pleasure, even through sex, which is congruent with the ""has little, if any, interest in having sex"" criterion. Anyway, you only need to meet four criteria to be properly considered schizoid, let alone a loner, so your point is moot. Correct. Correlation with paraphilias increases as we move up the Scale. It's all rational. He looks at the crime, but also the perpetrator. In short, the more the killer is rational and free from mental illness and the more the crime is cooly premeditated and involving prolonged torture, the higher a person is ranked on the scale. Both exist. You can be sadistic without sexual excitement. Ever heard ""sadistic glee""? The apparent source of our disagreement and the problem I see with your approach is that you seem to forget that the DSM and the PCL-R are only imperfect tools. _PERSON_ himself talks about ""white collar/successful"" psychopaths. These people wouldn't meet the criteria for psycho
pathy, or even ASPD, but they are psychopaths nonetheless, like the so-called Angels of Death. Sure, for practical and research purposes it's advantageous to use those diagnostic instruments, but in the present context, clinical judgment has precedence; and since the hallmark of those disorders is callousness, it makes sense that serial murder would be more than enough to warrant the ""antisocial"" label. I agree there could be some exceptions though: a good prospect is schizoid _NAME_. It begs the question: are there any monsters at all? But I get what you mean. Yes, some of the highest ranking serial killers were charming and led double lives. The ""monsters"" are those who are not approachable in conversation and seem to be evil all the time. LOL, I know Wikipedia believe that too, but _PERSON_ name literally appears under the definition of the schizoid serial killer. Perhaps it's possible to be both Schizoid and Borderline. It's related to Borderline Personality Organization in general - therefore schizoi
d - of which polymorphous perverse sexuality is a symptom. Don't assume my lack of response is proof of anything. As it happens, I just don't know. Imagine that. If you don't bother to do any reading or watch some episodes of Most Evil, don't blame him when you run into misconceptions. Cordially."

175977435,"Minipuff: You said for years you have been on 60 mg of Prozac, which treats depression as well as anxiety. But you are still having anxiety and anxiety attacks. He might not be willing to take you off that because you might not go on a new medicine. Which brings us back to: Buspar, anti-anxiety. Try the Buspar and if after a time if it doesn’t work, give him a chance to increase it. From the things you listed in your last post which upset you, you should get down on your knees and thank the heavens above that anti-anxiety medicine even exists. Try the Buspar and then at increased dosages, and if doesn't work maybe ask him about new medicine. Also, you said in your latest post, “If things don't move at my pace, and my pace is very fast, then I get agitated.” So panic attacks is not the only issue. Looking at some of the experiences you’ve had, you need more anxiety medicine. I think your doctor is maxing out on the Prozac and you’re still having anxiety issues, so he’s giving you a secon
d anxiety medicine. You are really, out the widow. I remember when I first took Lithium stabilizer for biopolar, with the 1st pill, I felt like a 100 pound weight had been lifted off of my shoulders, the release of tension was so great. I didn’t know I had been walking around acting like an idiot, snapping off at a lot of people. I thought the other people were in the wrong to cause me to be angry. But you won’t take the next anxiety medicine because of your medicine phobia. Still, the ball is in your court. A possible solution is laid out in front of you, but you won’t take the medicine. And you're looking around for solutions and who's causing the problem. You said you have an appt. with your psy. tomorrow Wed. and noted, “So I will talk to him then about my fears.” That would be good. Mayoclinic.org said about phobias, they can be helped by: 1.Psychotherapy, which you’ll be doing tomorrow. 2. Exposure therapy, which, “if you're afraid of elevators, your therapy may progress from simply thinki
ng about getting into an elevator, to looking at pictures of elevators, to going near an elevator, to stepping into an elevator. Next, you may take a one-floor ride, then ride several floors, and then ride in a crowded elevator.” How about as a baby step to taking your medicine, you take a vitamin pill? 3. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). What helped me with a lot of my problems was positive thinking, in that a column I read said that before going into a problem believe that you can solve it. Again, before even thinking about the problem, I first had to believe that I could solve it, which flipped my unconscious to positive and looking for solutions. If my unconscious is on negative (and my conscious is set on positive), I look for defeat, or half win, half loss. So, rather than open the door (which my uncon. says might be locked), I dive out of a plate glass window to get out of a burning building, which is half win, half loss, to satisfy both parts of my brain. I then check the door, and it was open th
e entire time. So, now I say, “Think positive, think positive, think positive” before I even think about the problem, so my uncon. will be looking for solutions. As for sleep, Melatonin from health food store. Ask your doctor about that."

dy but never did. I told him, I was afraid to keep coming out because of autoimmune status & caring for elderly parents. I have no smartphone. Then read of the situation where countless people have been exposed and humiliated by Zoom showing their private chats online for everyone to see! Should we feel great danger from our healthcare system?- And 
now walmart has only ONE door- farthest from the pharmacy- that is open! The store's big, overcrowded, people are downright nuts and there's only 1 door, to get in and out. 175977589,"L., Sometimes we get caught up in cycles of negative thinking. It can make management and recovery really hard...I've been there! 175977608,"OF, surely your pcp has another dr filling in for him, it would be negligent not to have someone covering his practice. Also, many drs are doing telemedicine appts even with new patients. This past year my husband's pcp put him on Citalopram for depression & anxiety. He started at 20mg & bumped him to 40mg a month later. I knew he was depressed but had no idea how much anxiety was as much of an issue. I can't begin to tell you the difference this made for him. He had back surgery in October & if it weren't for his depression & anxiety being under control it would have never happened. He has done very well since surgery. He's turning 76 this month, not exactly a spring chick. If I remember right you take Cymbalta which really does nothing for anxiety. Try to talk to a dr about putting you on a medication that works for both issues. I took Buspar several years ago & did well with it. I would call the pcp's office Monday & ask who is handling the drs patients. If nothing else, look for another pcp, bu

175977631,"Minipuff: I just looked at the side effects for Buspar and webmd.com said on the outside of the website: 1. Dizziness, drowsiness, headache, nausea, nervousness, lightheadedness, restlessness, blurred vision, tiredness, and trouble sleeping may occur. If any of these effects persist or worsen, notify your doctor or pharmacist promptly. ""trouble sleeping can occur."" So this would coincide with what you said you had, or trouble sleeping. On the inside of the same website, it said: 2. This medication is used to treat anxiety. It may help you think more clearly, relax, worry less, and take part in everyday life. It may also help you to feel less jittery and irritable, and may control symptoms such as trouble sleeping, sweating, and pounding heartbeat. Buspirone is a medication for anxiety (anxiolytic) that works by affecting certain natural substances in the brain (neurotransmitters). or ""may control symptoms such as trouble sleeping."" Somewhat conflicting, but I guess either could occur. In the fi
rst item above it adds: ""If any of these effects persist or worsen, notify your doctor or pharmacist promptly."" I take Melatonin for sleep. You can also ask you doctor or pharmacist if Melatonin is OK with the medicines you are taking. I also use a heating pad on low to help me go to sleep sometimes. I take the Melatonin an hour or two before going to bed so it can be in full effect. 12"

175977663,"It's like.. We know.. But the thing is, .. We have to become a different person.. Analysing and living life on antipsychotics.. We can't be psychotic.. Even though it feels like truth. We have to start from the beginning and look for truth. Completely different person. We stop our meds, come back to the state of truth.. (It's not truth but it feels like truth). We have to blindly look for it like everyone else.. live life.. Then we die happy. Or we can die psychotic. Who knows. All the creativity, the genius.. Sparks of psychosis coming through.. But not when completely knowing the paradox... I got my hand and cut a line through reality, said ""Enough! I want to go back to sanity. To not knowing what I know. 175977678,"I’m so sorry to hear about your struggles. Definitely seek professional help from a psychiatrist and/or therapist. I’ve been having issues for 30 years, with highs and lows. I’ve been on so many different meds, but it’s a trial and error process. A therapist will help you find ways to cope. Getting set up with good coping skills I think I a key component. Please don’t put yourself down or think you are crazy. These are chemical imbalances within our brain and we have no control over them. Unfortunately, it is a sickness just like diabetes, high cholesterol or even cancer. Don’t give up!!! I found over the years some coping skills that have helped me is journaling, in the moment remember to breathe, close your eyes and breathe, remember you are a good strong person and nothing is going to take that away from you! Have a cup of tea, read a “no-nonsense” book that you don’t even care what the title it. Get lots of rest and sleep, even if you have to go to bed extra early. Lack of sle
ep is your worst enemy. You are a very special person and are not alone by any means. Like I said, I’ve been suffering from anxiety and depression for 30 years and right now I’m at an all time low, but I’m going to fight back with everything I got. God bless and good luck to you!"

175977682,"Hello. I have bipolar. Your description of being overly happy and wanting to hurt yourself seems to describe the swinging highs and lows of bipolar. I once had to go to the ER because I was experiencing what is called 'rapid cycling'. I was laughing hysterically one moment, then crying the next. It was weird. I was aware of what was happening, but I couldn't control it. I hope this explanation helps. Good luck, friend. I would check with your doctor soon."

175977728,"I used to be a very nervous person. But since then, I've become much more calm. However, when something does makes me nervous for a few minutes these days, it can occasionally get on my nerves. I'm sure it can with you as well, especially if you currently have serious anxiety issues like I used to. But nowadays, when something makes me anxious for a short time, I often succeed at not having it get on my nerves. For example, a few days ago, I was driving my car when I heard an odd noise. I was afraid that something might be wrong with my vehicle. And I hate to have to spend money getting a problem with my car fixed by my mechanic. I'm not a rich person, after all. It turned out that the noise was merely coming from funky pavement on the road that I was driving on that had been patched up fairly recently. No big deal. Nothing I have to worry about. I could have told myself, ""Man, I wish that noise didn't scare me and cause my anxiety for a few minutes!"" Instead, I told myself, ""I'm just glad it tu
rned out to be nothing."" So if something makes you nervous and it turns out to be nothing, you can either tell yourself, ""I wish that hadn't happened!"" Or you can tell yourself, ""I'm just glad it turned out to be nothing."" I suggest going with the latter."

174371967,"I have a love/hate relationship with clozapine. It's considered the most effective antipsychotic out there, but you have to get frequent blood work because one of the potential but extremely rare but dangerous side effects is a lowering of your white blood cells. It worked really well for me as in completely got rid of all my psychotic symptoms, but I gained a lot of weight on it and eventually I quit taking it because the pharmacy ****_NAME_ up and I was too paranoid to begin taking it again and switched to Zyprexa. It also was not practical for me (who can't consistently drive to the pharmacy) to get blood work every week and go to the pharmacy the next day, so that's another reason I didn't go back on it. It made me sleep a lot too, but no more than Zyprexa."

175977898,"The problem with plugs is that, with the noise from the dental drill coming from inside the ear drum, the plugs would increase the sound, for no sound could get out of the ear canal. The noise cancellation technology head set probably wouldn't work because the sound from the drill would get to the ear drum first, then go to the noise cancellation headset. Too late. Also the head set would keep the noise inside the ear. Ordinarily that might work, but I don't think it would in this case. The best combination for me that I've found is, double ear plugs, that look like bubblegum (silicon earplugs, Walgreens, Walmart and net), with non-electric earphones. For plugs with noise cancellation headphones, the electric headphones don't work, because the electronics can't get to the ear drum because of the plugs."

175977909,"Hello, I completely agree with everything that's been said, especially with _PERSON_ advice about controverting your thoughts. I feel like I'm going mad ALL the time. When anxiety sweeps over me my intrusive thoughts make me think i'm going to go crazy and harm somebody I love even though I'm the most sensitive person that wouldn't harm a fly. It's because the anxiety plays on our fears and we often feel like we're losing control and this makes us feel like our mind is breaking. Our anxiety will say ""imagine if you ended up on a psych ward in a straight jacket"" and this makes us feel fear, heightened by the anxiety voice saying ""what if"" or ""imagine if"". I just try to live in the now/ present and ignore the 'what ifs', like somebody earlier said crazy people don't know they're crazy, and anybody with anxiety has probably felt the same as you at some point- you will be fine ""this too shall pass"", it never lasts forever and you are certainly not crazy. I never used to self-analyse until I sta
rted to get anxiety. One minute I would be like ""I didn't feel anxious for that last 5 minutes, I'm so happy"" and then because I'd acknowledged my feelings I'd start to feel anxious, it's like my anxiety was punishing me for not feeling anxious and it almost felt as if I'd brought it on myself, and I'd be clinging to every good emotion praying that the unwelcome visitor wouldn't come, but he always did. I sometimes try to imagine the anxiety as a big bully and if you listen to the bully it will pick on you more, but if you listen to the good voice in your head and ignore it it will get bored and start to disappear. It may never fully go but you can manage it. You will stop self-analysing and thinking about how you feel every single day I'm sure of it, as I said before 'this too shall pass'"

174372118,"No Bake Pumpkin Pie 2 cups canned pumpkin 1/2 cup sugar 8 ounces cream cheese softened 2 8 ounce containers of Cool Whip 1 Tablespoon cinnamon 2 Teaspoons pumpkin pie spice 1 teaspoon nutmeg 1 3.4 ounce box instant vanilla pudding 1 cup milk 2 pre made 9 inch _NAME_ cracker crusts Step one: put out the crusts so they are ready for filling Step two: bottom layer add cream cheese, sugar, and one 8 ounce tub of whipped cream in a separate bowl and blend well with a mixer. Fill the crusts evenly with this layer. Step three: mix pudding and milk and stir until thick. Add 2 cups of canned pumpkin, add pumpkin pie spice, nutmeg, and cinnamon, stir until blended. Put this on top of the cream cheese layer. Step four: for the top layer use the second 8 ounce container of cool whip to top the pie. Perhaps sprinkle a bit of pumpkin spice on top. This recipe makes two pies. Got this recipe from Facebook. I haven't tried it yet but it looks delicious and I want to try it soon. Especially now that it is fall!"

175978021,"Hi L., I am sorry to hear that you have been struggling lately, and about the fact that you feel you are dealing with a dependency to alcohol. It is all too easy to self medicate when dealing with mental health challenges. The good news is that you are aware of this issue...and from the sound of it, caught on to the trouble early on. This will help you in your resolve to cut back or stop in order to properly address your anxiety and improve your overall health. Whatever method/tools you employ for alcohol cessation...remember also to really concentrate on your anxiety coping skills as well. Approaching this as a combined plan should really help you. Let us know how we can be of support to you during this time. We are cheering you on! S.C."

175978040,"If you think about it, those things don't necessarily contradict each other. Near-zero belonging is better than less-than-zero. Chronic solitude isn't ideal, but, when human contact / human relationships actually make you feel more alien, solitude is the better option. ""The need for belonging"" is a basic human instinct that doesn't really translate well to modern life, where anonymity in your own community is the norm. What that means is that ""a sense of belonging"" and ""actual human contact"" often are separate things. And for someone who has difficulty feeling at home in any sort of actual social setting, those things can become almost mutually exclusive. Human contact in general has had an impact on my ""personal growth"" over the years mostly through negative reinforcement. ""Things that don't work. Things to avoid. Things that make me feel like crap."" Most of the positive reinforcement to my sense of self has come from ""arts and media"" instead. Music, TV series, video games and such. Th
at's where I get my ""sense of belonging"" from."

Important Information"" It said side affects included weigh gain. ""Bipolar II disorder is a milder form of mood elevation, involving milder episodes of hypomania that alternate with periods of severe depression."" ith involuntary muscle movement. Ingrezza is used to treat symptoms of tardive dyskinesia, a nervous system disorder. Tardive dyskinesia causes repetitive uncontrolled muscle movements, usually in the face (chewing, lip smacking, frowning, tongue movement, blinking or eye movement)."" I went outside for a walk - Listening to Linkin Park and a few other artists about suicide. I came back inside and told my mom that I was feeling suicidal. The next day, we went to the renters house (Our old house) because my mom didn’t feel that I was safe to be alone and it was turned into a crack house. It disturbed me but I wanted to get out of the dysphoria so I took a higher than usual amount of phenibut. I was laughing and keeping to myself. When we got back, I was even more dysphoric and I remember explaining to my mom that I wanted to move out because I couldn’t focus - She wanted to talk to her new bf about my schizophrenia and then she started talking about herself. They picked at my identity so hard, said my mom is a ***** when I told them about my ex step dad and saying that she has breast cancer and that’s the reason that I’m a “Slave of the psychiatric system and can’t get out”, made fun of my lack of facial expressions when I’m being grilled and gaslighted. I was reading and listening to music and podcasts - Just enjoying myself and starting to feel better. I listened to 
a song that I thought was sent from God to make me go psychotic every time I listen to it. He then said “You don’t judge me - Can I take a piss here?” and I said “no” and he started pissing so I thought he was trying to piss me off and was sent by aliens or something because I was not social distancing I needed juice for my mental health at the gas station - I was afraid that people would say “You aren’t protecting humanity” and I would say “I’m from the future, sent here on an intergalactical mission to save the world - also that humanity needs to die”.. you” - It was complete impulse. I knew what I was doing was just a reaction to make reality conform to my solipsism and torment but he gaslighted me and said “Don’t do that - Do you want a joint? Just be chill” and I said “I can’t smoke that - I’m not ****ing chill right now” so I walked inside and he said “Don’t do that” (Because he didn’t want to tell people) and then said “I know where you live”. I walked inside and told my mom, her friend (I thought she was doing coke in the house because I saw a swipe of water not the counter and powder on the floor that she could have wiped off) and my moms new bf (I was annoyed that my mom was talking to him because of the whole thing that the people said to me on the video chat) and I told my mom and she said that it’s ok - She said “Where is he?” and my moms friend said “Let’s go find him - Come out for a smoke” so we went outside and two other guys with the stoned drunk guy were looking at us and said “We need to pass” so 
they walked passed and stared at me and as my mom and her bf were walking out, my mom let the cat out. I said “God damn it” and went to get ham to catch the cat. My mom caught the cat and then fell and said she broke her toe or something and went inside with the cat. I tried to help my mom but she wouldn’t let go of the cat and I said “Give me the ****ing cat”. She was drunk. I then had a complete spasticated meltdown on the front lawn - Yelling and screaming - jumping around and kicking things, swearing “I’m sick of all of this ******** - Every time I start to feel better, some stupid ******** happens”. Everyone was saying that everything is ok and it’s the coronavirus and we’re all in this together and my mom said “What can you take to feel better?” and I said “A zopiclone” - She said “Go take that” so i went into my room, took a zopiclone and a diazepam and felt more relaxed. ut you’d have to pay because she’d lose her job so that’s not an option”. I then walked around town, passing a sitting cop car and dancing and moving around - I took 400 dollars out of a bank machine because I was afraid that my mom would take my money and then met my friend at the gas station. I told him everything and said “I was walking past someone’s house where people were having a camp fire. I wanted to talk to them because i needed someone to talk to but I’d feel like and intruder”. My friend just talked to me and calmed me down and then I left to go back home. I sat by the fire again in the front yard and a cop pulled up and said “We got a distress call from around here”. I told the cop a bunch of stuff about the cat and he said “Is anyone in the house?”, I said “My mom and her bf”. The cops went inside and I could hear them sleeping but her bedroom door was locked so I said “Mom are you ok?” because I thought that her bf was hurting her or something and she said “It
s just me and your sister” I called my sisters name to make sure that she was there because I knew she wasn’t so I banged on the door and said “Open up”. She probably said to her bf to pretend to be my sister I thought and she opened the door and they were both naked but were previously asleep. I said to the cops that everything is fine and they left. I yelled at my mom saying “You don’t give a **** about me you caused my mental illness you ****ing *****” and she then phoned my dad and we all talked. My mom was making up stories saying she thought I was outside by the fire and I said “Then why was the front door locked before I left?”. My dad said for me to go to bed because we both know how messed up she is. I woke up this morning feeling still sort of confused about everything and my sister phoned me and said that my mom does care about me and she does to. I know my mom can do what ever the hell she want, I can’t change her and I won’t try - But I’d rather be out of the house becau
se I can’t focus, she would rather drink and neglect my mental health and lie and manipulate my psychosis, use it against me, admit me to the psych ward, take my money. I know this. Nothing I can do. Now I have to sort out everything in my head. I was thinking about that crack house and my mom said ""We have such good memories"". I don't have good memories."

175978160,"Rest your weary mind dear _PERSON_. It needs rest and comfort from the one who understands you best, yourself! It's time to change oil in the overheated engine of your thoughts. Do not watch the news. This is a strange thing, then how do you know what's going on? How do you remain connected? How do you avoid danger? How do you stay in some kind of the know? Short answer... Turn towards your inner light and it will guide the way. Keep clear of the violence and fear and conflict as much as possible this week. It's time to create a new routine of more self-love and comfort for yourself, the basics that make you feel best. Proper rest, a little scheduled light exercise, healthy diet, and relaxing showers. Your interests need more nurture. Limit Facebook and all News on a strict and short leash. Call or text more loved ones and those who love you. Surround yourself with your own positives and neutralize the compelling nature we all sometimes give in to by dwelling too much on what is not within our cont
rol. Control what you can and free yourself of worry, and empower yourself with more you and less of the worries and lamentations. No, it's all true that there may be nothing you can do to change world you live in, but with most certainty fierce _PERSON_, you can change the you that the world of your thoughts pivot upon. So do not go gently _PERSON_. This is your time to redefine the rules of the hand that's dealt. This is your game and it's time to double down and play to win. You're the only one who can. - cres"

175978241,"I think it's great that you've tried writing here (and perhaps elsewhere). My wife also ended our relationship a few years ago...(since then, we divorced and remarried and then she's left again) So, in a nutshell, I understand more or less the panic and anguish you're facing... Your bf sounds a lot like my wife...hence he probably has undiagnosed Bipolar or some relevant disorder. I will be _NAME_. To have a sustainable relationship for any length of time...and I'm not talking about forever(perhaps a year or two, a decade or two; who knows what God has in mind), he MUST be diagnosed and then be either on medication and/or perhaps ECT, depending on how severe his condition is... Mania, if I don't remember wrongly, is more severe than hypomania...so if it's mania, you're in for a rough ride. Still, hang on to the railings and don't fall off! 1. If you want to pursue this long-term, you must try your very best, your utmost, to persuade him to obtain a diagnosis from the MH hospital and relevant meds. 
Otherwise, don't even think about this long-term. Without meds, his moods will be unpredictable indefinitely. 2. How much do you love him? Is he the only one for you for the rest of your life? Cos' for me, my wife is. And I'm willing to go the distance for her. Are you willing to go for him? In his lucid state, how does he feel about you? If he feels the same way, then hang in there and pray the hardest you've ever had to God...and maybe it might work out. I offer you no hope, just perhaps a tiny sliver of it because this will be a _USER_ID_ for the rest of your life. With meds, it's less of a _USER_ID_...more of a ride on a _NAME_ beach on a sunny day, with the occasional lovely seagulls, together with the obnoxious black crows... 174372566,"Hi everyone I just wanted to share my story and experience with schizophrenia to see if anyone can relate. In May 2015 I had my first psychotic episode while I was at work. I was working as a barista and had little sleep the night before. I started to hear my roommates voice tell me he was going to kill me if I didn't pay the rent I owed the last month I lived with them. I didn't have the money and my roommates knew that I couldn't pay it. I started hearing their voices that morning and thought they were out to kill me because I didn't pay the rent. I worked in a hospital lobby espresso bar and as soon as I heard my roommates voice tell me he had a gun I freaked out and locked myself in a room in the hospital till the ambulance came and brought me to a different hospital. I was believing my roommates were telling me to pay the rent or I would die. I kept hallucinating and imagining my roommate with a gun ready to shoot me when he was no where near me that day. I was released from the hospital that 
night. The next morning I asked my roommates if that was him I was hearing and he started laughing and responded saying ""no but I did have a doctor's appointment that day"". Because he was laughing and couldn't keep a straight face when I asked him I was suspicious that he was responsible for the voice I heard in my head. I lived with two roommates who were brothers for 6 months while in college and never had any arguments with them. The day I had my episode I heard both of their voices playing with my mind about the unpaid rent. The voices were telling me that I was going to get arrested and the government was after me but I knew these voices sound a lot like my roommates and the voice told me it was my roommates too. I was lost and confused and stressed out from college so I failed that quarter. A month later in June 2015 I had another mental breakdown. This one want as worse because my brain knew it was just my roommates voices. I was still hearing ""pay the rent"" ""my brother is going to shoot you"" ""m
y brother shot your dad and mom"" and I believed it because I still had no idea how I was heading these voices but I knew they were my roommates voices. I went to the hospital that day and was released that night. After this I started to hear them in my head more frequently during the night time before bedtime while we were all in the same apartment. It appeared as if they were doing nothing but I suspected they were reading my mind. Their voices kept asking me questions about my past sexual experiences in my head and that I needed to pay the rent because it would affect their credit scores. This was the first time I started to believe they could read my mind with some kind of software that is top secret. These roommates that I had are Christian and believe in Jesus as well as they knew I was Christian too. We all sat down one night before we all moved out at the end of June 2015 and I asked them if they could help me with my sexual addiction and they said they might have something that could help out but nev
er actually specified or showed me what it was. Another thing that made me believe they were reading my mind is we were all gathered in the living room, I was hallucinating their voices and they were telling me to pay the rent while staring directly at me and their mouths weren't moving. I didn't know what was going on so I left the apartment immediately and went to stay with family. Clearly they were communicating to me telepathically but I had no evidence that they were reading my mind and they wouldn't tell me with their mouths they were reading my brain. Their voices in my head told me they have software that could read my brain but I can't see how a computer could read the brain. For a while I believed this was the truth and listened to whatever the voices told me. Back then I thought they were gang stalking me for not paying the rent on time and because they didn't like that I had sex with multiple women inside of the apartment we all lived in. In my mind they were telling me ""you're not a Christian yo
u have had sex with a lot of people"". After moving out of that apartment with them I still heard their voices and was depressed for 3 months. Couldn't get out of bed. I was enrolled in community college and failed that while quarter because I couldn't get over the intensity of my voices. The way my voices was making me feel was very agitated most of the days and annoyed. At this point I want diagnosed with schizophrenia. I was diagnosed with adhd, sleep apnea, and migranes. The voices began to tell me ""medication is a sin and that I would go to hell for taking drugs"". I couldn't think this was a lie because the voices were controlling my thoughts and I finally threw away all the medication I had. The voices told me this is what Jesus wanted me to do. The voices of my now ex roommates also told me because their computer program was connected to my brain they could feel all of my feelings. I took adhd medication and the voices tried to prove to me that the medication didn't work because it just provides you 
with a feeling. I thought all of this was real and tried to get my family to believe it too. One way I tried to relieve the voices was to buy some noise canceling headphones. I tried them and I could still hear the voices clearly. I can't see how this would be my ex roommates doing this to me because sometimes the voices are loud and sometimes quiet so they would need some way to turn it down and up if mind reading was real. If I can still hear the voices with my headphones on and turned all the way up its definitely not a computer program. No computer is that strong. It's just a really bad hallucination. Fast forward to now a days in 2019 I still hear voices that still continue to tell me they are real and my ex roommates who are reading my brain. I continue to believe I am just hallucinating. I argue with the voices and tell them they aren't real and that my roommates are innocent. This helps me out because the voices have no way to change my beliefs. I was just wondering if anyone else has had a similar ex
perience to this type of schizophrenia or voices that you may hear."

175978470,"E, there are several type of sleep apnea. The most common one is obstructive sleep apnea. This type happens when the throat muscles intermittently relax & block the airway during sleep. A noticeable sign of this type is snoring. Here are the typical symptoms; excessive daytime sleepiness loud snoring observed episodes of stopped breathing during sleep (by another person) abrupt awakenings accompanied by gasping or choking waking with a dry mouth or sore throat morning headaches difficulty concentrating during the day mood changes such as depression or irritability high blood pressure decreased libido The above symptoms are on the Mayo Clinic's website. The symptoms you discussed with the dentist are not on this list. I am surprised at the dentist even making the suggestion. If you have been stressed/anxious more lately, certainly that will affect you sleep. Grinding your teeth, stress will cause this with many of us. As a dentist, she should have been able to look at your teeth to look for damage t
o your teeth from grinding them. They makes plastic mouth guards available in drugstores for people that grind their teeth. I worked in a high stress job & would grind my teeth at night & caught myself during the day doing it. The next morning my jaws would ache from a night of grinding. The plastic piece helped a lot, plus it made me feel better knowing I wasn't damaging my teeth. Both my husband & son have apne. My husband will not use a CPAP machine, his is severe. He snores like a freight train, I sleep with ear plus. When he sits down he falls asleep within minutes, in bed he jerks awake. At night he flips & flops so bad he is like a fish out of water. But, his is severe. He has nearly every symptom _NAME_ this list. My son has the machine & says he sleeps the best he has ever. He no longer wakes up tired, he is rested. Most of all he no longer snores! Check out the Mayo Clinics site & read up about this. Unless you are having symptoms listed above this does not sound like sleep apnea. I am not a dr but 
have good knowledge of it, lol."
175978471,"You mention your mood plunged in April, so probably the Pandemic Effect is a big factor. Life as we all knew it abruptly changed for all of us, so it's not the least bit surprising that you--like so many millions--are struggling now to adjust to a new, surreal reality. I've found that avoiding most TV/Internet ""news"" and political chatter is helpful in reducing stress and negative feelings and improving sleep. Also, unplugging a few hours before bedtime and trying to spend as much time as possible outdoors, exercising and looking a natural beauty is very relaxing. The media feeds anxiety because 100% of it relies on hype, hysteria, faux rage to attract viewers and boost ratings. Politicians/partisan media pundits argue, shout, and blame the other party because they think fear and anger motivate people to vote for them or against their opponents. That may be true, but being bombarded by so much toxic media harms the mind.Post Edited (kate333) : 8/18/2020 11:34:51 AM (GMT-6)"

175978473,"Hi Bam, Heart attack pain is often described as a sensation of a crushing weight on one's chest. There may also be pain in the jaw line area, or even upper back, and a shooting/radiating pain going down the left arm. With a cardiac event you are also going to have nausea (extreme) shortness of breath and dizziness/feeling faint. Of course the frustrating thing about these symptoms are that they are also often present with anxiety, especially a panic attack where they might all be happening simultaneously. In your case however, it sounds like you are primarily dealing with the chest pain which would not be indicative of a HA...especially considering that you are not high risk. So do your best to trust your doctor and keep working on your Health Anxiety management to reach the goal of not getting derailed by your anxiety symptoms...and eventually lessening/eliminating them altogether. S.C"
175978474,"Yes, manipulation becomes the name of the game with some bi-polar people. You have to determine what is right for you. How much can you actually endure before it starts to hurt you. 175978543,"“If deep sleep is about body, REM is about the brain,” says Grandner. “The brain is very active during REM sleep, yet the body is very inactive. ... REM is when most dreaming happens and your eyes move rapidly in different directions (hence the name). Heart rate increases and your breathing becomes more irregular."" 175978563,"First, it’s good that you wrote in. Second, I think you have a very good therapist. I’ve had a few psychologists, but they all seemed to think they could cure me without medicine. The fact that you have a therapist who would listen to you talk, hear of your difficulties, and realize she might need more than just a pep talk every now and then, and then recommend a psychiatrist, is pretty amazing to me. I’ve had bipolar for many years and remember the first time I took Lithium (for the mania part) I felt like a weight had been taken off of my shoulders. I only then realized how much I had been battling the tension of mania. It was just a natural feeling for me because I had been battling that for most of my life. It was like I had been gritting my teeth and “bucking up” just to make it through a small amount of time. Oh, I remember what I thought now, when I took my first lithium pill after 10 or 15 years of being tense: I thought it felt like the air had been let out of an overly inflated 
balloon. I couldn’t believe I had not taken Lithium sooner. One of the problems was, my psychiatrists had not prescribed it. I would come in in a depressed state, and they would diagnose me as depressed, and give me an anti-deperssant. Because they had not diagnosed me right, then they couldn’t medicate me right, so it wasn’t doing me any good. The anti-depressant alone (with no Lithium, etc., to hold down my mania), would excite my brain and throw me into mania. It would also cause me to have anxiety attacks. Why the psychiatrists couldn’t ask me if I had mania (do you ever have a racing mind?) when I came in as depressed, is hard to understand. But I had several of them who failed to see that. So if you ever do see a psychiatrist, don’t assume they are going to get it right. Keep these things in mind if you do see a psychiatrist, including if you go in as depressed, so you can say, “Oh, but I also have some of the signs of mania, such as…” and give him your reasons for believing you might be 
bipolar. Also, also, also, tell them your therapist believes you might be bipolar. That should do it. My mother’s mother had bipolar and that’s who I got mine from. Did you say you had a relative who might be bipolar? You give an interesting description of this, saying, “From within the 2nd session, she has been recommending me to see a psychiatrist for medication. I am TERRIFIED. I am very much afraid of change. But I do know that I do not want to live with the way my emotions are, especially days leading up to and during my feminine cycle. She even recently stated ""Now I don't want to you think that just because you have a certain disorder that it defines who you are, because it does not... I truly believe you have bi-polar and should be tested for it"" Webmd.com said the symptoms of mania include: • Excessive happiness, hopefulness, and excitement; Sudden changes from being joyful to being irritable, angry, and hostile; Restlessness; Rapid speech and poor concentration; Increased energy and less n
eed for sleep • Unusually high sex drive; Making grand and unrealistic plans; Showing poor judgment; Drug and alcohol abuse; Becoming more impulsive; Less need for sleep; Less of an appetite; Larger sense of self-confidence and well-being; Being easily distracted During depressive periods, a person with bipolar disorder may have: • Sadness; Loss of energy; Feelings of hopelessness or worthlessness; Not enjoying things they once liked; Trouble concentrating; Forgetfulness; Talking slowly; Less of a sex drive • Inability to feel pleasure; Uncontrollable crying; Trouble making decisions; Irritability; Needing more sleep; Insomnia; Appetite changes that make you lose or gain weight You can check out some of these sites yourself by typing in “bipolar” into the search engine. Again, you said, “I am TERRIFIED. I am very much afraid of change. But I do know that I do not want to live with the way my emotions are, especially days leading up to and during my feminine cycle.” There is a saying about change 
which says, “Nothing is so painful to the human mind as a great and sudden change.” (_NAME_, 1818, Frankenstein) Sometimes we are our own worst enemy. It’s like 10 people are keeping you from getting help. Really, there is only one, yourself. I had that, myself, for many years, that’s why I’m an expert on it. My negative unconscious was coming up with good reasons why I should treat myself bad, just like I had programed it to from child hood training or from bipolar, or from both. I had to be taught how to be positive, and then I quit sabotaging myself. There is another quote which says, “Strength comes from your vulnerability, and being able to step outside of your pride, your protective shell, your fear and say, ‘I need help.’ — _NAME_, It’s Okay To Ask For Help, You Know. It’s good that there is a website such as this so we don’t even have to leave home to get help. It’s good that people have the strength to write in. Can your wonderful therapist recommend a psychiatrist? Can she 
give you his or her phone number? Or, can you look up on the search engine “psychiatrists for your hometown” and write down a few of the numbers? You can get a male or a female psychiatrist. Unless your next appointment is far off, I would get a recommendation from your therapist, or call in and tell the secretary you’d like a recommendation for a psychiatrist. Maybe one male, one female, and take your choice."

175978593,"Humans tend to normalize behaviors of close intimates, tucking certain responses and behaviors into folders labeled: “Just the way he is” or “So typical of her.” We do that because, in the moment, we chose to stay in the relationship, even though the sailing isn’t always smooth. Some of the time, we fail to recognize that we’re actually excusing behaviors that should never be tolerated. People with insecure attachment styles whose emotional needs weren’t met in childhood do this more often and for longer than securely attached people who are much more likely to call out hurtful behavior because, for them, it’s anomalous. Those who were used to being marginalized, ignored, mocked or picked on in their childhood homes are much more likely to normalize or excuse bad behaviors. It’s a bit like the pile of boots and shoes by the front door that you get so used to that alas you no longer see it. (For a more in-depth discussion of how this affects unloved daughters, see my new book, Daug
hter Detox:Recovering from an Unloving Mother and Reclaiming Your Life. Tools of manipulation and power All of these behaviors are ways of exerting control over you, and are signs of an imbalance of power in the relationship, as well as clues to the other person’s motivations. Some of them are more obvious than others but the real key is whether or not you’re calling them out for what they are or whether you’re pleasing, appeasing, rationalizing, denying, or making excuses. We all need to take responsibility for whether or how we tolerate behaviors that shouldn’t be a part of anyone’s emotional landscape. Read more here: https://blogs.psychcentral.com/knotted/2018/02/7-toxic-behaviors-you-should-never-tolerate/?li_source=LI&li_medium=popular17"

175978603,"UPDATE: Hi folks - I thought I should check in and let you all know how things have transpired in the past couple of weeks. After sticking with the Brupopion for three weeks, and averaging 2 to 3 hours of sleep a night, I had had enough and insisted on speaking to my doctor for a change in prescript ions. That was on Nov 19th. Unfortunately, when I contacted the clinic, I learned that my PCM was out on vacation for a couple of weeks, but they were kind enough to let me come in and speak with another doctor. The new doctor was very attentive and listened to what I had to say, including my suggestions for alternative drugs and requesting a thyroid blood test. Although he completely sympathized with me and and the major insomnia problems I was having, he felt that replacing the Trazodone with Remeron was a bit premature. He felt that the Buproprion was the cause of my insomnia and he replaced that prescript ion with Lexapro. Within two days of stopping the _PERSON_, my sleep improved tremendously. I c
ontinue to track my sleep on a CBT-i application I have on my phone and my sleep efficiency over the past few days has exceeded 80%. I am consistently getting 6 or more hours of sleep a night. Today, I had a follow-up with that new doctor as he wanted to see how I was doing on the new meds. Since I am doing well, at least for right now, he recommended I stay on the Lexapro / Trazodone combo for the next six months at which time we'll do another follow-up and possibly look at possibly reducing these meds. While at the clinic today, I also had some lab work done to (1) Check my thyroid levels, and (2) Check my vitamin D levels (which were considerably low during my last physical in Feb, 2019. So that's where I am. I'm still not sure if I really have an anxiety / stress / depression problem. All that I know is that I'm getting sleep at night, and I can't ask for any more than that. _PERSON_ - Colorado Springs"
