175978616,"Hi there I am a somewhat functioning BI-Polar 2 with social anxiety, eating disorder history, and depression. My husband and I have been on a roller coaster ride for quite some time. In terms of your husband, I’m sorry to say but medication is needed. Treated similar to type 1, the medication process can be hard but in the end is worth it. Only a psychiatrist can truly diagnose and prescribe, and they are there to help not hurt. A bi polar talk therapist could also help to truly break down those barriers of honesty with both self and family. I also always advocate that spouses seek therapy as well. Bipolar anything can be extremely harmful, and as my husband and I discovered, there is a very thin line between helping and enabling. We had to learn this line together, and it we are still working to understand the pain that can come from crossing and creating that line, Also, i’m tempted to ask why is he saying no to treatment? Is he truly worried about his creative process- or is he just afraid? 
And what past experience is driving that fear? I always had a reason not to get help. In the end I was just really scared."

175978619,"Your story sounds very complex and I resonate with it on a lot of levels. It sounds like it is overwhelming and a lot to think about. Can you focus on one day at a time, to start. Is there anything that you enjoy doing, just for the pure joy of doing it? Like reading, or art, maybe coloring, or writing? I have a lot of anxiety around social situations and pushing myself outside my comfort zone too, and I find that I am able to recharge, at least a little, from doing a calming solitary activity. Usually focusing my mind on something simple and light-hearted helps to sooth a worried mind. Maybe try not to focus on fixing anything or figuring anything out right now and just give yourself some space to breathe. Sit outside and enjoy nature. That always helps me. I would also encourage you to keep talking to a therapist and work on learning how to value yourself more and how to process and express your emotions in a healthy way. In my experience, I've turned myself into a pretzel trying to get people to 
like/accept me but I am finally starting to discover that I have to accept who I am first. Also, remember that this is a process and it takes a lot of time and patience. There is no deadline or urgency, you can do it in your own time. Have faith!! Also, prayer is powerful, if you are religious/spiritual and that resonates with you."

175978726,"Hi, I have found that moods ebb and flow with time, depending on life circumstances. However, when there is a prolonged feeling of being down, listless, not caring about anything, or a feeling of emptiness inside, it is depression. There are treatments that really work. Depression is often due a chemical imbalance in your brain that can be addressed with the right medication. It is no different than getting a pair of glasses to be able to see clearly. I strongly encourage you to be evaluated by a doctor."

175978785,"Hello Rich: You may have Agoraphobia or you may be Housebound. It can happen with depression or Anxiety. Sometimes when people are usually tired and/or in pain, it may happen then also. The symptoms are somewhat ridiculous sometimes, however. There are supposedly only 3% of the U.S. with this condition. I find that hard to believe. There are most likely way more. Just that the patients don't mention this problem to their Doctors. If you have a disability or are a Senior, you can look on the net in your area to have a volunteer walk with you to a park or to visit someone nearby, etc. There are also volunteer drivers which you would pay a small amount to go a certain distance. Usually, cheaper than a Taxi, to pick up groceries or buy clothing, go to medical appointments, play cards at a Senior's center, etc. I know that it is easier with your own vehicle but if you don't want to be caught up in traffic( I don't blame you), it would be another resource. 175978873,"_AT_MENTION_ I think maybe ""agnostic"" was the wrong word. Perhaps ""vested interest"" would have made my point more clear. Most people say they want truth or an additional perspective, but what they want is for that to be their truth and their perspective. A good teacher, indeed a good thinker, is a person able to argue in favour of something they don't believe in. Knowing something to be right is the first indication that it's probably wrong; that you lack the whole perspective, as nothing is 100% true or right. Things are only right in context and people seem to be less interested in context. Someone once showed me an idea they used to convey perspective. They showed three people a photo of the same object, although no one could see the other's image. They were then asked questions about the object and none of them could agree on how many sides or shape etc. One saw a triangle, one saw a square and one a rectangle. In essence, they'd all been looking at a wedge of cheese, but the photo was take
n from different angles. There was no way that they would agree, as they were all 100% convinced that they were describing what they saw. What was missing was context, but the only way they could agree was for one of them to ""let go"" of their perspective and step over to the other so that they could see what the other person was seeing, making it clear. One of the most important things we possess is our opinion, but the value of the opinion has been lost to many through the idea of ""it's just my opinion,"" offered in such a way that it can be dismissed as having transient relevance. If an opinion is researched, placed in context and delivered with conviction then it's the most powerful tool a person can wield, but like all tools it needs to be carefully honed and used with care, precision and effect."

Ask your therapist about mindfulness or go to mindful.org. There are a lot of things that can help you there. I hope that the CBT helps. I had a book on it called ""Feeling Good"" by Dr. _NAME_. 175978900,"Yes, you can feel moments of anxiety that become bothersome and still push through it. There should be more awareness about feeling the way you described, especially at your age. I'm not a Dr. - you just happen to sound like me when I was your age. Try simple things first like changing types of food/caffeine intake and refined sugars and salt. Stay hydrated enough with electrolytes and see how you feel in a few days. Emotionally sensitive types can have hypersensitivity and make adrenaline like no body's business. Again, just speaking generally and from my lifelong experience with coping, having high energy, overthinking, when being alone isn't fun. All of those attributes can be used in a good way too. You sound like you are very smart and know your body. Hormones will fluctuate and I think the next few years should balance out for you. Also, never feel weak to talk with a counselor or at least journal."

175978920,"@ juli_raven8 - Thank you for the compliment and I understand what you mean, how for some the medication is necessity, but is it always? Sometimes. Sometimes not. (half of a half is pretty good!!). I do similar to you with what keeps some edge off. The _USER_ID_ placed upon mental health in America largely comes out of that fear of judgment you speak of... the looks and whispers one imagines (or not). It's time to step up and own it all without shame. The world is ill and depressed and discouraged and dismayed. If we, as individuals are then it should be no surprise, and it's okay to be struggling, to need comfort and support, but we must also look to ourselves and own our self-responsibility to not give up on ourselves, to not quit failing and falling and getting back up and try again and again. Needy is human but not insurmountable. This is not a one and done thing, it's life maintenance. And I think that people are less judgmental than appears. Family, friends, and strangers alike are dealing wi
th their issues, insecurities and fears at the same time regardless. I've found that not only talking to strangers rather than those close to us often can be a more mutually receptive environment because everyone can relate (theoretically) and is why this format and forum takes a lot of that pressure and anxiety away. When I say reach out to those that one loves or loves you, it's not to lay all the baggage at their feet, it's to do the good one can for themselves by showing others care and empathy, whether they requested it or not and even if you, yourself might need it more. It's for the giver as much as the receiver. The act of healing for others is, in fact. part of healing oneself. And then the of unpacking of a more unwieldy suitcase of emotions becomes a little easier for all. So, to me all your observations are spot on juli_raven, but we as individuals, as a country, and world collective community must not forget self-healing is required work for any steps towards significant recovery from the traumas 
of life. Own it and carry on without fear even if it's scary. We must be warriors for ourselves everyday. If not us, then who? - cres"

175978961,"I'm so sorry to hear you are going through this. COVID is already not easy and for young people, it can make a difficult situation even worse. It seems like you're doing the right things, limiting screen time, exercising. Keep that up as that all helps. Is there something you enjoy doing before bed that will relax and soothe you? Perhaps listening to music, writing, drawing, or reading a book? I always curl up with a good book so that I can hopefully drift to sleep. If the anxiety wakes me up during the night however, it's hard and I have to pray. I use Psalms 94:19 to help me get through: ""When anxieties overwhelmed me, You comforted and soothed me."" It helps to have that outlet. If you're not religious however, the Scripture can still apply that it would help to find someone to talk to, someone comforting, kind, and patient so that you have an outlet to explain your feelings. Perhaps a friend or another family member? I hope you find some relief from your anxiety and peace of mind. Best wishes.

175978963,"Hello onlyitj: I noticed this is your first post here on PC. So... welcome to Psych Central. I'm sorry you find yourself to be in such a difficult situation. Hopefully coming here to PC can be of some comfort & support. One additional forum, here on PC, that may be of interest to you would be the Partners of People & Caregivers forum. Here's a link: https://psychcentralforums.com/partn...ivers-support/ You asked what you should do along with what will be in the best interest of your children. And how can you make sure you are safe. Unfortunately I have to say I don't think I am in a position to answer those questions. (Perhaps there will be other PC members who will feel they can.) My own thinking, with regard to this, is that what you may want to do is to talk all of this through at-length & in-depth with a mental health therapist of your own. One thing I was unclear about is if your wife is actually being treated at this point for her mental health concerns. You mentioned her having been diagnose
d. But then it sounds as though you moved to a different city. So perhaps she's not longer actively treating? If she is I would think you might want to see if you can make arrangements to consult with her service providers. (You'll likely need her permission to do so.) They are likely to be in the best position to advise you with regard to concerns such as your safety & that of your children. If your wife is not actively treating at this point in time, I would think getting her into active treatment would be imperative. Here are links to 9 articles, from Psych Central's archives, 7 on the subject of coping with someone who has delusions plus 1 on how to convince a loved one to seek professional care & 1 on how to help a loved one who is in denial: 10 Things You Should Know About Delusions | Caregivers, Family & Friends Coping With Your Loved One's Delusions | Caregivers, Family & Friends 8 Ways To Cope With Someone Who Has Delusions | Caregivers, Family & Friends 10 Things You Should Do With Someone Who Suffe
rs Delusions | Caregivers, Family & Friends https://blogs.psychcentral.com/careg...dium=popular17 https://blogs.psychcentral.com/careg...dium=popular17 https://blogs.psychcentral.com/careg...dium=popular17 https://psychcentral.com/blog/how-to...dium=popular17 https://psychcentral.com/blog/11-way...-denial/?all=1 I hope you find PC to be of benefit."

Where others do too little, I do too much. As our relationship went on, I became more and more... obsessed and jealous and...all the toxic stuff, that you don't want to... She knows that...and tells me that it is cute that I want her so badly, and that she wants me just as bad...and there is the breaking point. I just know, she can't... She is always so lovely...but when she's having a bad day or so...she can be quite a drag
on...and that makes me feel worse than others would experience it...When I ask something and she semi-sarcastically answers and I just feel dumb...she makes me feel dumb...or when I ask her how she is doing, and...she doesn't ask back...that just makes me feel like she is not at all interested and doesn't really care? We both agreed on, that friends are something we don't like having, and that we only need each other...but over time she has made so many different friends, and even got in touch and hung out with a former friend of hers, whilst I'm sitting here, not feeling the desire to be with anyone but her. She is my world, she is my everything...every thought is her and she is in everything I do...and not receiving that back..hurts. If something as minor as not being asked how my day was, happens, my whole day is trashed, and I just feel in the mood to just lay around and...start crying? Yeah, it's not good...it's unhealthy...and this issue is about me, and not about her. I take things way too personal...b
ut I feel so pointless, it makes me feel so worthless...I hurt...and constantly think about...just ending my suffering... I have no idea where to go from here. I want to end this relationship, and stay alone for the rest of my life, so I stop putting grief on others, but on the other hand...I NEED her...she gives me reason...she gives me purpose...and I wouldn't know if I could do without her...which is also kind of sick, if you ask me... Is there anything...I can do? I want this to stop...or else by chance things might turn a way I rather not want them to go..."

175979152,"I just read this in a different forum somewhere. Reminded me of my post. Hopefully it helps your mum. ""Generics are cheaper because they aren’t the brand name formula, and many people ARE sensitive to the different “inert ingredients” different manufacturers use. If changes occur with a change in manufacturers of a generic ask the pharmacist to refill with the previous manufacturer, and if switching to a generic from the brand name causes problems ask your doctor to write for the “brand name only”, documenting the problems. Insurance will often approve the brand name for this reason. They just insist that the generic be tried."""

ntinuous"", is also specified. While I am not constantly in crisis, my connection to ""consensus reality"" is at most extremely tenuous at best. 175979177,"I might have OCD or GAD, depending on who you ask. Maybe both. This is my usual pattern: I do something, then later I regret it, then castigate myself for it, and worry intensely about the consequences. (I also tend to ruminate; that is replay the events over and over and over again in my mind) I’ve suffered from this for more than a decade, episodically. But these days, I am going through a particularly bad stretch which has now been going on for about 15 months. Some of the things I worry about are health related. But other stuff too. I’ve tried therapy, with a highly regarded (and very expensive) psychologist, medication, meditation and a couple of other things. Nothing has worked. For now, I am off the medication because it was not helping. I do have Klonopin and Xanax, but I take those only on extremely rare occasion, and then in very small doses, because I do not want to get addicted Exercise provides a short term temporary reprieve. But an hour later, the anxiety is back again. When I am 
hard at work, I also get a reprieve from the anxiety. But that’s not a great solution because I really don’t wanna work 12 hours a day seven days a week! In many ways, I am very fortunate. I have a good job, enough money that I do not have to worry about money, a nice house, a great family, friends, etc. but the intense and almost ever present anxiety that I suffer from makes it hard for me to enjoy my life. 175979209,"Hi _PERSON_, This is a brave post, and I love your dedication to your marriage. There is a lot to be said for that I have known my husband for 12 years, married for 6, and doting mother for 5. It’s been wonderful, but we can be haunted by my mood swings and internal battles with depression. Recently diagnosed with bi-polar disorder, I have been a challenge (to say the least) and am guilty of running away from my husband, hurting with words, paranoid, low lows, and high highs. I once made a budget for an entire two year period... and thought I could write a novel at the same time (I don’t write lol). Now that I am well medicated, and working through nutritional improvement, activity improvement, and step by step therapy I feel like my eyes are just starting to peel over the fishbowl and see the world. This took work, dedication.., and personal accountability; despite the overwhelming guilt. As my husband and I work through this, one strong peace of advice comes to mind. You are a caregiver, and 
you can’t forget about you. You can’t fight the hidden world of somebody’s mind, and you can’t do it alone. And, to a certain extent, neither can your wife. Burnout on both ends can be catastrophic in both worlds. Often times my husband used to try and pacify me, or just fix it, and when I was in a state of mania... there was no coming back. My reason was gone, sanity was gone, and my kindness was gone. And it was never his fault (no matter how much my I told him it was). So I guess what I’m trying to say, is a healthy caregiver is a good caregiver don’t forget about your own mental health, and reach out to services to try and understand not only what your wife is feeling, but what you’re feeling. I know that sounds like a tall order, but it’s worth it to make sure everyone is ok Bi-polar can be incredibly unpredictable, and in that world help and healing is a strenuous and daunting process. Some of the musts got us: Complete transparency with each other and doctors (they’ve heard it all) Nu
trition changes- we eat 90% plants ( my husband says if you want to feel like sunshine you have to eat sunshine haha) Well balanced meds Working out Hygiene lists and daily task lists ( I need reminders for everything) so, even when I’m down I know I need to brush my teeth Talk therapy And most importantly- sleep. The manic get worse with no sleep For what it’s worth... I used to run because I was terrified of being alone. Strange lol."

175979327,"Hello HealingWell-ers. I realise that this is an old thread but I thought I'd share my experience with the same visual issue that's discussed here. I first began to notice some odd trails as I walked past objects in my peripheral vision. I first noticed this about 10 years ago - I was walking to work and as I walked past lamposts or trees I could tell there was some kind of ghosting going on. As it was only in my peripheral I knew it was there but couldn't look directly at it. Soon I also noticed it (as mentioned by someone else in this thread) that it sometimes happened when I walked into a room, as I went through the door frame. I also have the exact same visual issue that has been described in this thread as a milky shadow playing catchup. In the right conditions (for some reason dim light and after waking up) I can move my hand Infront of my face and clearly see a trail of some kind. It is not a motion blur as it is still present no matter how slowly (or fast) I move my hand. Sometimes, as also 
mentioned in this thread, I will catch it happening if I go to pick something up with my arm. My history is that I suffer from anxiety and depression. I take anti-deppresants. I have not taken illegal drugs since I was 17 but experimented with LSD twice (I am currently 42). It doesn't seem to be drug related as most people here have never taken drugs. Last summer I had a Stroke but I know this is not related as I noticed the visual issues many years prior to that happening - I am due to have a hole in my heart closed in the next few months (apparently this was likely the cause of the Stroke). I have astigmatism and wear glasses to correct it. 99% of the time I have no issues with my vision but every so often these symptoms seem to show their ugly face. Keep well."

175979348,"MV., Vistaril/hydroxyzine (prescript ion antihistamine taken off label for anxiety) can be a great alternative to a benzodiazepine. It is taken PRN for times of acute anxiety/panic just like a benzo, but does not carry the risk of dependency. The downside is that the efficacy may not quite match that of a benzodiazepine, and some have reported that the sedation effect was too strong for functioning well during the day... ...but everyone has a different experience and needs, so I absolutely think it is worth trying! It could be just what you need for your management regimen! Let us know what you decide and how it goes if you do give this Rx a try! S.C."

175979369,"What you grapple with regularly sounds much more challenging than anything I have had to tame within myself. That said, here are some things which have worked and are working for me: Lately, I've been doing the _PERSON_ meditation here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KxgD9En6Vso I have followed the above practice for 17 days expecting nothing , simply 'showing up'. However, for the past few days, my productivity has increased appreciably. This is saying a lot, as I am normally a pitifully disorganized procrastinator who keeps erratic hours. This is by no means my first attempt at meditation--I have repeatedly failed in the past because the challenge of keeping my mind still put me off. The fact that the _PERSON_ video is set to a voice helps immensely . I'm using it to get in the habit of stilling my mind twice a day. After many months, I plan to wean myself from the video and revisit the meditation practices which I found too hard years ago. Personally, I believe that all contemporary famous guru
s, especially since the 1960s, are charlatans and manipulators cashing in on a venerable tradition. To me, _PERSON_ is a pleasant-looking man with an agreeable speaking voice--nothing more. However, the twice daily habit of sitting cross-legged, spine erect , breathing deeply, accompanied by the voice in the video, and largely unencumbered by thoughts, is something I look forward to which calms my mind. Behaving well with the body has frequently helped me to bring my mind under control. You might find _PERSON_ meditation beneficial too. The Power of Now , by _PERSON_ ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Power_of_Now ), also helped me immensely. It's pleasurable to read, accessible without being dumbed-down in any way, and presumes zero knowledge of spiritual practices. I bought a used copy from Amazon.com for under $10. Although I normally have a hard time concentrating long enough to make adequate progress reading, I managed to finish the entire book and found every morsel worthwhile. If you have a library ca
rd, your local public library almost certainly owns it. Many times, experienced meditation practitioners have advised against ""ignoring"" intrusive thoughts. Instead, they have advised passively ""watching"" such thoughts--neither ignoring nor engaging with them--just watching them appear, pass by, and vanish . Getting in the habit of simply quietly watching them. I believe that the ultimate function of this is to wean us of the deeply-entrenched habit of identifying with our thoughts . Illusory thoughts."

I have had many medical conditions throughout my life (starting at the age of 2 days), and still do. But, that is not who I am, it is what has happened to me. ronic. But, I have had years when I am doing well. Even when I am dealing with my medical problems, it is just a part of my day, it is not my day. I am not bi-polar, I have bi-polar. I am seeing a therapist and my shrink regularly. I am eating healthy, getting exercise and taking my meds. I practice my coping mechanisms. I do what I am told to do when I am struggling... but it seems fruitless. When you add having symptoms plus being shown that your medical issues are what defines you to other people, it is hard to want to go on. My ""baseline"" is thinking about suicide and researching it a lot. I look for new ways to die that might be considered an accident, not suicide.... that is normal behavior for me. But right now, I am not researching. I am not planning my funeral (yet another baseline for me). I am just wishing I 
could sleep forever. I could just get ""out""... what ""out"" looks like, I do not know. These thoughts and feelings are known to my care team and family (which IS odd for me because I normally hide it). Thanks for reading my rant. Stay safe and healthy."

175979407,"I was diagnosed with Bipolar I two years ago. Was hospitalized numerous times, once for 36 days. I can trace my symptoms back to when I was a teenager and it took till my 30s to be properly diagnosed and treated. But I’m still not where I want to be, and I don’t know if things will still get better, what my ‘normal’ is or if another dreaded relapse is just around the corner. My symptoms leading up to this are all textbook...and I was treated for years with heavy duty antidepressants before those medications finally contributed to my severe and uncontrollable manic episode, thus requiring hospitalization and med changes due to my diagnosis. My symptoms of mania were also classic - spending sprees, erratic speech, not sleeping or eating for days, 1000 amazing ideas I wanted to do but never finished one, thinking I was psychic and wanting to be a famous singer. I had people who I thought were friends take advantage of me and steal from me, even when they could recognize I was sick. And I was a
lso highly irritable and took it out, over the years, on almost everyone that is close to me, and I hurt so many people. The worst part is having the judgement from those who don’t understand and the guilt about things you’ve done and said when a lot of them you don’t even remember because you were so sick. And trying to repair the damage done from an illness that created a monster... The knowing that this is a life sentence that requires lifelong medications that you hope and pray will keep you stable, and feeling that you don’t even really know who you actually are anymore, because you’ve been plagued for so long... I want to believe in happy endings and choose to fight. I want to spread the word to end the stigmas and educate those who haven’t a clue. I want to help others as others have helped me and make a difference. I want to thrive and to survive. And I hope anyone else struggling or dealing with someone struggling can try to be gentle and compassionate with themselves and others because t
his illness is not a choice. You never know how strong you are until being strong is your only choice to survive."

175979446,"I did have that general recurring feeling for about half a year, ""coincidentally"" starting right after the last presidential elections here. I think it's very much a normal reaction to a highly abnormal state of affairs, and it doesn't have much to do with what mental conditions you do or don't have. It went away with time and active distractions. It's essentially a mourning process. Okay let's go over those other bullet points one by one then: That's an obsessive thought pattern. Obsessiveness may or may not be present, but it's not part of the usual descriptions or definitions of SPD in any way, it's just something else. It is part of StPD, and the distinction between SPD and StPD is arguably arbitrary, but even when it comes to StPD, there's a subtle but significant difference: the person's level of enjoyment and engagement is lacking regardless of whether they've been obsessive lately. If anything, that ""search for a bigger meaning"" happens because of that persistent lack of enjoyment rathe
r than the other way around. This is a dogmatic way of thinking. Again not particularly related or unrelated to SPD, I think (more common and specific to the slightly more distant cluster-A relative, PPD). The ""futility"" part kinda touches on it, but it has a strong and specific connotation that won't necessarily be there in reality. ""Changes in anything are moot"" would be a more characteristic belief. This specifically implies a changing state. ""Becoming"" disconnected and isolated rather than ""being"" disconnected and isolated. Again subtle but significant. Kinda sounds like a rephrasing of the previous point, except for the ""completely different level"" thing. That feeling may be common in SPD (don't know if it is), but it's not specific to it and it's not integral to it. ""Just something else"", like the obsessiveness from the first point. Again the ""being"" versus ""becoming"". If you have low motivation to do things you normally do, that means that having motivation to do those things is (or was
, until recently) ""your normal"". It specifically implies a break from a ""normal"" baseline. Good-old existential crisis. I don't get why you connect this one to SPD. Suicidality is unsurprisingly associated with mental disorders in general and with anything that alienates you from society no matter the cause, but I don't see any particular link to SPD (unlike, say, BPD). The main thread connecting all these points is the ""becoming rather than being"". It's not trying to describe what someone may be like, it's trying to describe what someone may be going through. Well the Dalai Lama is a public figure. You don't see monks giving talks and interviews, and you don't see the Dalai Lama doing anything other than that. Not really a fair comparison. Neither is representative of ""Buddhists"" in general anyway."

175979508,"You can look that up on your computer when you get home from work or on weekends. If you know an attorney, you can contact them by computer. You can write down the ones who work in the category you are interested in: wrongful death, might be a guess, or ""cause of death"" or something. After getting a list of 4 or 5 attorneys, and writing down their address, phone number and email address, you can pick the top one you want and contact that person. You can choose a male or female attorney. They will surely have an email address, and ask them if they handle your type of legal concern. 175979530,"No. Guess I'll die and you'll live A lot of scientists have said a lot of things, for example, that the fat content of food, and not high fructose corn syrup, was responsible for obesity. Many of the things scientists say are subsequently debunked. Unfortunately, unless one knows for oneself (i.e. are you one of those scientists?) the details of a specific issue, it's almost impossible to distinguish truth from what is nothing more than paid advertising. One thing I do, however, know, is that to be a ""scientist"" nowadays typically requires a great deal of funding. And that funding comes from somewhere, typically from someone with a vested interest in the lab results. It is not unheard-of where scientists who did not deliver their sponsors' desired results not only lost their funding but had their careers ruined."

175979534,"Additionally, there is a point I must disagree with Speedwalker on and that is you or anyone being ""past the point of self help"" which could too easily be misinterpreted as "" beyond any help"" or just operating from a viewpoint looking backwards rather than forward. Personally, I think operating from a platform in the positive and proactive is better than doing nothing or operating solely from the negative. This is why I made the entire beginning of my initial reply about how you, _PERSON_, are beginning to take responsibility for yourself by posting, explaining, and reaching out. That's you doing for you in crisis mode. The greater point I try to continue explaining is that it's not just about crisis mode and seeing a doctor or getting on a medication is not a free pass to complain about your state of being without continuing to act upon it for yourself in general. Too many people fall into this way of thinking which does not serve one's best interests. They see a therapist or several and/or go 
from med to med throwing their hands up and pining over why nothing seems to be working without putting the REAL work in to discipline the mind and body to relax and work together. Make no mistake that it is not always made easier by therapists or meds, it all requires WORK you must do for yourself as well. Otherwise you're just throwing money out the window, wasting away, and expecting wine from water out of meds and therapy if you'll pardon the metaphor. ~ cres"

175979704,"I get that. Interestingly, a song can be ""playing"" and still slip out of the forefront of my consciousness: I'll be aware of it for the first few minutes, but if I get distracted some way, it will continue playing, but I will barely be aware of it. Once the distraction passes and I return to the default state I was in, the song will resume as if it never stopped. It's almost as if the music plays in real time. I attribute this to the inner idiot-savant that has, on occasions far too often to be chalked up to coincidence, allowed me to open a book to the exact page I was looking for or to know exactly what time my clock will read when I wake up in the middle of the night. Sometimes songs hijack my head. If I'm in the grocery store and am some soft rock song I never much cared for is playing, I'll keep hearing it for the rest of the afternoon. I consider this to be a nefarious form of psychic surgery. It's intrusive, manipulative and should be illegal. Heed the lyrics! It could be your subconscious 
trying to tell you something."

175979709,"Hi AM and welcome to the A/P! I am sorry to hear of the past struggles you have had with your health...and the understandable anxiety that it has left in its wake. It is not unusual for an illness to be the catalyst for anxiety...especially if it was a preexisting sort of issue waiting for a trigger of sorts. The good news is that you have come very far in your journey, but wanting to feel your absolute best is of course the goal...so I am glad you are not complacent with how things are at this point...and are looking for more answers. Stress in and of itself is a normal human condition, and not always a negative thing. It keeps us sharp and motivated. It ensures we do what needs to be done, and is part of a healthy and necessary state of being. However, when it gets to the point where it affects our quality of life, or we can no longer function because it has reached toxic levels, then of course, it is time to seek help. You mentioned being on medication, but not having a very good experience, so 
not wanting to go down that path again is understandable. Have you tried the other two most reliable treatment options, therapy and self help? If not, I can't urge you enough to do so. You can find the latter at the top of our forum page in our Resources. There is lot of great material to be found there, so do have a look... ...and talk to your doctor about the therapy option. Working with a mental health specialist could help give you the tools to help manage your stress. Keep posting with us as well if you find it helpful. We understand, care and support is key! _PERSON_ Cat"

175979751,"Hi _PERSON_. My name is _PERSON_. This is also my first time on this page but your post just spoke to me and I couldn't let it go. I'm 27 now and struggle with bipolar disorder. I can sympathize with what you are going through because I have some of the same thoughts and feelings that you are describing. They started when I was very young and it wasn't until I got help that I knew why I was having these thoughts and feelings. I am a very blunt person and believe lies are just some BS to hide behind. Trust me when I say I will be real and not lie to you. While I still struggle with my gender identity, harmful thoughts and my emotions it does get better! I finally decided to get help after two suicide attempts. Please don't let it get that far for you. I finally decided that it was time to get help and things got so much better for me. I was diagnosed with bipolar disorder. I got on my medication and I am in therapy once a week. The fear that you talk about seems like the same things I thought. I tho
ught if I got diagnosed then people would think I was crazy and all the other _USER_ID_ that goes along with mental illness. BUT...that fear is just the negative thoughts winning. The fact that you are posting on here shows that you want help. You have taken a big step. Now it is time to reach out and get the help that you may need from mental health professionals. The nice part is that you are old enough that your parents don't even have to know that you are going to get this help. If you decide that they need to know then you have the freedom to let that be your choice. I'm not saying it won't be hard. Mental illness is hard. That's not to say that it isn't worth fighting. In the meantime there is an app that I use called Calm Harm. It helps give you distractions so that you can calm yourself and ride the wave so that you don't feel the need to self harm as much. Keep fighting and keep fucking going. We are here if you need us."

175979811,"Thanks for your note, ForeverPositive. (I like your name...) I might try medication but there are so many different ones, and the trial and error process can take a long time, and then there are the side effects... If I were retired, I might be able to deal easier with the side effects. I started on 10mg but I could not deal with the side effects, so I reduced to 5mg. At that point the side effects disappeared but I think it was a subtheraputic dose and was not doing anything. 175979871,"That overbearing and neglectful leads to ambivalent binding is well known in psychology. May also lead to borderline disorder, showing this ambivalence. But the main cause in all disorders is a trauma in early childhood (age 1,5 to 3) which results in a complex PTSD. In a normal neurological development you would learn in that age from your primary caregiver(!) to autoregulate your emotions. Although it's learned in a brain area that does not know speech or rational thinking, but only emotions, it's a kind of internal mother that is always present to calm you down when something frightening happens: ""Calm down. Mother is here. You are safe"". In order to internalize this, you need emotional experience at that age (later you don't remember) and a mother/primary caregiver who calms you right at the moment you experience it. If you don't, you will never learn, because the time window of brain developement is closed and brain developement goes on. No matter if your parents are overbearing or neglectfu
l, in both cases you don't learn to autoregulate your emotions. And you will suffer the rest of your life - pychologically and physically, including many social problems. And all ""discorders"" are just compensations of that. You develop them to get along with life. They are a cure, not a problem. But of course neurotypic people do see this differently, as you don't fit into society like they do."

175979884,"I am a long time marijuana user and began for weight loss due to cancer. It was that or a feeding tube. Disclosure: I am no expert and can only relate my own experience to you. I carefully experimented with what worked and what did not. I am extremely vigilant to make sure I know exactly what I am using. I learned that using any type of Sativa made my anxiousness skyrocket and I cried hard on and off for no apparent reason. That took about a year. It was before commercialization and it was under a doctor's supervision. I now choose ONLY an Indica or heavy leaning Indica Hybrid. My anxiety level decreases and my mood brightens. I am calm and can eat. I found it extremely important to make sure my environment is a place I can focus. I don't rush and imagine an inhale of medicine and an exhale of toxins. I allow myself to feel my muscles release. I have ADHD and for me I need a distraction close by. I avoid all things stressful, like knitting - I'm terrible! I do like TV, reading paper books since I a
m tactile, I also do industrial art. Anything that keeps me relaxed and I'm doing something I like. I use only as much as I need to relax. What helps me is to take a small pull on my device, then take a deep inhales, hold it in my lungs and slowly exhale. I do this laying down so I don't become dizzy. I remind myself it is OK to do this for a positive purpose and I have that mindset of what I want to experience."

Have you mentioned these feelings to your therapist? A few things I’d recommend: - Face time/message your loved ones often – you’ll feel more connected, 
especially with them moving soon - Have alarms set and a schedule, as if this virus didn’t exist. Set an alarm to wake up, have breakfast, get dressed for the day, have your morning coffee, laundry, cleaning, etc. This will help you to feel like life is more normal, since your body is used to the usual things you used to do every day. - Find a hobby to keep you busy when you’re at home - Playing a virtual game with family/friends – something like Yahtzee, Uno, etc. Also, finding things to do to calm your anxiety could be: listening to calming instrumentals, coloring, spending time cuddling with your cat, knitting, praying, reading, journaling, having a bath with a bath bomb, etc. just to name a few. Find what works for you, make a list so you can turn to the list whenever you have time or when your anxiety increases! Thank you for reaching out, I hope something I have suggested will help you. Keep fighting, you’ve got this! xx"

175979991,Wow I'm learning about stimulant-antipsychotic dopamine theories. It's extremely interesting. Stimulants increase dopamine and cause tolerance over time. Antipsychotics increase dopamine but cause intolerance over time. Using them both together cancels each other out yet still increases dopamine so you don't build tolerance to either. People with ADHD have larger bursts of dopamine but lower dopamine in synapses.

175980048,"First check his medicaid program to see if these treatments would be covered by his current NY Medicaid anyway. You could also check the Medicaid program in NJ, and see if they are any more generous than NY. Each state runs its own Medicaid program, with federal 'block grant' funds and their own contributions. I would suspect NY would be more generous because the state is bigger and may have more funds. If NY is more generous, maybe he should keep or establish residence in NY. If NJ is more generous, he could establish residency with you. He could try to fudge it, but penalties for fraud are serious. Lastly, SSDI is a federal program, so it won't matter which state he lives in to keep it. I've considered moving to a next state over for housing purposes, but i would not risk losing my current state's Medicaid program."

175980116,"Hi LMD...I too have recently had to deal with sleeplessness due to anxiety. What helped me was reciting a quote I got from one of the links in the resources section namely, 'Stop! 175980127,"Session with Dr. _PERSON_ went okay yesterday. It is weird doing telehealth with him sort of because I have never seen him in person. Whereas with Pdoc I've seen him in person and regular T does phone calls only or in person. He kept reminding me that I have a thought disorder (schizoaffective disorder depressed type) and that some of my thoughts may not be real. This totally confounds me. I mean I *have* them so how can they not be real? I mean, they certainly exist. I'll give an example. Sometimes there is a demon in my head and he tells me things mostly things like to hurt myself. But he isn't always there. And his voice is inside not outside which is how I know he is in my head. I have voices that are outside of my head and they are not in my head but I hear them. But he is in my head because the voice is inside of my head. He said lets just suppose this isn't real. He said some people think they can communicate with aliens or that the CIA is after them (who knows, maybe they are!) and how that 
isn't real. Now I don't know if aliens exist but if people think they can talk to them, maybe they can. And the CIA well who knows what they are up to. I generally think my life is far too boring for the CIA to be after me personally. Like I think they have other suspects that have much more interesting lives. But who knows, since I was hospitalized IP maybe they do have me on some sort of watch list and monitor my movements. If so they have a very boring job because I go to work, Target, home, Del Taco, and Church. Pretty boring. Back to the demon thing. Most of ya'll know that I am very religious. I believe in Angels and so I believe in their counterpart, Demons. To say they aren't real goes against some pretty ingrained religious beliefs that I have, which are not likely to change. Actually he didn't say they didn't exist. He said the opposite of good is not evil, it's the absence of good. But I don't know that I believe that either. Too much fire and brimstone in my religious background. So he said when I 
have a demon in my head then I am supposed to think good thought and if I can't think good thoughts I am supposed to read good thoughts. Like affirmations or a religious text. Ha. I should read _NAME_ or Revelations. That's a religious text but one that scares the bejeebies out of me. He said if I was Catholic I could have an exorcism. I told him I'm not Catholic and that my denomination doesn't do exorcisms. But doesn't that mean that they are real if you have to do something to get rid of them? See the whole thing was rather confusing. I do like that we did at least talk about it in some detail. Regular T just skips over stuff like this and I am left feeling like I don't know what to do with it. I'm just not sure what he is trying to tell me. The whole thing was rather confusing. Anyway I see him in two weeks. This time at 4 PM so I won't have to miss any work. I'm happy about that. Comments are okay. I am rather confused on how the whole thing went anyhow. I don't think I could be more confused than I am n
ow. HUGS to anyone who wants them!"

175980179,"I know 2020 has had an awful ripple effect on the mental health of many people, and I'm no different. I've always had a rather unstable mental state, I'd go from being all smiles and upbeat to downtrodden and bleak in a short moment. I'd literally feel like I was being weighed down by my negative energy. Every day I have horrible thoughts about myself, saying that I'm an awful person, that I deserve to die, that everyone would be happier if I was gone. Sometimes I can kick those thoughts. Other times I need to cope with them by joking about it (i.e. jokes about being bad at something or unloved). But some days it just reaches an apex that nothing will solve. I'm also a drinker. I honestly do not believe I am an alcoholic, and I certainly don't display the symptoms associated with alcoholism, but it never helps my thoughts. I'm constantly worried that as time goes on, my reliance on alcohol will grow stronger. The other day, fueled by self-loathing and propelled by lots of alcohol, I prepared to jum
p off of a hotel balcony. Everything just felt so hellish. I always feel like I'm going around in circles, never accomplishing anything. I can never escape myself or my reality. I'm always going to be a panicky, depressive mess who missed out on every good formative experience. I figured, it was too late for me. Thankfully my brother and his girlfriend were there to stop me from jumping off of the balcony. In hindsight it wasn't tall enough, but the intent was clearly there. What feels so awful is that on days where I don't want to die, death terrifies me more than anything. Literally my biggest fear. So I'm caught in this cruel catch-22 where I simultaneously can't stand being alive but also am too scared to die. Except when I'm not. I just want to break the cycle. I just want to actually enjoy life. I just want the nightmare to end."

175980215,"In some parts of the United States snow is already on the ground, in some places it has been for quite a while (hello, _USER_ID_). I do not care for snow. I have lived places with blizzards and they can be fun for a bit but then the dirty slush is left behind and it just feels dirty everywhere. I now live in the South and prefer my winters. I did not see a single snow flake last year and that was perfectly fine with me. Seasonal Affective Disorder, or S.A.D, is a mental condition in which a person’s mood is affected by the season. Although this a condition that can be diagnosed, I believe a lot of people feel the effects of seasonal change, including those of us who live with bipolar disorder. Already with the waning light, I feel more lethargic and sad. This happens every year. My deeper, longer depressive episodes lurk in the shadows of winter. Conversely, my manic and hypomanic states tend to occur in spring and especially summer. Read more here: https://blogs.psychcentral.com/being-bipolar/20
19/11/02/how-light-affects-bipolar-disorder-patients /"
175980216,"Depended on the situation. I did well as a store manager. No one hovering over me, was mostly dealing with training new employees, customer service, and doing my own thing. The owner, when there, was mostly in their office. It was easy and people found me pleasant. However, office setting middle management was a nightmare. The standard employees were fine but the people with power were too much to handle. Always asking for things and wanting more (things I didn't even do), always blaming me for mistakes, always judging me for how I did things and complaining. Once I quit they asked me back. It was ridiculous. I quit the store manager job for essentially the same reason though--hating my boss. Once I spot blood in the water I develop a rich resentment. I guess this is more an antisocial PD thing, issues with authority. I despise all my bosses."

You said she used to use the medication Thiothixene, which webmd.com says, ""Thiothixene is used to treat certain mental/mood disorders (such as schizophrenia). This medicine helps you to think more clearly, feel less nervous, and take part in everyday life. It can reduce aggression and the desire to hurt yourself/others."" When my Dad had cancer, he was diagnosed at a regular hospital. They said he had lung cancer. My dad never smoked or anything. They tried to do a biopsy two or three times but couldn't get a bite out of the tumor. They were going to take out his lung. My Mom was like we are going to City of Hope which is a cancer hospital here in So. Cal. They did their own biopsy and it was not lung cancer, it was Non-Hodgkins lymphoma which had formed in the lung. The other hospital would have taken out the lung and wouldn't have cured the cancer! Plus when they thought it was lung cancer, it was like really bad prognosis. When they found out it was Non-Hodgkins lymphoma stage 2 they were like, you're going to be fine. Chemo. Radiation. 175980318,"I have seen 3 psychiatrists and 1 psych RN. Two of the psychs were very laid back and pretty much said maybe we could try some ssris and maybe they would help,which one would I like to start with. Lexipro caused itching and swelling (no help w/anxiety), Zoloft caused suicidal thoughts (not helpful with anxiety), Prozac at best numbed me a bit, but did not help enough with the anxiety and caused a 30 lb weight gain within 3 months - 4 yrs later, I still have been unable to lose that weight, which has been a major blow to my comfort and self esteem. I was also given Xanax which did/does help w/panic attacks, but isn't a daily med. Psych RN offered medical marijuana - not really helpful for daily anxiety and DR, but has been helpful for my menstrual discomfort. One psych said that she thought I was bipolar (even though I have never had a manic episode and do not experience any big highs) she said she felt this was a possible diagnosis because my reaction to Zoloft (suicidal thoughts) was ""not normal"
". No p-doc has ever addressed any of my physical symptoms. It's usually completely glossed over. I've been reading a lot of books about thyroid health - of all the symptoms I have had, the one thing I have actually been diagnosed with is hypothyroidism, which apparently is tricky because everyone has their own level of thyroid hormones that is best for them. It's also not something that is tested unless you have symptoms - so I have no idea what my levels were when I felt healthy. Also, since the thyroid regulates and is involved with so many different biological functions, it can cause somewhere near 300 different symptoms! The problem is, I can't find a doctor that tests all of the thyroid functions, the gold standard is TSH. And most doctors say if your TSH is within the normal range, you're fine. The normal range is very broad (0.4 - 4.0 or some doctors go by the older standard of 0.5 - 5.0), but a lot of my symptoms seem to be on that long list of things thyroid patients deal with (painful/heavy periods
, anxiety, depression, panic attacks, sore throats, fatigue, feeling cold, exercise intolerance, inability to lose weight, gerd, etc.)."

175980356,"Distractions at work can be a big challenge for adults with various mental health diagonises. Try these steps: 1. Route your calls to voicemail, then check it only at set times during the day. 2. If you work ~ Ask for a quiet cubicle or office at work, so you aren’t distracted by others. ( Tell boss you work better and harder this way! ) 3. Use a ""white noise"" machine or listen to earphones to drown out other sounds at work. 4. Stick to doing just one task at a time . ( This REALLY HELPS! ) Give all of these a try and let us know what works or doesn't work for you! If you want to share why thats great but only if you want to. I use #4 almost always otherwise I would get NOTHING accomplished ever! Tc, _PERSON_"

175980397,"best thing to do is therapy, secondly i'ld try to check for a problematic behavior in the family, it could be a trauma she had been through, it could be a long lasting behavior that maybe you dont even notice, what im saying is that its important to make sure the source of the disorder is not still floating in the house, the reason for the behavior is early childhood-infancy intrusion of privacy, so try to check that field and be honest with yourself for her sake, maybe even try to get an outside opinion, my parents still dont recognize / deny their behavior, so it could be something you aren't aware of. about expectations and pushing - this subject is problemetic, if you push her you might make her do something she isn't interested in doing reluctently, if you dont push her she might not do anything at all, i dont know the situation so i cant know the right thing to do in her case, but what i do know is that you have to notice the implication of your expectations, try to notice when she doesnt wan
t, try to give her a voice because we usually struggle to express our needs, ask her for her opinion, keep in mind you may be asking for her opinion for years untill she might finally develop an opinion, im not talking about an opinion about a future job, but about small things, what food she prefers and so on. on the same note- try to let her feel free to get mad at you, i think anger is the first step of leting things out, the first emotion that pops up, you can do that when for exemple you noticed you did something she didnt like, you may say - does it make you feel a little upset? again, you may ask this question 1000 times before she will actually answer yes. that's all i can think of right now. my answer is only valid if your daughter was diagnosed by a professional."

175980508,"It's like I don't like going to the dentist so much, I try to make sure I don't have any cavities. It's not that I don't like going to the dentist, it's that I can't. In that, with my sensitive ears to noise, the loud steel dentist drill on the hard tooth is only 1-inch from my ear drum, one of the loudest sounds you can imagine. So, I can't get a cavity or they'll have to pull a tooth out. So I reverse engineer it. That is, I don't get any cavities. Hello!!!! I haven't had a cavity in 15 or more years. How do I do that? I don't eat any sugar, which started with a 2nd health condition I have or, sensitive ears to noise, in which, sugar doesn't help that, so I stoppled eating sugar for that reason. So that might be called half the battle. When sugar hurts your health, you'll stop eating sugar, hopefully. I don't eat desserts, sugared-drinks, candy or sweets of any kind. (There's some sugar in canned foods, but i try to rinse it out with water.) I drink a non-sugared drink, it's called water. Whoa, h
ow tough is that? OK, after my meals, I brush my teeth. Very tough. i also rinse very vigorously, meaning squishing the water between my teeth for 5 or 10 seconds to wash out any small items between my teeth. I then floss, to knock out any food particles between my teeth. I then rinse with Listerine Total Care which can kill the germs that cause cavities. Brushing or flossing does not kill germs that are on or between you teeth. And that's where cavities form, between two teeth. Listerine Total Care gets between the teeth and kills germs that cause cavities. Sometimes at night when I'm lying in bed, I'll feel a tingling between two teeth. I know what that is. It's a pre-cavity starting to form. I very often get up right then, floss between the affected area(s), gargle with Listerine Total Care, and the tingling stops. I know what's just happened: the Listerine (and floss) killed the germs that caused the pre-cavity. It's like a miracle. If an hour or two later or the next day the tingling is still there, I re
apply that. It's that or have my teeth pulled, what do you think I'm going to do? (Sometimes I don't floss (or use Listerine) after every meal, but I do rinse with water thoroughly for 5 or 10 seconds. Sometimes I even wait for a tingling between teeth, which might not be a good idea.)"

175980535,"Don't make me come up there. You said, ""Really?? I thought muscle pain cold helps ?"" Are you still breathing? A cold pack on chest pain? My chiropractor told me concerning my bad lower back, I have an extra vertebrae, and it slips out every now and cause me pain and he pops it back in. So he told me, in between visits, to alternate heat and cold on that or most any injured area (not the chest, I would think). So when my back is hurting, I put my heating pad on it and it increases blood flow (more oxygen and nutrients) to the injured area. Moist heat, wringing out a small towel for instance, might work even better, but the towel can't be dripping wet. This for about 10-15 minutes. On my same hurt back, or most other injured areas, after waiting some 10-15 minutes, I can apply a cold pack to the same injured area. This helps to shrink the inflammation. They sell cold pack granules at drug stores that conform to your back, arm, etc., and they stay in the freezer. Might buy two so one can still be in 
the freezer."

175980561,"I don't know if _PERSON_ was specifically researching synchronicity. He was mainly researching mental telepathy. Having subject guess the symbols on these Zener cards. He then analyzed the results after many trials and did a statistical analysis of that to come up with the odds against chance. Out of the 5 cards, random chance would be 20% for a correct guess. I think this is where _PERSON_ saw the connection with synchronicity. Most psychiatrist today believe that thing just happen randomly and there is no hidden meaning behind anything. Most think if you see special meaning in something, that is magical thinking and you need to be on medication. There are a lot of book on Synchronicity now and a lot of people think there is something to it. As far as questioning your beliefs when you mentioned working with a friend, here are 4 simple questions this author _NAME_ came up with. I just copied this off Wikipedia. I don't know if you could use it or not, but I thought I would paste it in here. Specifi
cally. The Work is a way of identifying and questioning any stressful thought. It consists of four questions and a turnaround. The four questions are:[8] Is it true? Can you absolutely know that it's true? How do you react, what happens, when you believe that thought? Who would you be without the thought? The next step of The Work, the turnaround, is a way of experiencing the opposite of the believed thought. For example, the thought ""My husband should listen to me,"" can be turned around to ""I should listen to my husband,"" ""I should listen to myself,"" and ""My husband shouldn't listen to me.""[8] Then one finds specific examples of how each turnaround might be true."

175980566,"about the pinched nerve you say, ""I know I have a pinched nerve in my neck I’m working on getting fixed."" That's very good. You're taking care of yourself. From having a bad back and learning things from the chiropractor, he told me that a heating pad, alternating on the injured area for 15 minutes, some time in between with neither heat or ice applied (30 minutes?), then ice pack on the injured area. I used moist heat, which I find seems to go deeper into the injured area. Wet a small towel or the insert which comes with the pad, and wring it out. Then put the moist pad between the heating pad and the injured area. The heat increases the blood vessels, which bring more oxygen and nutrients to the injured area. The ice pack reduces the inflammation. It works very well on my back. (I also use both on my ears, because I have sensitive ears to noise. But both help calm my ears down.) The name of the ice pack, is the gel pack. For instance, when I used to use ice cubes in a container, they were roc
k hard, but that's all there was back then. This gel, it might look like soup at the store in its warm state, when frozen will better bend around the injured area, and apply more coldness to the skin. Sometimes I only put it on the injured area, like my lower back, for 30 seconds because it's so cold, then move it to another area of my back. It really helps reduce the inflammation and the pain. As far as the anxiety, are your seeing a psychiatrist? If you're taking Xanax, that's only a short- term tranquilizer. Is that from a general practitioner? I think a long term anti-anxiety would be better. Can you see a psychiatrist? As far as the concern, you said, ""I know I don't"" which is a big help. So, it's a big help, also, that you don't have the problem. Maybe that's how your stress is coming out. If you could relieve the stress, maybe you wouldn't have that. As for sleep, I take Melatonin from the health food store. The grocery or drug store health food section might have that. Or it can be ordered over the 
net. Or, the grocery stores that deliver might can deliver it to your house. They deliver every thing else. As for the Melatonin, I would get it in the 1 mg tablets, that way you can get the right dosage. I take 4, 1 mg, 1 to 2 hours before bedtime, which gives them time to take effect. You'll know when they start to take effect, you'll start getting sleepy. I then take 1 more right before I go to bed, to space them. If I wake up at 5 in the a.m. and I'm not sleepy, but have had only 4 or 5 hours of sleep, I can take another one, if I don't have to get up early. If I'm not taking psych medicine, Melatonin doesn't work. But as a bipolar, I take Mirtazapine anti-depressant and Lithium as a stabilizer, with the stabilizer keeping the anti-depressant from sending me into mania."

Are you in love with him or just with him bc you need him financially, physically, emotionally? The reason I ask is sometimes, the person we are with is not the person we should be with. We ""settle"" and than feel life is unfulfilling and that we failed, when the truth is, we become so stuck in the life we are in, that we give up trying to have the life we want. And we can have. If you are with your boyfriend because you can depend on him, he helps you with your daughter, you are afraid to make it on your own, or bc he is taking care of you and you are not in love with him, than it's not fair to you, your daughter or him. If you are in love with him, and he is in love with you, than you have a good foundation to start from. Once you are sure of your true feelings for him, than you can move on one way or another. Think o
f yourself as a beautiful butterfly who is stuck as a caterpillar in a cacoon. Why are you stuck? Is it bc the tree you are in is comfortable and you see no reason to change anything? Is it because if you become a butterfly, you will have to make it on your own and that scares you? Is it because you are afraid if you come out of your cacoon, you might fly into a window fan and get hurt and fail as a butterfly. Is it because you are afraid if you become a butterfly, you might not be able to fly, and then you can't fit back into the cacoon and you will be a caterpillar stuck in a butterflys body? These are metaphors, but you see where I am going? What is keeping you trapped in your cacoon? You have accomplished far more than you realize. And you have many gifts you may not even realize you have. Only you hold the answers. Once you answer why you can't seem to grow and blossom, than you can work on how to get where you want to be. Depression is a part of you like the color of your eyes. Don't push it away. Embra
ce it and use it in whatever you decide to do. There are so many people in this world that have depression and anxiety and panic attacks and refuse to admit it. So, they drink or do drugs to squash the feelings. But that doesn't work. Imagine if they could scream from the tallest mountain ""I'm depressed, anxious, and have panic attacks!! But I am going accept it, and try to make my dreams come true anyways!!"" People would look at them and say ""Good for you!! I'll be there if you need help on your bad days!!"" I did it. And it felt great! And I did things I never thought I could ever do. And you can too. Get into counseling if you can. And work thru this and stay busy. A little each day. It's a comedy and kids can watch, but it has a message in it too. With Bill _NAME_ and _NAME_. Try to find it. You will love it. Good luck honey. You can get out of that c
acoon with baby steps."

175980593,"I was afraid this was coming, paying people based on their health. But now bonuses based on Body Mass Index (BMI) are here. Healthcare costs companies a fortune. 35% of employee compensation is in benefits, and the largest share of that is health insurance. Of course, companies seek to decrease these costs. Annual biometric screenings, a measure of health data collected for each insured person, have become commonplace. Blood tests, health questionnaires and body weight go into a database to be used, say the companies and insurance companies, to recommend ways a person can improve their health. But it’s not a big leap to see the employers and insurance companies using this data to maximize profits by trying to minimize healthcare costs by favoring workers they perceive to be healthier. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/older-bipolar/2019/08/overweight-people-to-be-paid-less/"

175980643,"super20dan said... Xanax should NEVER be used for sleep. fastest way to become addicted. same for klonipin. Z class of drugs can become addictive as well to include Ambien. It would be nice if nobody ever needed benzos and doctors were more knowledgeable and compassionate regarding the prescription and withdrawal effects. Sadly most are not aware or don't care. I was prescribed ativan and like another poster was having inter dose withdrawal symptoms. I found a very nice compassionate doctor and was able to start a taper process. Anyone who is on benzos and wants to reduce or get off try to find a good physcian or psychaitrist. You will most likely have to switch from a fast acting benzo to a slower acting one like valium. Valium can stay in the system for 200 hours as opposed to the half life of ativan and xanax. Once you are stable on the longer lasting benzo you can start a tapering process. The _NAME_ manual was created by a British doctor who noticed all the issues that came when people quit be
nzos cold turkey or were lowering their dose faster than they needed. Some of her initial information is great and some has been improved. There are many forums that are dedicated to benzo taper and withdrawal. It is a double edged sword as you will find lots of nice helpful people and situations similar to your own. You will also read lots of horror stories, symptom lists and encounter a few who let benzos withdrawal define them and they get off on the suffering. So take things with a grain of salt. I hope this information helps someone."

175980668,"Psychiatric medications have come a long way over the years. However, like all pills, psychiatric meds have their trade-offs. They all come with the possibility of unpleasant side effects. That's a big reason why some people with serious forms of mental illness elect to seek professional treatment with psychotherapy without trying medication(s). So is it possible to overcome moderate to severe anxieties, depression, bipolar disorder, and other forms of mental illness with psychotherapy alone...therapy without medication? Maybe. But I wouldn't try it. The thing is, if someone has mental illness, they need to get mentally healthy as quickly as possible. And psychotherapy is a slow process. Also, talk therapy has only limited success. Therefore, I think it's a bad idea to try to overcome serious forms of mental illness with psychotherapy without medication(s)."

175980710,"That wonderful 1991 movie, Paris is Burning , makes this even more explicit. The possibilities seem endless. It is initially easy to feel confused, until we realize that, naturally, each of us is interested only in certain specific 'hats'. Yes, very much so, because it's true. Having been raised for the most part almost diametrically opposed to wisely, I was an impostor for a LONG time. It has taken my whole life so far, and great cost to me and everyone who had to deal with me , for me--one person--to even begin to be genuine, and then only in lucid moments. To some extent, yes, to ""fake it"" in order to survive and have the opportunity wise up (it's an endless process the outcome of which is never a given). No one gets out of here alive, and if we lack the courage to meet and to battle consistently and relentlessly with our most shameful flaws and to free our deepest selves , we will not die satisfied. Code: Select all Regardless of how socially popular we appear, regardless of how good-looking 
we appear and how numerous our sexual conquests, regardless of our income, of our credentials, of our assets, of our job title, of the size of our office, of our community standing, of our celebrity, of our power of life and death over thousands, even millions. Regardless of ALL of that, we have to come 'home' to ourselves. And, if we cannot do that, not much else matters. https://i.imgur.com/VCFNPW7.gif source: https://allpoetry.com/The-Man-in-the-Glass Often, 'an obvious security hole', is a trap While I don't believe emotions are necessary to experience the most important thing in life, I do think a conscience is. Those who maybe lack what's called a conscience, who maybe are born with an inability to feel responsibility, may very well get through this round of the polishing drum called Life unscathed, unaffected, unpolished, un changed , and unimproved . Such people (some believe Bill _NAME_ may be one), such 'winners' on paper, will have experienced a life analogous to endless, meaningless toilet paper y
ardage. Although, maybe even a conscience isn't necessary. It is the stuff that harms our egos and ONLY that stuff that transforms us for the better, and if we lack the ability to respond bravely to harsh Reality, we will miss entirely the purpose of existence. But there is always next time. Everyone will get there eventually . And when we do, I believe that we will 'each' look back on 'THIS' with a chuckle, although I'll be d***_NAME_ if I always remember this . --> It's one thing to realize this and QUITE another to ACT CONSISTENTLY ACCORDING to this awareness .
