175980729,"I have to tell you what happened today. First, a little history. I had a break about a month ago and thought the neighbor upstairs was plotting and making obnoxious noises. I heard two people, a man and a woman, upstairs OK? Well at the apex of the break I ""talked"" to my neighbors through the ceiling. Kinda let a lot of things off my chest. A month goes by I'm getting better and I decide to write a letter of apology to my neighbors for the unkind things I had unleashed on them. I left the letter and a gift from Amazon at their door. BTW the gift was a crock pot....who wouldn't want one of those Afternoon of the same day I hear a hard knock on my door and answer it. A big fellow holding the box with crock pot and my opened letter says it must be a mistake...the letter didn't make sense. When I asked him about the woman upstairs he said he didn't have a girlfriend. It dawned on me that it was all a big psychotic SNAFU. I had had auditory hallucinations for months which had a man and woman as the pl
ayers. So the crackpot downstairs is giving the crockpot to her brother. I feel better....."
174375896,"Hello all, I know this is a small subset of the forum and in my last post I already mentioned that I haven't been here in a while. I guess I just have had some things on my mind that I wanted to share some how and it makes me feel somewhat emotionally alleviated if I post here. I have really been struggling a lot lately with constant voices and coded messages to the point where it is disrupting my daily life. I deal with this on a regular basis, but normally I am able to muster the energy it takes to ignore the noise and chaos in my mind and do what I need to do to live. I guess the reason I wanted to post here is because every so often, I feel like I get the message from people that they think I am somehow lesser of a person or stupid because I say I am lonely and don't have friends in real life and I often find support from people on the Internet, most of whom I've not actually met and can't verify if they're who they say they are. I follow some other schizo communities and sometimes I hear comme
nts that schizo people should just ""get out there and be more social."" I know that that is probably in frustration to seeing those with mental illness struggle with isolation and depression. However, it frustrates me because it's really ignorant. The thing about socialization in the real world is that it takes time, energy, and effort, for the normal, average person. Some schizo people might have a lot of time, if they are on disability or don't have to work. For me, I am already at a disadvantage because so much of my energy is spent on my regular day-to-day duties like caring for my children and home and working part time. But in addition to that, I think that people don't understand how exhausting social interaction can be when you are constantly fighting to ignore or silence voices in your head, or feeling paranoid and seeing signs and codes and threatening messages everywhere. The truth is, first, it can be hard to even find friends as a normal adult. Second, most normal adults are either scared/unsett
led by psychosis, or they don't understand how to talk to someone who is struggling with it so it makes them uncomfortable. So I don't normally even disclose my mental health issues to people who are new friends, because I don't want to scare or burden them. For me personally, it is extremely difficult to be in an environment where there are several conversations going on at once or there is a lot of fast verbal ""back and forth"" and noise. It makes my wires feel crossed and it agitates me to the point where I start feeling violent and want to lash out at people. I try to avoid this situation at all costs because I have learned to manage myself and I want to be a good friend, coworker, parent, etc. The reasons why it's often just not possible to say, ""hey cool, i'll get off the Internet and go make friends"" as a schizo person is because every time I go out to do something fun that regular people do, I risk the chances of putting myself in a situation where I cannot control what is happening and I needlessl
y make a scene, embarrass others, or have to rely on others or end up in a costly hospital stay. Or, I risk the chance that it takes so much energy to engage in social interaction that I don't have enough left over to care for myself properly and make sure my bills are paid and my family is fed. Additionally, with mental illness, there are so many times that you cannot predict whether you will be capable of doing something that you promised to do. I know that depression can literally make my body feel achy and weak, or that my mental illness takes such a toll on my physical state that I have to lay in bed and just watch Youtube or sleep for hours to recover enough to manage getting out of bed. There have been times that I volunteered to work with nonprofits or community groups and was really excited to help, and had to cancel because I just did not have the capabilities at the time of the event. It was sad and frustrating and embarrassing for me, but because of situations like that, I have learned to be reall
y cautious. When I see others having fun, I often feel lonely and I wish that I could just be outgoing and make a bunch of friends and go do things together. But the reality is that, in terms of what is socially expected of a friend, I would make a really terrible one because I cannot be relied upon or dependable. I don't have any control over times that I am just not able to keep appointments I have set. For these reasons, online mental health communities are really beneficial. There are other reasons, as well. For instance, regular friends shouldn't be relied upon constantly to be your only source of support, or they will burn out. That is not fair to do to any one person. If you make friends with a lot of people online who understand, generally, mental illness, then you can rely on several people, and you can also provide support for them in return when they need it. Not only that, but many times, I might need to talk to someone at really weird hours in the middle of the night, and it would be rude to regu
larly call an IRL friend for that kind of thing. Additionally, sometimes staying distracted can help and posting on forums or chatting with others can take your mind off of voices and things that are bothering you, without just sitting in a room alone and going insane. But if you are really tired, or if something is triggering you, you also have the option to shut the computer and sleep or go for a walk, and care for yourself in the best way that you can without offending people. Obviously if I invite a friend over for the afternoon, I can't just disappear to practice self care. The threats of being homeless, being destitute, losing loved ones, or ending your own life can all be very real and very scary threats that those of us with mental illness face on a regular basis. I know that a lot of people think getting support or making friends online is stupid, but for me it has probably many times been the difference between staying alive or committing suicide. I do still feel very lonely, and I do still long for 
real life relationships and activities. But I am really thankful for the connections I have with strangers from other places, because it has allowed me to cope."
175980730,"I went to the bar to have a few drinks. My waiter actually bought a beer for me, that's the 3rd time that has happened at this place. I truly don't understand why they treat me so nicely there. I stay there for 3-4 hours and tip 50% but that's no reason to buy me a drink. They need to save that money for college, seriously. I feel so bad for millennials and younger generations. They are getting screwed by stagnant wages over the past, I thought it was the past 10 years, but it's been the past 20 years. I have to make sure houses and apartments are painted, all drywall finished. I got this."

175980804,"I find that sometimes boredom is good. The reason I say that is because becoming comfortable with being bored, for me at least, is a good skill to have. 175980811,"It is possible your anxiety episodes are a result of thought patterns that are being triggered. You might have to see a therapist to determine what are the triggers that start those thought patterns. If you are not wanting to go that route just yet, maybe find self help or psychology books that are specific to anxiety triggers. If reading is not your thing, try yoga, meditation, and/or mindfulness techniques to see if one can calm your mind. Aging and death is a natural process in life. Those are two things every human being share in common. It is also two things that humans cannot control. Most people with anxiety problems are related to things that they cannot control(other people's actions, aging, death, etc). 175980872,"It is tough to feel like you do. You do deserve to feel loved. This may not apply to your situation, but may give you pause for thought. I show love by doing - making favourite food, organising outings, surprise him with intimate times in places he doesn't expect. I want him to take me out to do something we both like - movies, dinner, hiking with me and he wants more 'one on one' if you get my drift! So neither of us feels loved even though we think we are showing it. Talking is the only way to figure it out, all the best!"

175980890,"By typing into the search engine in the opening page of the browser, ""antidepressants that don't cause lowering of sex drive"" you can see these same results in the opening 8 or 10 topics that come up. I think, too, there are other factors which need to be considered by you and your doctor. What I found was, that the antidepressant Bupropion, sometimes known by its brand name, Wellbutrin, came out at the top in every study. I even anticipated the next problem of weight gain from various such medications, but it said about Bupropion (Wellbutrin) one of the side effects was: weight loss. First, webmd.com cautioned, ""Treat the Depression First"" in that ""Whatever is happening with your sex life, it's important to treat depression first. Address any sexual side effects later."" *One website, in an article written by _NAME_ Block at www.jennyonthepage.com said “In fact, antidepressants in the SSRI family (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) are known to cause low libido. Prozac, Zoloft, Celexa 
and Paxil are all SSRIs and all have been documented as having sexual side effects.” “Changing to Wellbutrin (another antidepressant that works only on dopamine and norepinephrine receptors) or adding it to an SSRI can help counteract sexual side effects,” he said. “Wellbutrin has been shown to have no sexual side effects due to its mechanism of action,” Collom said. In fact, “Wellbutrin can actually increase one’s sex drive.” *www.verywellmind.com suggested 1. Take a Lower Dose and to 2. take the Pill After Sex. *Health.harvard.edu More sexual side effects: citalopram (Celexa); fluoxetine (Prozac); paroxetine (Paxil); sertraline (Zoloft) less sexual side effects: bupropion (Wellbutrin); duloxetine (Cymbalta); mirtazapine (Remeron) *psychcentral.com A 2001 study out of the University of _NAME_ said ""serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs, such as Paxil or Zoloft) and serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs, such as Effexor and Cymbalta) were associated with a higher rate of sexu
al dysfunction, other antidepressants were associated with significantly lower rates, namely bupropion (Wellbutrin) and nefazodone (Serzone)."" ""Wellbutrin, the brand name of bupropion, had the lowest overall rate of sexual dysfunction. It was associated with a rate of 22% of the overall population."" *psychologytoday.com Wellbutrin is just as effective as the most popular class of antidepressants, the SSRIs (Prozac, Paxil, Zoloft, Celexa, Lexapro, Luvox). Its nonsexual side effects are no worse, and it’s unlikely to cause sexual side effects *Livestrong.com Bupropion, sometimes known by its brand name, Wellbutrin, is an antidepressant...Side effects relating to sexual dysfunction do not occur; however, headaches, weight loss and nausea may be potential side effects that patients should be aware of when taking this medication. Mirtazapine is another kind of antidepressant medication...sexual side effects, such as a loss of libido, do not occur while taking this medication, but patients may feel dizzy, anxi
ous or confused. Somnolence, or excessive sleepiness, occurs in more than half of patients taking this medication. Venlafaxine is known as a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor--While sexual dysfunction may occur, loss of libido is a rare side effect; according to the medical reference ""UpToDate,"" only about 5 percent of patients will experience this unpleasant effect."

175980897,"Hi. Along with OCD/anxiety issues, I also have reflux and swallowing problems due to Eosinophilic Esophagitis (EOE). I would definitely suggest speaking with your doctor if you continue to experience difficulty swallowing. It could be that you're refluxing which is causing inflammation in your throat. This exact symptom of difficulty swallowing was the reason I went to my doctor a few years back. I did not find out it was also related to having EOE until I had an endoscopy and biopsy which showed that eosinophils were the culprits. You might want to check out books or YouTube videos by two leading reflux experts, Drs. _NAME_ and _NAME_. They have some great advice and plans related to lowering reflux (which you may or may not have) caused by excess acid. You should also keep a food diary to see if any specific foods cause you to have swallowing difficulty. Good luck. I hope it all works out for you."

175980995,"I don't suppose it has to. Or else the ""depression"" part of the name wouldn't be necessary. I think it's easy to understand why it can be linked though. If something has long been part of your understanding of yourself and the way you relate to the world around you, then once you realize you can't rely on that premise anymore (or realize you never should have), it's just like a literal depression in the ground beneath you. You can't just keep walking. Or worse, if it turns out to be a gaping hole under a house you've built or let someone build for yourself. It all comes crashing down, and you're homeless all of a sudden. Yes. Freedom isn't an inherently good thing though. More freedom entails more choice, and choice takes effort. There's a point where you get diminishing returns. The choice of limiting your choices is just as logical as it is inevitably arbitrary. Belief systems are one of the main ways how people limit their burden of choice. The main problem with it is that it's generally impos
ed more than it is voluntarily accepted. The chance of individual incompatibility is high. But then again, the option to freely choose what exact belief system you're bound by (or worse, a sense of urgency to choose it because you currently lack an effective one -- AKA: an existential crisis) is much more daunting than the everyday burdens that a belief system is supposed to relieve you from to begin with. And that's a big part of why people tend to cling to (seemingly obviously) questionable things right up until $#%^ has undeniably hit the fan. Of course you can. Fear doesn't arise out of deliberate contemplation or logical conclusions. It arises out of instinct."

As has been mentioned in the past, it normally really does take skills like a huge degree of adaptability, a capacity for psychological (or emotional) closeness, willingness, ability to trust to any real degree, etc. in order to have and maintain something complex. If those skills are unrealistic, then at least for the time being, one might as well focus on having a pet dog or God or whatever else improves quality of life."

175981037,"Thanks for your response, S. Cat. I will ask the doc about vistaril. I actually tried another first generation antihistamine, Doxylamine (which is OTC), as an alternative to the benzo, one night. I had used Doxylamine in the past, before I was on the Zoloft, on occasion, so I figured I would give it a try (and my doc said its OK to try it). It did put me to sleep but I was very drowsy the whole next day -- the so-called ""hangover effect."" Fortunately that was a Saturday, so did not interfere with work. But still.... Tonight I plan to experiment with half of a Doxylamine pill. I am thinking that might be enough to get me to sleep, but without the hangover effect the next day. In addition to the difficulty falling asleep, I have been waking up very early (515 am or so) and with an uncomfortable activated/agitated/jittery feeling. Last night I tried taking .5mg of the Klonopin rather than .25mg, and I slept better and had much less of the jittery feeling in the morning. (Not zero, but less). The doc 
has approved that dose. But again I am trying to limit my use of the benzo. Of course, none of this is a good long term solution. I need to be able to fall asleep without benzos or antihistimines or sleeping pills, and sleep through the night, and wake up without this very uncomfortable agitated feeling. Time will tell whether these Zoloft sleep-related side effects will dissipate with time, or not. I guess they usually do. But usually is not the same as always, so we will see... You also mentioned the possibility of increases in my Zoloft dose. That is not something I am going to be willing to do. It is true that many patients with OCD anxiety require a higher dose of Zoloft. (My doc put the odds that 50mg would be sufficient for me at around 50%). But I am just not willing to deal with the side effects of an increased dose. The cure can sometimes be worse than the disease. And I need to be able to function. So I will get whatever benefit I can get from the 50mg of Zoloft -- assuming I can resolve the sleep 
issues -- and then deal with the rest through the CBT/ERP I am doing."
175981038,Sounds awful.
175981039,"I had a volunteer job as a telephone counselor. I'd recovered from a few years of bad depression, and I felt obliged to do something for other depressed people. Don't ask me why I thought one-on-one counseling would be a suitable activity for me, but it ended up having a lot of benefits. The training is actually really good for learning how to talk to other people in all sorts of situations, and I could get out of Christmas, New Year etc. by scheduling shifts. It's the only time in my life I've had a cast-iron way to get out of social events where I actually got social credit for escaping. ""Hey, that's so generous of you to give up your Christmas."" Ha. Hardly anyone calls crisis lines in the middle of the day on public holidays. The peak comes afterwards, when people have spent the day lonely or arguing with family. So I could put my feet up in an soundproofed call room and read a book instead of having to go to a party. That's probably the most schizoid moment, but when I quit was typical too. I
t was one in the morning, and I was listening to someone who was really depressed. I realised that I was actively hoping that they'd turn out to be suicidal so I could call in a police intervention instead of having to listen to the details of their life for another ten minutes. No more telephone counseling for me after that, but I do miss the quiet of the call room in the early hours of the morning."

175981045,"I just want to say a couple of things that helped me. I also used to say, why me, what did I ever do to deserve this kind of anxiety. One day it finally dawned on me, why not me. Every cancer patient says why me, every heart attack patient says why me, every person that can’t afford their rent says why me. There are millions of people in this world walking around saying why me. So, why me, because we are all human beings and we all have something bad Also, I kept wondering when my anxiety was finally going to be cured. The day I realized that anxiety is not cured but rather managed, it really helped me. And I work hard every day to manage it and I have more good days than bad days. Finally, I am a good bit older than you and have a daughter your age. If I found out she was suffering from anxiety without telling me I would be very upset. I want my children to let me help them with all their problems. That is what parents are for."

That is the time to think about diabetes, before you get it. Net says to reduce chances of getting diabetes: 1. Cut Sugar and Refined Carbs From Your Diet. 2. Work Out Regularly. 3. Drink Water as Your Primary Beverage. 4. Lose Weight If You're Overweight or Obese. 5. Quit Smoking. 6. Follow a Very-Low-Carb Diet. 7. Watch Portion Sizes. 8. Avoid Sedentary Behaviors. Best foods are: Fruits (blackberries and strawberries are best for diabetics), vegetables, whole grain bread, brown rice, beans. Instead of refined carb white bre
ad, eat whole grain bread; instead of refined carb flavored yogurt, try natural yogurt; and instead of refined carb breakfast cereal, try oatmeal. Also watch what you buy at the super market, with canned food having the most salt, frozen much less, and fresh food the least of all. For instance, canned corned beef hash has has 980 mg. (40% daily value) of sodium, compared to 43 grams for frozen fish, and 70 mg of salt for fresh chicken, which is lower in cholesterol and fat. Canned lima beans have 300 mg. of salt, while frozen lima beans and broccoli have none (1% for broccoli). 175981067,"I am kind of okay with having support for an experience of suffering, if that support is stoic and quiet rather than an incessant talker. When it comes to something awe inspiring, like stunning views, sunsets, great movie, being in nature; or something that triggers creative thinking, I prefer to be alone. Then, the presence of another, even someone quiet, can interfere with my introspective processes. I guess sharing suffering offers a distraction and dilutes the intensity of pain. Sharing something magical is a distraction that dilutes the intensity of joy."

175981076,"If your situation is one in which you need to remain living at home, I agree that your instinct to remove yourself from the situation is good. Without knowing very much about you or your neighborhood, I can only offer an anecdote. As I grew up in a small town and was dealing with anxiety and depression, I found that walking/jogging/running was a very good outlet for me. Not only did I have a legitimate excuse to escape the house, but the exercise invariably helped me with my headspace. There were many, many runs fueled by anger back then. If you’re in high school, I would really suggest joining a club or team - even if you’re not athletic. I know Covid throws a wrench in this, though. But trying to improve your situation is never pathetic. If you’re out of school, I agree that writing is good, but it is a solitary endeavor which will not help you to meet people. Community is pretty important. Is there a book club or writers’ group in your area you can join? Maybe there is a virtual group? I 
know that initiating these activities seems overwhelming… I’ve been there… but if you can get over that one “hump,” it’s worth it. Also, have you told your family how their fighting is affecting you? Do you feel safe doing so? Additionally, if they can’t love and accept you for who you are, your sexuality and identity are none of their business. Of course it is not “a choice.” Keep yourself safe - both physically and mentally. I do encourage you to reach out to a support group for this. There are several hotlines that can help! Although it may feel like it, you are not alone. You just haven't found your people yet. When you do find them, it's so worth it."

175981168,"I had wanted to post this in the thread about the book by _NAME_ Stone, MD, entitled, The Anatomy of Evil , which began with the _PERSON_ diagram labeled, Where Personality Disorder and Evil Intersect. According to the original post in that thread, Dr. Stone has concluded that, while schizoid personality is present in only about 1% of the population, it is present in 50% of serial killers. There was so much wrong surrounding the _PERSON_ diagram and its author's conclusion that I don't know where to begin. To many lay people, the medical degree can imply virtual omniscience. Many do not stop to consider that, to know anything deeply, the boundaries of one's specialty must needs be narrow. Not only that, but as schizoids know all too well, few medical specialists are even acquainted with, much less experts in, diagnosing SPD. In my very limited reading about SPD, I have never seen Dr. _PERSON_ name mentioned before. To arrive at such an alarming conclusion credibly, Dr. Stone would have had to have 
treated many schizoids for a long time--long enough for a statistically significant number of them to have opened up to him. Ideally, Dr. Stone also would have had to have met and worked directly with a statistically significant number of serial killers. Did he do those things? Another problem I have with Dr. Stone is that he titled his book, The Anatomy of Evil , as opposed to, An Anatomy of Evil . Not only does Dr. Stone seem to imply that the buck stops with his book, but he appears to be attempting to connect objective analysis ('Anatomy') with morality ('Evil'). How Medieval. Dr. Stone presumes to be an expert in a rare personality disorder whose sufferers even more rarely seek treatment, an expert on serial killers, and a _USER_ID_ who has managed to apply scientific methods to the study of moral failure. I don't think even _NAME_ would have presumed so much. And the _PERSON_ diagram. How did Dr. Stone arrive at the relative sizes and arrangement of the sets? How did he arrive at the amount of overlap? 
While what was shown is, of course, not the whole work, the assumptions, generalities, and apparent lack of rigor, compounded by the lurid conclusion, make this a dangerous book. _NAME_ Stone, MD, appears to be assigning the blame for some of society's ugliest crimes to an already marginalized population, one often afflicted with indifference regarding its own existence . That Dr. Stone appears to do this in such a cavalier manner is not only unscientific but ignorant, criminal, inhuman, and, dare I say, Evil."

175981195,"What I know about it is that the legal definition is different than the psychiatric definition (if there is a psychiatric definition of it at all). I know that if pleading the insanity defense, the defendant claims that he or she had little or no control over his or her behavior that led to or caused the alleged crime. People who use the insanity defense often claim that mens rea is impossible or unlikely to be proven. Mens rea, or a guilty mind, has to do with one's intention to commit a crime. Hence, the argument goes something like: if you cannot know that you are committing a crime, then you won't be able to prove mens rea because you don't have a state of mind that permits you to have the knowledge that you are committing a crime. The other element of criminality is the actus reus. This has to do with the action that is prohibited. I am not a lawyer, but I think it's probably equally hard to prove both mens rea and actus reus. But, if you cannot prove one or the other, then that will lead to t
he person not being convicted. I think that the insanity defense mostly influences mens rea. I think that either way, even if you get off because of the insanity defense, you are still liable to be committed to a mental institution for an indefinite period of time in a lot of cases. So it's not like pleading insanity is going to get you off lightly. I am mostly looking at this from a philosophical perspective, as I wrote a paper on the insanity defense one time for a philosophy of law class."
175981196,"My spine has been messed up since a kid. Trampoline accident and a drunk guy jumping on my neck. Closed up spina bifida when I was born. Seems like one vertebrae is half on one side and half on the other side in the opposite way. But no more pain so far! My mom has the S curved spine when she was a kid and they were gonna put a rod in her spine.. But she instead did physical therapy and got better..... So there's hope.. You're just dealing with **** tonnes of stuff. Relax the mind. I can't relax my mind. I tried with every drug. I'm still haz OCD ADHD. The hardest work is the easiest thing that you're like ""I can't believe I just had to do that.. It's so simple that I ignored it.."". Don't worry. Be hippie."

Electronic harassment, electromagnetic torture, or psychotronic torture is a conspiracy theory that government agents make use of electromagnetic radiation (such as the microwave auditory effect), radar, and surveillance techniques to transmit sounds and thoughts into people's heads, affect people's bodies, and harass people.[1][2] Individuals who claim to experience this call themselves ""targeted individuals"" (""this""). They claim they are victims of gang stalking and many have jo
ined support and advocacy groups.[3][4] Multiple medical professionals have evaluated that these experiences are hallucinations; the result of delusional disorders or psychosis,[5][6] the same sources from which arise religious delusions, accounts of alien abductions, and beliefs in visitations from dead relatives. It can be difficult to persuade people who experience them that their belief in an external influence is delusional.[1][2] The experiences of people who describe themselves as undergoing electronic harassment using esoteric technology, and who call themselves ""targeted individuals"" (""T.I.""), vary, but experiences often include hearing voices in their heads calling them by name, often mocking them or others around them, as well as physical sensations like burning.[1][2] They have also described being under physical surveillance by one or more people.[1] Many of these people act and function otherwise normally and included among them are people who are successful in their careers and lives otherw
ise, and who find these experiences confusing, upsetting, and sometimes shameful, but entirely real.[1] They use news stories, military journals, and declassified national security documents to support their allegations that governments have developed technology that can send voices into people's heads and cause them to feel things.[1] The New York Times estimated that there are more than 10,000 people who self-identify as targeted individuals.[7][8] Psychologist _NAME_ co-authored a study of gang-stalking in the Journal of Forensic Psychiatry & Psychology. According to _NAME_, ""One has to think of the T.I. a phenomenon in terms of people with paranoid symptoms who have hit upon the gang-stalking idea as an explanation of what is happening to them"".[7] Mental health professionals say that T.I.s can experience hallucinations and their explanations of being targeted or harassed arise from delusional disorders or psychosis.[1][6][9][5][10] Yale psychiatry professor _NAME_ states that people often ascribe voice
s in their heads to external sources such as government harassment, God, or dead relatives, and it can be difficult to persuade these individuals that their belief in an external influence is delusional.[1] Other experts compare these stories to accounts of alien abductions.[2] Press accounts have documented individuals who apparently believed they were victims of electronic harassment, and in some cases persuaded courts to agree. In 2008, _NAME_ went to court claiming that his former business associate had threatened him with ""jolts of radiation"" after a disagreement, and later claimed feeling symptoms such as electric shock sensations and hearing strange sounds in his ears. The court decided to issue an order banning ""electronic means"" to further harass _PERSON_.[11]"

175981210,"My husband has adult ADD and what helped him is intermittent fasting. His last meal is usually around 2:30 and won't eat again until the morning. Plus he eats mostly what I eat which is a Paleo type diet for my medical condition. So no grains, sugar, preservatives. Just fresh whole foods, meats and veggies, fruits and aged cheeses, nuts, etc. He went from 204 to 170 lbs in 6 months. He also finds some workouts on YouTube to do. That's the key. If you don't like the exercise, you won't do it. So find what you do like, whether it's cardio or dance, walking, or weights and if you like it, you'll stick to it. I hope you can find something that works for you."

175981277,"A good link I found# Gaslighting is a malicious form of mental and emotional abuse, designed to plant seeds of self-doubt and alter your perception of reality. Like all abuse, it based on the need for power, control, or concealment. Some people occasionally lie or use denial to avoid taking responsibility. They may forget or remember conversations and events differently than you, or they may have no recollection due to a blackout if they were drinking. These situations are sometimes called gaslighting, but the term actually refers to a deliberate pattern of manipulation calculated to make the victim doubt his or her own perceptions or sanity, similar to brainwashing. The term derives from the play and later film Gaslight with _NAME_ and _NAME_. _PERSON_ plays a sensitive, trusting wife struggling to preserve her identity in an abusive marriage to _PERSON_, who tries to convince her that she’s ill in order to keep her from learning the truth. Gaslighting Behavior As in the movie, the perpetrator o
ften acts concerned and kind to dispel any suspicions. Someone capable of persistent lying and manipulation is also quite capable of being charming and seductive. Often the relationship often begins that way. When gaslighting starts, you might even feel guilty for doubting the person whom you’ve come to trust. To further play with your mind, an abuser might offer evidence to show that you’re wrong or question your memory or senses. More justifications and explanations, including expressions of love and flattery, are concocted to confuse you and reason away any discrepancies in the liar’s story. You get temporary reassurance, but increasingly, you doubt your own senses, ignore your gut, and become more confused. The person gaslighting might act hurt and indignant or play the victim when challenged or questioned. Covert manipulation can easily turn into overt abuse with accusations that you’re distrustful, ungrateful, unkind, overly sensitive, dishonest, stupid, insecure, crazy, or abusive. Abuse might 
escalate to anger and intimidation with punishment, threats, or bullying if you don’t accept the false version of reality. Gaslighting can take place in the workplace or in any relationship. Generally, it concerns control, infidelity, or money. A typical scenario is when an intimate partner lies to conceal a relationship with someone else. In other cases, it may be to conceal gambling debts or stock or investment losses. The manipulator is often an addict, a narcissist, or a sociopath, particularly if gaslighting is premeditated or used to cover up a crime. In one case, a sociopath was stealing from his girlfriend whose apartment he shared. She gave him money each month to pay the landlord, but he kept it. He hacked into her credit cards and bank accounts, but was so devious that to induce her trust he bought her gifts with her money and pretended to help her find the hacker. It was only when the landlord eventually informed her that she was way behind in the rent that she discovered her boyfriend’s treac
hery. When the motive is purely control, a spouse might use shame to undermine his or her partner’s confidence, loyalty, or intelligence. A wife might attack her husband’s manhood and manipulate him by calling him weak or spineless. A husband might undermine his wife’s self-esteem by criticizing her looks or competence professionally or as a mother. A typical tactic is to either claim that friends or relatives agree with the manipulator’s negative statements or to disparage them so that that they cannot be trusted in order to isolate the victim and gain greater control. A similar strategy is to undermine the partner’s relationships with friends and relatives by accusing him or her of disloyalty. Effects of Gaslighting Gaslighting can be very insidious the longer it occurs. Initially, you won’t realize you’re being affected by it, but gradually you lose trust in your own instincts and perceptions. It can be very damaging, particularly in a relationship built on trust and love. Love and attachment 
are strong incentives to believe the lies and manipulation. We use denial, because we rather believe the lie than the truth, which might precipitate a painful breakup. Gaslighting can damage our self-confidence and self-esteem, trust in ourselves and reality, and our openness to love again. If it involves verbal abuse, we may believe the truth of the abuser’s criticisms and continue to blame and judge ourselves even after the relationship is over. Many abusers putdown and intimidate their partners to make them dependent so they won’t leave. Examples are: “You’ll never find anyone as good as me,” “The grass isn’t greener,” or “No one else would put up with you.” Article continues below... TALK TO A THERAPIST NOW: Therapists live, online right now, from BetterHelp: _NAME_ Green _NAME_ Green, LCSW, MSW _NAME_, MS, LPC, NCC _NAME_, LCSW Heather _PERSON_ Heather _PERSON_, MS, LADC, LPC _NAME_, LPC, NCC _NAME_, LCSW-R Recovery from a breakup or divorce can be more difficult when we’ve been in 
denial about problems in the relationship. Denial often continues even after the truth comes out. In the story described above, the woman got engaged to her boyfriend after she found out what he’d done. It takes time for us to reinterpret our experience in light of all the facts once they become known. It can be quite confusing, because we may love the charmer, but hate the abuser. This is especially true if all the bad behavior was out of sight, and memories of the relationship were mostly positive. We lose not only the relationship and person we loved and/or shared a life with, but also trust in ourselves and future relationships. Even if we don’t leave, the relationship is forever changed. In some cases when both partners are motivated to stay and work together in conjoint therapy, the relationship can be strengthened and the past forgiven. Recovery from Gaslighting Learn to identify the perpetrator’s behavior patterns. Realize that they’re due to his or her insecurity and shame, not yours. Get sup
port. It’s critical that you have a strong support system to validate your reality in order to combat gaslighting. Isolation makes the problem worse and relinquishes your power to the abuser. Join Codependents Anonymous (CoDA.org) and seek counseling. Once you acknowledge what’s going on, you’re more able to detach and not believe or react to falsehoods, even though you may want to. You’ll also realize that the gaslighting is occurring due to your partner’s serious characterlogical problems. It does not reflect on you, nor can you change someone else. For an abuser to change, it takes willingness and effort by both partners. Sometimes when one person changes, the other also does in response. However, if he or she is an addict or has a personality disorder, change is difficult. To assess your relationship and effectively confront unwanted behavior, get my book Dealing with a Narcissist: 8 Steps to raise Self-Esteem and Set Boundaries with Difficult People. Once victims come out of denial, it’s comm
on for them to mentally want to redo the past. They’re often self-critical for not having trusted themselves or stood up to the abuse. Don’t do this! Instead of perpetuating self-abuse, learn how to stop self-criticism and raise your self-esteem. You also need to learn how to be assertive and how to set boundaries to stop abuse. ©Darlenelancer 2017"

When I was there, I suffered so much abuse, from pharmacological torture, to solitary confinement to bullying, that I tried to kill myself while I was in the hospital. From that moment forward, my life and freedoms have been gone and so has my trust for counselors. That's also the reason why I turn to online for help, is because I have no friends in real life and because everything you say to a counselor is NOT confidential. They can and will lie to you about certain things, such as a thing that happened to me recently. And the medication is only treatment. In fact, it's called TREATMENT for a reason, because it's only a tempo
rary fix. By using it, you become a drug addict. In truth, there are many causes of mental illness, however from some recent studies that I've found is that consumption of seeds is actually one of the main causes of mental illness. In fact, grains rot your teeth. That's why there's been links between celiac disease and Schizophrenia. The true cure for all mental illness is simply changing your diet. Most Americans eat mostly vegetables and grains. Look at the food pyramid, which has been vegan since 2005. It says you need to eat plenty of GRAINS, which is not what you're supposed to eat if you want to remain healthy. If you want to cure yourself of mental illness, all that is needed is to simply change your diet. And by that, I mean namely either the zero carb (carnivore) diet or at least keto. There has been much research on this, and it all suggests that other than environmental causes, poor dietary choices is one of the leading causes of mental illness in America. 175981411,"Beware of confirmation bias. If the traffic light is red every single time you stop at an intersection, that doesn't mean you're unlucky or the light is out to get you, it just means you don't stop at the intersection when the light is green. The light is indeed red every single time you stop, and that's an accurate statement, but it's still miles away from being an accurate assessment of reality. Accuracy, truth, reality, faithfulness and good intentions are all different things. As for myself, within my ability, I treat people the way I want to be treated. And, within reason, that also includes taking into account the fact that they won't expect or benefit or suffer exactly from the same exact things as I would. Because it's one of the main things I want others to consider when I'm concerned as well. Namely: they're not me, and I'm not them. If people fail to reciprocate, then I reciprocate their failure. Some people take offense at that. That's the point when it's not up to me and not my problem
."

174376855,"Hello _PERSON_: Thank you for sharing your concern with us here on PC. I'm sorry I'm not going to be of any help with this. (Perhaps there may yet be other PC members who will have some thoughts they can share.) In the meantime, however, I noticed this is your first post. So I thought I would at least say welcome to Psych Central. Most of us, here on PC, are consumers of mental health services not mental health professionals. And, based on what you wrote, it sounds to me as though figuring out what is actually going on with your gf, as well as what to do about it, is a job for a mental health professional... perhaps a psychologist, a psychiatrist or a mental health therapist. You didn't mention if your gf is under the care of any type(s) of mental health professional(s). If not, I think the best thing that could be done to assist her may be to help her to find appropriate mental health treatment. Here are links to 4 articles, from Psych Central's archives, that may be of interest depending on your 
gf's current mental health treatment situation: Supporting Friends and Family Who Have Mental Illnesses 15 Ways To Support a Loved One with Serious Mental Illness How to Persuade Your Loved One to Seek Professional Help 11 Ways to Help a Loved One in Denial I hope you find PC to be of benefit."

It causes a painful rash that then blisters and is usually only on one side of the body I had it on the right side of my neck and up onto right side of head. 174377029,"I am grateful as I said for my job. It is a fun job!! I am meeting all kinds of people. I am exercising still but am not as disciplined about it. Sometimes, I feel tired then I rest. It breaks my heart about the homeless, but I used to be one of them. I have been blessed to come this far in a short period of time. However, since I was homeless, I had a serious setback two years ago because I stopped my medication. Thus, I don't want to repeat history again. I report taking my medication daily to my father. He is happy I do this. I feel tired at times from it but have no major complaints because it has been helping me remain stable. Life is amazing! I've had my ups and downs. I have to say I've had more down periods than up periods. I'd like to change this. Ever since I've had psychosis, it has been a battle for me. But, the medication is really he
lpful these days. When I first became psychotic, I changed from rispedal to Zyprexa to Seroquel to Clozapine to Geodon to Abilify. Abilify, it is for me now. This medication helps but at times mild psychosis breaks through then I stop my medication. I have to remember when the symptoms come worse to see my doctor and take my medication faithfully. I was doing well for three years then decided the heck with it. But, I had a hard time with my parents this last time. They never allowed me to go out the house without them. It was like being in prison! I had enough of this, I thought. I need to become more responsible for myself or else, just check out of life. I decided to fight for my freedom!! And, I am free now!! I am free and working. I am healthy too!! I thank God for my life and the blessings!! I must say after two years of imprisonment, I was ready to check out, thank God, I did not. The man who befriended me is nice and supportive! He is good to me. But, as I said, we will remain just friends. Well, I hav
e to teach tonight. I have to teach this weekend too!! Life is swell."

175981591,"I am beautifully bipolar and overweight and I love myself. It is easy to hate – to hate the jiggle of your belly, the fact that you would never imagine a gap in your thighs. Hate is easy. Love is a lot more complicated. The world feeds us this bullshit that you are not worthy of love and respect if you are “thick” or a “big girl” or, gasp, “fat.” I used to be part of the machine that creates this poison in my twenties. I worked in the fashion departments of magazines. I worked on seasons of New York Fashion Week. I styled some shoots in _NAME_. I helped make people like the current me feel bad about themselves and I am sad about that. But if you live with bipolar disorder chances you are overweight or obese. It is okay. You are in the majority with me. When we are depressed we do not really have an amazing amount of energy to make it to the gym. We are lucky to have the energy to shower. For some of us, depression makes us crave food. When you are eating more but not moving more, the 
pounds slide on. I wish I could tell you the secret to exercise motivation, but I have am at a loss. I have not one, but two, gym memberships and I still do not go. 75% of people living with bipolar disorder are overweight or obese. Not a very hopeful number to overcome. But it is possible. Diet and exercise help but there are other factors which make it hard. Many medications we take pack on the pounds. In the beginning I was prescribed a medication on which I gained twenty pounds in a month. (I got off of it). https://blogs.psychcentral.com/being-bipolar/2019/07/10/i-am-beautifully-bipolar-and-i-am-overweight/"

175981613,"Some people in our world find humor in watching neurotic people on TV, such as long time comedy actor _NAME_, or _NAME_ on the sitcom from the 1990s, Seinfeld. And a friend of mine who worried a great deal about little things liked to laugh at himself because of it. But being neurotic is nothing to be laughed at. Being neurotic is a very serious issue and can interfere with how happy you are in life. It's more difficult to be happy in life if you get all worried over every little thing. Take it from someone who knows. I used to be like that. However, with a combination of psychotherapy, medication, and setting as well as achieving realistic goals, I was able to overcome it. Nowadays I'm much more calm. I don't worry about the little things nearly as much as I used to. If you are like how I used to be, you can overcome it. Hey, I did."

175981649,"So I feel quite unmotivated with a lower mood two days without phenibut. Phenibut and Vyvanse really help with my negative symptoms. This is very interesting research about GABA-B receptors and schizophrenia; GABA B Receptors, Schizophrenia and Sleep Dysfunction | SpringerLink It says that people with schizophrenia often have trouble with slow wave sleep and less GABA-B receptors (Which leads to increased dopamine) - agonists (Like phenibut, baclofen and the narcolepsy med GHB) can help improve memory and cognition by improving sleep. And that benzos and z-drugs like zolpidem worsen cognition."

175981651,"I am a 59-year-old woman who has never felt like I am good enough. On the outside, you would think I have nothing to complain about; my life looks good, but, on the inside, I feel like I am always trying to hide the fact that I'm not good enough. I was raised by a mother who never told me she loved me. She criticized me constantly, and, even when I was six-years-old, would give me the silent treatment when I did something wrong. She was cold and unforgiving. It is difficult to explain to those who had loving mothers how it makes you feel to think your mother doesn't love you unless you are perfect. She never had fun with us, and we all felt as if we were a burden to her. To this day, I am still trying to impress her, and she is 88. I got married when I was 19 to the first person who told me he loved me just to get out of the house, which was the wrong thing to do, I know. The man was five years older than I was and very nice, but not for me. I was divorced after a year. I went on to marry and divor
ce two more times, both to men who did not treat me well, but they told me they loved me in the beginning, and that's what I needed to hear. I am constantly trying to be perfect, in my looks, my house, my job, etc. If someone critiques me, I take it very personally and feel like a failure. I know the what and why of how I feel; I just don't know how to overcome it and be happy. I have had counseling, and it has taken three years to uncover the reasons for why I have made the choices I have made, and I am ready to work on making myself happy, not my mother. But, if I do overcome all of it, who would want me after I have been married three times? There are days when I feel crushed by the sadness I feel."

175981664,"hi, we can not live in a bubble. If you practice the right protocols, then nothing to fear. When the anxiety hits, it is good to distract from these thoughts that are presenting, of which we generally call stinking thinking. Having things to occupy as at this time is crucial. A toolbox method we use, my toolbox, music, cold water on head, some use ice in hands. Distraction is key. You already know it passes, and that at certain times it is less problematic. For me, it is the quieter moments when it comes on, the brain starts with mulling over things, like a cobra readying itself to strike. Sometimes for people it is other things, fear, situations, etc. i use incense to quieten down my mind. Keep strong. Look at the resources thread at the top. it is good. Well done on reaching out here as well. HT"

175981773,"Yes, which is still bad if it happens fast. Even with those low estimates, he still is advocating that measures should be taken. Which means it is not a conspiracy, if the main guy of the task force in the US downplays it. Take the Hong Kong and Asian flu pandemics, and condense them into a few months, instead of a year or two, and it is relatively bigger in terms of impact. Mostly people in general seem to be overestimating the death ratio, and underestimating the spread rate. Like in his paper, he uses an R of 2.2, which is low, but consistent with what happened in China, arguably. It's a lot faster in Europe and North America. Not something people knew about March 16 when he published this. His current estimates are higher. Also, people like to point out the 0.1% death ratio for the flu, but that includes poor countries. In first world countries, the ratio of death from the flu is usually 10x lower. This can give a general idea. https://www.researchgate.net/publicatio ... f_COVID-19 They only di
agnosed 5 out of 1000 people in the US, so unless you know 200 people, chances are you won't know anybody that has it yet. It only really started a few months ago, give it a year. Plenty of people got it, but didn't realize it, or thought it was the flu, or had no symptoms. Hard to tell, but its an opinion. It's not a reason to deny reality. I do think some countries have reacted to fast and too strongly and are suffering for nothing, but they would need to act at some point. The last holdout is Sweden, which acted softly, but are reconsidering. Their economy still slowed down, it's not like it is business as usual. This being said, letting people die or simply killing them is usually good for the economy, if its the right people. Not so much anymore in a consumer economy, but people still have those ideas that only productive people help the economy. Now being a hero is staying home and consuming local. You can look at Europe with their negative interest rates. They pay good borrowers to borrow money. Like I

175981793,"There are very few people out there who are genuine. You just gotta sort out the good and the bad. I'm guilty of letting people walk all over me because like the fool in the story, because I want to make people happy. The Fool - Fruitsbasket YouTube _PERSON_ has a point Once upon a time, there was a foolish traveler who had gone on a journey. Why was he foolish? Well, because he was fooled by everyone he met! ""Please, some money for medicine...?"" Everywhere he went, people made up all kinds of sad stories to tell him, and the traveler fell for every one of them. ""I have a sick younger sister..."" ""I don't have money to buy seeds to plant in my fields."" Pretty soon, his money, his clothes, even his shoes had been cheated away from him. But the foolish traveler was always glad to help. And he always told the people the same thing. He said: ""I wish you happiness."" But by this point, though, the traveler was completely naked, and with nothing left to cover himself, he decided to leave the main r
oad and travel through the dense forest, where no one could see him... But soon, he was discovered by the goblins that lived in the woods. The goblins wanted to eat the traveler's body, so they begged and pleaded, and used kind words to try and trick him... Of course, the traveler was fooled. First, he let the goblins eat one of his legs. Then an arm. Then more and more... Before it was over, all that the traveler had left was his head. He'd even given his eyes away to the last of the goblins... And as that last goblin was eating the traveler's eyes, he turned and said ""Thank you, traveler. In return, I leave you this present."" What the goblin left was a slip of paper, with the word ""fool"" written on it. The traveler couldn't see it. He didn't know what it was. Even so, tears began to flow down his face. ""Thank you,"" he said. ""This is the first present anyone ever gave me. I'm so happy. I'm so happy. Thank you."" Even without his eyes, he cried and cried, great tears of joy. Then, the traveler died, th
e smile still on his face. see? loss, hardship, things like that? you can’t only focus on them. the traveler didn’t…he never thought about his own troubles at all. i imagine that it probably does sound really foolish to some people. but i don’t think he’s foolish at all. even though other people probably think he was being tricked? i don’t think he was. i think he did exactly what he wanted to do. i think, more than anything, he just wanted to make others happy."

175981872,"There’s more to forensic psychiatry than the medical model. There’s psychoanalysis of course. A psychopath who isn’t antisocial (they do exist) is still a psychopath, but your much beloved descriptive psychiatry is not detecting them, while it erroneously lumps heterogeneous people based on external behaviors that have different intrapsychic meanings, potentially failing the first and most important step in treatment: correctly identify the diagnosis. Like I said, it’s technically possible for a serial killer to be neither antisocial nor psychopathic - like _PERSON_ - but they are exceptions. Some are are highly narcissistic, but the vast majority have ASPD or full-blown psychopathy. It doesn’t mean they can’t be schizoid or borderline too. But unlike psychopathy or schizoid PD, BPD in a serial killer won’t be a major psychopathological factor, apparently. Serial murder has to be the most antisocial thing someone can do, yet you still struggle with the notion that they are most likely 
at least ASPD. Go figure. Also why you give full credit to some internet articles but you can’t trust that the leading expert on psychopathic behavior knows what he’s talking about is another baffling question. You don’t need an official diagnosis to see that _PERSON_ was schizoid for the same reason that you don’t need a meteorologist to notice that the sky is blue. But don’t stop there and read more about him. Unless you don’t trust yourself… Finally, I have no idea where you got the idea that schizoid is not part of BPO."

175981924,"This: it's non-stop, I wake up thinking lots of weird stuff at a fast pace and it's annoying. Exactly the same for me. And many many other people who knows or fear that their thoughts are being heard. It all comes down to fear of rejection/being portrayed as a weirdo/psycho/crazy person. And ofc its a very VERY unpleasant feeling. But! Think like this: we're already rejected from this society. The day we got psychosis, that day is also the day we got rejected. They wanted us to know they're hearing our thoughts and that they're observing us 24/7. They have done it all our lives. So They know you inside out. They know how you react to certain stimuli, they know how you think in general, etc.. And lastly, they know you're not a threat. The last part is important. What ever ###$ up thoughts you think in a ocd'ish type of way(just like i do) they will act on it just to make you feel down BUT they know your PROFILE so dont worry. They wont do $#%^. hats just laughable, _USER_ID_ about anymore. What im trying to say is what ever you think they think about you(that youre horrible/crazy/weirdo) that doesnt mean a single $#%^! It all depends on what you're looking for when you listen to _PERSON_ piano sonatas. Do you want drab and gray, or do you want lively and colorful? _PERSON_ is amongst the greatest to ever live because he had such as happy sound to everything he played. He made it his own. He didn't just read the sheet music and play it like a robot, he added flair and personality to it, and what a likable personality it was. He could take the dreariest, melancholic piece and bring the sun and the bright blue sky out with it. Then you have someone like _PERSON_, who in terms of p
ure, raw skill is probably the best pianist to ever live in my opinion, but he played with that dark, doom and gloom tone. The biggest ""doom and gloom"" piece for solo piano is _PERSON_ Piano Sonata in B minor. This is the piece the classical and baroque era purists go to when they say ""this is why I don't like the romantic era! It's not because I haven't been able to wipe my own ass in ten years, it's because it's so dark and depressing!"" It's a lovely piece, _PERSON_ was a master of the piano, literally if you play everything he composed for solo piano, non-stop, it would play for over 24 hours. The man transcribed _PERSON_ nine symphonies for piano, and it did every last one of them justice. Some guy transcribed _PERSON_ piano sonata in B minor to solo violin and it's awful sounding. You can't take such a complex piece and transcribe it to a single string instrument. An entire orchestra would have been better, or a string orchestra, or hell, even a string quartet, but a solo violin? It's disgusting soun

175981966,"Hi!! I have lots and lots of diagnosis's that have caused me to have chronic pain every day. I've had 17 hours straight of excruciating pain. I know what you are going through. The best way I've found is this: When my pain gets severe or is the kind to stick around, I ask my fiance to rub my arm or something. By his rubbing his hand softly on my arm, my brain can now focus on a the good feeling of his touch instead of the horrible pain. It normally doesn't take more than maybe a half hour for the pain to go away. It's amazing how the brain works. By concentrating on the good feeling the brain is no longer thinking of the pain. The longer it can concentrate on a good feeling the less it's recognizing the pain. If this is done long enough eventually your pain goes away. I hope this helps you. _NAME_"

175981985,"I was told from a Dr that I was spot on panic attacks for sure. But, I'll start from the beginning, I'd love to get other patients' input on things - not that I don't trust my Dr, but I wonder if they have 1 diagnosis, do they stop looking for other things in the mental health world? And the Dr that diagnosed my panic attacks is not the Dr that I am currently seeing. So maybe he just went along with the original diagnosis. In my early 20s, I started having panic attacks, they started suddenly. By the book description too. That sudden electric feeling in the stomach. The tingly through my arms and legs, up the back of my neck to my brain. Racing thoughts always circling around doom and death. The thoughts start small and then grow to leading to demise. I rock back and forth, I want to cry but it's like there is too much terror in my brain to even have the ability to cry. I come from a family who does not discuss mental health. I was suddenly the black sheep bc I was spiralling out of control and had 
no one to talk to no one to relate to this and no one was or even is willing to educate themselves on mental health. When the attacks first started on more than 1 occasion, the doctor's attempted to hospitlize me but my parents talked them out of it. I don't feel like I have extreme mania or extreme depression. I do have a tendency to get super passionate about a project or a hobby and then with in a few days, lose all interest in it. People say I wash my hands excessively. I have control issues and trust issues. Sometimes I get angry over the most trivial thing and the response I have is extreme. It use to be worse when I was in my 20s. If I would get in an argument with my parents, I'd trade my car in, change my phone number, not talk to anyone in my family for weeks or months sometimes. Now in my late 30s, if my husband doesn't do something that I ask him to or if something I'm trying to do doesn't go my way, I usually end up crying and yelling and throwing things away. Here's an example... I wanted a shel
f above my kitchen sink. My original plan didnt work. I thought of another way to put the shelf up but it wasn't working and my husband said why are you working so hard for a shelf, just forget it. And I started to cry and shake and ripped it down and threw it away and didn't talk to him for the rest of the day. I knew it was an extreme response later but in the moment I was so upset I didn't think. I get antsy while waiting. Whether I'm waiting in the drive thru at fast food or waiting for someone to grab something at the store. If things don't move at my pace, and my pace is very fast, then I get agitated. I always figured that was related to my control issues but maybe someone here can relate and give me direction."

175982005,"Hello bernimac32, Welcome to Inspire! Thank you for sharing your story. We encourage you to check other discussions in this community about addiction. You can start by typing your search terms in the box near the magnifying glass at the top right side of the page or by clicking the link below. Search: Addiction Our partner for this community, Mental Health America, also provides resources on their website including information about treatment options, guided recovery techniques, and self-help toolkits. This information can be found at the following links. Mental Health America: Finding Help for Myself Mental Health America: Recovery and Support Mental Health America: DIY Tools In addition, you may want to check out our iFred community. 175982022,"People with celiac disease are 17 times more likely to have bipolar disorder than those without celiac. I had gut problems for decades. I thought it was normal to feel like crap after I ate. Then I was diagnosed with celiac disease and my life completely changed. I feel great since eliminating gluten from my diet. I have more energy, I’m not sick all the time and I’m less moody. The moody part really intrigued me, so I looked into how celiac and bipolar relate. It turns out there is a strong association between the two diseases. Also, comorbidity with a mood disorder is a key indicator in measuring quality of life in individuals with celiac disease. 1 -2% of the population has celiac disease. In this group 4.3% are diagnosed with bipolar disorder. In the research cited, in the non-celiac control group only .4% had bipolar disorder. There’s growing evidence that autoimmune disorders and bipolar disorder are closely associated. Celiac disease increases immune activation, which is hypothesized t
o act as an important factor in the onset of bipolar disorder. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/older-bipolar/2019/07/bipolar-disorder-and-celiac-disease/"

175982046,"Medications.. They're chemicals.. We are chemicals.. sometimes our chemicals can be imbalanced.. All these psychiatric meds can help people that have been damaged from psychosis and mania or inducing drugs.. or when the neurotransmitters are just squeezed out, depression. Meds are like anti-drugs. The antidote. So stopping them would be like wanting to take drugs to make you feel better.. or normal.. many take drugs to feel normal.. and other times, to get high.. But the point is this.. which ever wave of the drug-light spectrum paradox, we're never normal.. no one is.. And if you feel better on meds, you want to stop them because who wants to take meds? No one. Only a crazy person.. Who has to take meds? Well.. someone that needs them.. The point where you decided that you needed them could outweigh any irrational effects that you feel when you're stabilized to give proof.. or not? It's so ****ing hard to distinguish what is real when the illness is about losing touch with reality.. because what i
s reality? Subjective is all you know.. but objectively, others can give a different perspective.. but only you know yourself best - No one else.. A psychiatrist can be right.. but then again, you have to think, what is a psychiatrist? They use rules based on objective research.. it all contradicts, especially with spirituality.. or just a summary of it, ruled by government and culture.. culture is really what determines who is sane.. many people speak different languages.. and then you think about science.. who's making the vaccines for example? God? It's an excuse for not going in deeper.. And sometimes you just think so deeply that you get cognitive fatigue and stress that you want it all to stop.. people judge you for not keeping it together when we're all really crazy and going down this rabbit hole.. sometimes you just need a break, to sleep.. be sedated on antipsychotics.. decrease every single chemical completely.. but when it's all gone, BOOM, everything happens.. So you have to take this into consid
eration.. it's ok to go off meds for a little bit only after you have lowered the dose.. you don't just jump off the cliff and think you can walk in the valley without falling.."

175982063,"The web says ""Dysarthria"" is: ""Speech that is characteristically slurred, slow, and difficult to understand. A person with dysarthria may also have problems controlling the pitch, loudness, rhythm, and voice qualities of his or her speech. Dysarthria is caused by paralysis, weakness, or inability to coordinate the muscles of the mouth. Dysarthria can occur as a developmental disability. It may be a sign of a neuromuscular disorder such as cerebral palsy or Parkinson's disease. It may also be caused by a stroke, brain injury, or brain tumor. Treatment of dysarthria includes intensive speech therapy with a focus on oral-motor skill development."" You said: ""Apparently, dysarthria (the technical term for her problem) is common with many medications. It should improve, but we need a strategy in the interim. If she were able to type (not sure at this point), there are type-to-speech programs out there."" It's good that you are trying to help her. Are you able to visit her?"

175982105,"Bipolar Disorder and Celiac Disease People with celiac disease are 17 times more likely to have bipolar disorder than those without celiac. I had gut problems for decades. I thought it was normal to feel like crap after I ate . Then I was diagnosed with celiac disease and my life completely changed. I feel great since eliminating gluten from my diet. I have more energy, I’m not sick all the time and I’m less moody. The moody part really intrigued me, so I looked into how celiac and bipolar relate. It turns out there is a strong association between the two diseases. Also, comorbidity with a mood disorder is a key indicator in measuring quality of life in individuals with celiac disease. 1 -2% of the population has celiac disease. In this group 4.3% are diagnosed with bipolar disorder. In the research cited, in the non-celiac control group only .4% had bipolar disorder. There’s growing evidence that autoimmune disorders and bipolar disorder are closely associated. Celiac disease increases immun
e activation, which is hypothesized to act as an important factor in the onset of bipolar disorder. The metabolic explanation is that malabsorption of tryptophan leads to a decreased central serotonin synthesis. Also, cytokines common in celiac may exert an effect on the brain circuits related to mood regulation. The researchers won’t go as far as to say that celiac disease causes bipolar disorder, but they do surmise that in people with a vulnerability to bipolar, there is a risk that celiac triggers the mood disorder. The study also noted the profound impact the two disease’s co-occurrence can have on quality of life (QOL). “The results show, surprisingly, that in the absence of psychiatric illness people with celiac disease do not have an impaired QOL compared to the people who do not suffer from celiac disease. But when measuring the burden suffered by people with celiac disease comorbid with mood disorders, the “dual diagnosis”… lowers the quality of life in the same manner as serious chronic 
diseases.” In fact, the study suggests that the negative impact on QOL in people with celiac disease and bipolar disorder is second only to that of people with bipolar and MS. I know my life has vastly improved since my diagnosis of celiac disease. Small inconveniences such as difficulties in restaurants pale in comparison to the violent mood swings and intestinal distress I suffered before and have since largely disappeared since I changed my diet. Please understand, though, that my bipolar disorder is still medically treated as it was before I knew I had celiac disease. Removing gluten from my diet has not led to the removal of my psych meds. My bipolar disorder is not cured. I just feel a lot better. In concluding their study, the researchers suggest r it is advisable to perform an adequate screening for celiac disease on all the people with bipolar disorder that show some key symptoms or have a family history of celiac disease. And everyone diagnosed with celiac disease should be screened for a mood dis
order. click here to Read more: ( https://blogs.psychcentral.com/older-bipolar/2019/07/bipolar-disorder-and-celiac-disease/?utm_source=Psych+Central+Weekly+Newsletter&utm_campaign=fc0ad0d86c-BIP_EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_COPY_01&utm_medium=email... )"
175982106,"I'm a bicyclist. Ever since last month's accident near Las Vegas in which a truck plowed into a group of 20 cyclists, killing 5, my anxiety has risen and it's difficult to stop thinking about it. This has happened to me before. As a cyclist, I've done everything I can control, and am a 100% attentive, defensive and abide by all rules of the road. I was hit by a driver as a kid, and landed in the hospital for a week, but thankfully don't remember anything. I've had motorists throw things at me, etc. With all the distracted driving going on, I know I take a chance riding my bike. I stay on roads with designated bike lanes or on trails that are reserved for non-motor-vehicle traffic."
